Early-Access review: UNIQUE. One of the best co-op games I've ever played. It's complex and very deep mechanically. The submarine editor is an astonishing feat, I feel like I'm programming. There are many different systems, from submarine sections, air and water propagation, ballasts, electricity and circuitry, logic doors... The amount of possibilities in building your submarine seems endless. I've personnaly spent countless hours building a sub to use it on a campaign, and it is so rewarding. You're building your ship to your liking, and need to foul test it to detect design issues or bugs until you get it right. You even have wifi nodes, and you can actually build a drone ship which may attach to the sub and you may control from a PC in the main one (how cool is that?).

Gameplay-wise,  it's amazing. After building your sub, you need to assemble a crew and take advantage of its possibilities, manage it efficiently. Apart from that, you get your own character class, inventory management, resource-management, future-planning... Exploring the world is super fun, but it's also a horror experience. Tension is always palpable, and it is so immersive. Putting on your dive suit to go out and explore a cave, fighting with monsters or people alike, underwater or in interiors. 

Story/Plot was mostly superficial in EA, as well as factions and skill trees, so I'm not reviewing that. (No need, the rest is just so good already).

It's a must play with at least a colleague.

Barotrauma is an immersive co-op submarine crew simulation centered on teamwork and hopes of the people of Europa. The game starts you off with the cheapest recycled submarines available, then assigns you some easy tasks like few transport jobs that are safe and pays enough to feed yourself and your crew. Perhaps you'll even have a little extra to purchase some rounds for your favorite revolver, or a couple of medkits just in case things take a turn for the worse... Or maybe even invest in your ships' armor and formidable guns that will eventually protect you from everything that is not inside the ship! As you progress through the campaign map, you'll see different and vast amount of missions there are in this game. And don't worry, the more dangerous it is the better the pay is! Your goal is to survive and reach the end of the campaign map, which I will not talk about due to spoilers. 
The gameplay loop is exceptional, seamlessly complemented by the randomized campaign map and its nodes. Each experience in this game is unique to the seed and, naturally, friends you're playing with. Moreover, the immersive sound design further enhances the gameplay experience. The engine emitting series of clunky noises accompanied by the heavy, metallic sounds of your submarine moving in cold waters, the oxygen tanks working ceaselessly to sustain life, the ballast tanks regulating water in and out, and the eerie sounds emanating from the unknown creatures lurking in this god forsaken ocean... It's a hopeless situation, but you try to make the best out of it. My personal favorite is the outpost theme called Wartrauma, you'll often hear this theme after a significant battle or as preparation before confronting a titan. It eminates a militaristic and somewhat nostalgic ambiance. And god, does it make you feel like you can conquer everything this moon throws your way!
As you plunge deeper, the atmosphere grows increasingly tense and darker with every meter descended into Europa's frigid and unforgiving ocean. Unwelcoming alien life lurks in the depths, launching unexpected attacks on your submarine. Betrayal simmers among your crew, with some turning against you, seeking to sabotage every endeavor. Traitors conspire to bring down the ship, adding to the perilous array of challenges and pirates attempting to bring you and your crew down. I cannot put this into words properly but when you find a game that is very magical to play for the first time -- like when you played Minecraft for the first time as a kid -- I had the same feeling with Barotrauma. My first experience was a multiplayer lobby filled with great friends of mine, and because of the timezone I'd sacrifice my sleep every night to play with them. It was worth it, and I cherish the many fond memories I had with them.
Barotrauma. It's a great fucking game. Go get a group of friends that are interested. Play it. Play it again with mods, and enjoy your night.
Genuinely one of the most unique and fun games i have played. I would recommend watching a youtube video on it and play with 3+ friends

This game knows how to make the most boring jobs fun.  Like the doctor. Oh yeah, just wait around and do squat, maybe repairing the ship from time to time, manning the guns every now and then until someone gets injured.  But when someone DOES get injured? When someone's about to die? It gets tense.  Trying to find out what medicine to use, performing CPR just to keep them alive.  And when the entire ship is unconscious?  It's YOUR job to save everyone, to be the hero.  And it's fun to hear a "thanks doc" from appreciative teammates.

Plus, I mean, sneaking some husk eggs when you're supposed to be injecting "morphine" into people is fun.

Oh, and good luck trying to "fix" a husk infection.  I injected two anti-husk drugs into someone, and I saw that his husk infection was going down one percent per few seconds.  Minutes later, I see he's at 95%.  Had to put him down...

Really great, but only when it works. The base game is ok, but it is fairly small. The mods are where this game shines, it has a massive modding community. If you like working as a team to make a ship run well despite the odds, and being able to customize it to match exactly what you want, this is the game for you.

However, large amounts of mods and playing with friends leads to very unstable gameplay, with several of my friends having repeated issues when trying to join despite following every single troubleshooting guide. It is especially frustrating when all seems fine for half of our campaign and then suddenly they can't join anymore. A lack of a client side crash log makes it nearly impossible to troubleshoot issues without long hours of testing.

Because of the stability issues with mods, and the lack of content in the main game, I cannot recommend this game for $35. Wait for a major sale, and expect it to make you frustrated enough to quit with some of its issues.

I want to say first that Barotrauma is a unique and good game, the type of game that AAA companies wouldn't make, the kind they would likely never even consider to make. That is ok, because this kind of game doesn't have to be a big thing, it just has to be its own thing, and be its own thing well. I wish that more games had the respect for their audience that Barotrauma does.

Before reading further: The game  loses something if you are planning to play it solo. For that reason I would generally recommend having at least one other person to play with, ideally two or three. It's a team focused game around crewing a submarine in dangerous waters, dragging it back from the brink of catastrophe and putting out fires (sometimes literally) to keep that rusted tin can of a submarine chugging along just long enough to reach the next safe harbor: it benefits from communication, coordination and that shared experience. Think of the moment in Das Boot when U-96 is stuck on the bottom of the gibraltar strait, the hull groaning under the pressure as the crew scrambles to desperately try and save the submarine. Bots just can't replicate that fully. it won't really be the same, it'll just be silent.

I think Barotrauma is the type of game that is kind of hard to write review for, given that what the individual takes away from it can vary wildly depending on preference. I think it would be good to first say that like many indie games it has its own specific niche it caters to: for some of us, that niche is something it does very well, for others, that niche might not be enough to get past some other aspects. This is not to imply that Barotrauma is a 'diamond in the rough', but it is the type of game where the appeal can largely be derived from whether the atmosphere and the experience are something you think is worth looking for. If a relatively complex-but-simple crew based submarine game about exploring deep into uncharted alien waters is something you find inherently appealing, then the experience that you will likely find is hard to replicate anywhere else. If that kind of thing is not something that excites you, or if submarines in general don't strike your interests, then some of the jankier aspects (the physics, character controls, some of the aspects of the gameplay) will begin to make your experience feel like a chore that dissuades you from going further. The reward you get out of playing the game is that unique atmospheric experience, so if the appeal is lost on you then you may find yourself losing motivation to continue. I think there is a lot depth here if you are willing to dive into it, but if that prospect doesn't seem appealing on it's own, then consider doing some more research into the game before you make any decisions. 

I said before that Barotrauma is a niche game that does its niche very well. I also said that the game has respect for its audience. While I won't go into general gameplay mechanics in this review (because it would take too much time), I do want to talk briefly about what made the game so appealing to me. The submarine editor I think is the most in-depth and interesting part of the game, given it allows you to take what is effectively the main character of your story (the submarine) and completely rebuild it from the ground up. Starting from scratch I can create a submarine however I want, handling the hulls, the layouts, the electrical systems and wiring, the automatic control systems and subsystems (through logic components, which allow you to do some really complex things given enough dedication), the ballast and fluid control systems, the decoration and aesthetics, the gun coverage, etc. Some of the things you can do with the tools available to you are really complicated and in-depth, like switcheable periscopes and gun systems, remote-control shuttlecraft and drones, 'overdrive' engine systems, 'silent running', emergency backup power systems, autonomously-controlled submarine guns, moonpools, automatic reactor and temperature control, REGEX-based computer control systems, periscope navigation, etc. As of right now, the workshop has 31,170 player-made submarines uploaded. I have uploaded 7 of my own (they are mid at best). The majority of my hours were in the editor. These kinds of things take hours of effort to make and demonstrate the kind of passion that people have for this game, as well as the depth that the game offers to tailor your experience to you. Some of them are low effort, some of them have problems that have not or cannot be fixed: the game is complicated by nature and not everything will work as you might want it to. But it goes to show just how dedicated people can get to this game, and just how much the game (and its developers) trusts you to do whatever you want with its systems. Want to create creatures of your own? The game has a creature editor for that too. A lot of the game is moddeable, and adding new items, equipment and armors can be as simple as XML and a text editor, depending on what you are making. Once you have an understanding of just how much effort and knowledge goes into the workings of both the systems themselves and the submarine you chose, you gain a sort of profound respect (or disrespect sometimes, ha) for the game that doesn't really seem to go away.

The concept is really cool, this could be a really good game but the game design ruins it.
-Missions are really tedious and repetitive. Almost every level plays the same down to a small amount of enemy diversity.
-Enemy balancing sucks ass. Just absolutely horrible how there are multiple enemies who can instantly breach your submarine's hull from a single hit, flooding and totally fucking you over, and they can usually tank enough bullets for you to not be able to stop them before that happens.
-For a horror game it's really really really hard to get scared when you're more pissed off at the horrendously annoying enemies. Deep sea horror personally really affects me and I expected this to have great scares but I instead just found myself frustrated
-Playing a solo campaign trying to command the braindead AI is a total nightmare. Every time you reset a mission you also have to set the AI commands again manually.

Barotrauma is a co-op adventure game that takes place on the moon of Europa. Players assume the roles of a submarine crew, exploring the seas and battling monsters with limited resources. The game's music, atmosphere, gameplay loop, and progression are all fantastic, creating an immersive and engaging experience.
The music in Barotrauma sets the tone perfectly, enhancing the atmosphere and creating a sense of tension and suspense. Combined with the game's visuals and sound effects, it truly immerses players in the underwater world and adds to the overall experience.
Speaking of atmosphere, Barotrauma excels in creating a dark and foreboding undersea environment. The graphics and sound design work together to create a sense of claustrophobia and unease, making every moment feel intense and suspenseful.
One of the game's strengths is its satisfying gameplay loop. Balancing exploration, resource management, and combat, players are constantly engaged and challenged. The mechanics are well-designed, allowing for strategic decision-making and teamwork in order to survive the dangers of the deep.
Progression in Barotrauma is well-paced, providing a sense of accomplishment as players upgrade their submarine and unlock new abilities. The game keeps players motivated and eager to explore further, offering a rewarding sense of progression.
On the other hand, enemy variety in Barotrauma is lacking. While the gameplay itself is solid, the limited range of enemies can become repetitive after a while. This detracts from the overall experience and could benefit from more diverse and challenging opponents.
Additionally, the game does suffer from some bugs and technical issues. While these can be frustrating at times, it is worth noting that the developers have been actively addressing and fixing these issues.
In conclusion, Barotrauma is a captivating co-op adventure game with a fantastic music score, immersive atmosphere, engaging gameplay loop, and satisfying progression system. However, the lack of enemy variety and the presence of bugs do detract from the overall experience. Nonetheless, for those who enjoy underwater survival games with a cooperative gameplay element, Barotrauma is still a worthwhile choice.

Dramatic end to a mission today: after the labyrinth of the cave, the reactor has run out of fuel. Air becomes scarce, travel impossible. The daring Pan: reach the nearby station's production facility with raw material for new fuel rods and return to the boat with processed rods. The 300 meters to the station are easier than expected. But then comes the nasty surprise: The station is empty and the upper levels are locked. Is this normal? A second diver brings the plasma cutter and gets to work - unfortunately on the outer wall and not on the door. The glowless ones are crushed in seconds by the water pressure. And yet: it could have worked, couldn't it?
The community actually pulled through and made some amazing mods, thus fixing the game for the devs. It's not top tier, but not too shabby either!

[i]TL;DR: Barotrauma is a unique submarine-in-an-alien-sea simulation game. The game boasts a great atmosphere and plays well with friends. There is a bit of a learning curve, however, and there is little in the way of quality of life features. Overall, I can recommend this game so long as you go in with your eyes open.[/i]

Barotrauma is as much a simulator as it is a game. And by that I mean that there's more depth to certain aspects of the game than you might expect from a cursory glance. But this also brings with it a severe lack of quality-of-life in terms of inventory management, crafting and item storage as well as UI design.

That said, Barotrauma is quite immersive. The gameplay loop is simple yet effective - complete missions, earn money and improve your gear and submarine to go deeper into Europa. While the game can be played just fine in singleplayer, I feel that most people would get more enjoyment out of multiplayer. Bots are very efficient at some aspects of the game and they work well enough for the most part. But for some players, the chaos that results from playing with only people will be a big draw.

The visuals are generally dark and moody, while the Europan wildlife looks familiar-yet-horrifying. I can't honestly say the game looks [i]pretty[/i], but the visuals achieve what they set out to do. They have a certain vibe to them and it works.

The sound effects are on point, the guns and creatures sound good. The background music is atmospheric and not very intrusive. Again - it fits the vibe that the game is going for.

Of particular interest to some will be the fact that you can design and use your own submarines. Over the course of the campaign my friend made several custom submarines and we had a great time using them. So while it may not be for everyone, I feel that the submarine editor is a great feature of the game.

I had a good time playing this with a friend until we completed the campaign. As far as I can tell there is little reason to keep playing after that. The ending itself is also a bit lackluster in terms of gameplay and story.

Either way, if you don't mind a bit of a learning curve and messing around with a fiddly UI and inventory management, this game can be unique and entertaining.

It's tough to strike the right balance in this genre. "Fun" versus "relentlessly tedious" is subjective and when no two people have the exact same line between the two it's hard to please everyone. Unfortunately this also makes it hard to buy games within the genre with confidence that you're going to enjoy them. I have no doubt that for the right type of player - the one that doesn't mind a hefty dose of the tedious in exchange for the opportunity to truly go 100 miles deep in certain mechanics - this will be a winner. For me, though, the learning curve was too high, and I didn't find the progression system or gameplay loop at all rewarding even when things did start to click. Just not for me.

A retelling of my most Legendary Barotrauma story: I remember playing a round where our server of 17 players was shoved into a sub that was built for 6, knowing what usually happens when these events occur, I stole every single drug and immediately abandoned the crew. Most of the crew were eaten by mud raptors, but a good chunk of them managed to survive the onslaught. So, after hearing them screaming about requiring medical attention, I listened to my conscience and returned to treat the survivors. While doing so, I saw the mangled body of a security guard who, despite being eaten by a mud raptor, was only an inch away from death. After figuring he was a lost cause, I decided to shove an injection of Deusizine (A drug I never used before) up his ass for funsies, where said guard proceeded to jump up and down while screaming at the top of his lungs. Shocked by this fortunate turn of events, the remaining crew made our way to the beacon station, repaired it, and then failed the round, because everyone had clicked End Round during the mud raptor attack. 

10/10 would do it again.

A niche game which has obvious flaws yet executed its core game mechanics very well. For those seeking info before purchasing: this game has a decent learning curve and the pace is slow at the beginning. If any of submarine/diving or deep see survival  or 2D visual layout is a game breaker to you, don't buy. Otherwise once you've made it past the torturous learning period, you'll find this game quite fun instead.

Pros: Game-play is second to none and as varied as can be, you can be anything from submarine defence and heavy weapons expert to humble electrician who bends atoms to your will.

The atmosphere ranges from jovial drinking with the crew to straining your hearing whilst searching for the Latcher that sunk you. 

The progression system is quite well done, stressing your submarine to it's absolute limits before allowing you to upgrade.

Customisation and creation of creatures or submarines is extensive in the editor or with rewiring.

Surrounding lore and backstory of the factions and of Europa itself is fascinating.

In single-player this game fits the niche between trucking simulator and side scrolling action-horror.
In multiplayer it ranges from murder mystery to laughable insanity.

Cons: The game fails to explain some of it's more complex systems adequately enough, rewiring your submarine is a notorious example of this.

Sometimes you fall through stairs you thought you had fully climbed or miss a ladder you thought you had grabbed.

Being 2D comes with the challenge that NPCs and corpses take up the hobby of blocking your bullets, usually at the most crucial of moments.

The lore, whilst quite good, requires quite the amount of searching outside of the game itself. Past what I would consider normal.

Playing in single-player hinges you to AI which sometimes overdose you on morphine or shoot you in the back. Whereas in multiplayer your game will entirely depend on your crew, either you work together efficiently or you get a troll who blows up the reactor. (not a designated traitor, just a prick)

After putting some time into a campaign, the missions can become rather repetitive.

Conclusion: This game has it's problems and is incredibly niche, but if you find it enjoyable it's a real gem.

Barotrauma is one of those gems you can't compare with anything else. It is the only game I own that comes close to what I loved about FTL back in the day. Completely enjoyable solo if you commit to learning the limitations of the A.I. (and also how to (ab)use it later on), it is very doable and often easier than with a multiplayer crew. The strength of this game lies in its depth and complexity, embracing the depths of Jupiters Moon uncovering its secret.

The only downside to this game is that the game is horribly optimized, runs on one CPU core and tends to stutter itself into oblivion mostly in the 3rd and 4th biome, making a modded "lag fix" almost mandatory. Equally, the depth of the campaign itself is enjoyable for a full playthrough, but becomes stale for the second. Mods expand this game enourmously, without touching the core gameplay (almost) at all. Dynamic Europa is one of my favorites, it flips the macro game upside down and improves it on every front. Adding more wrecks, beacons and stations make the game feel like you see more variations, styles and the vanilla game provides.

The only issue I've had was finding a few friends to play the game with. Barotrauma isn't for everyone, but is a LOT of fun if you give it a try and stick to it.

Such an interesting and unique game, with so many different mechanics and tools the possibilities are endless! 

I had a small crew and a weak submarine in my first run. We had power failures left and right, and many creatures could easily board our ship. But as the game progressed, slowly I was able to afford more and more upgrades, until I could buy a bigger and even better ship. This cycle continues on and on but each mission is different than the last, and definitely more dangerous than the last. I made different alliances with certain factions and unlocked new research and technologies. Once I finally bought the best ship I was no longer scared of the occasional crawler, spineling, mudraptor or hammerhead. But such feelings of comfort did not last long, as the game then presented me with new stronger, faster, bigger, and scarier creatures that made their predecessors seem like a joke. They tore my ship apart, along with the people inside it. 

The learning curve in Barotrauma is steep and difficult, it is not an easy game to pick up and play, and the tutorial does not efficiently teach you the various aspects of the game. Especially how to play roles such as the Medical Officer, Engineer, and Mechanic. However, even though this may seem like a downside, I believe not knowing what to expect in a horror game like this actually helps add to the game's theme of isolation and exploration. In some twisted way, things like your Submarine being boarded by aliens and all the power failing is actually really fun, I mean....isn't the whole point of horror games/movies is to have stuff going wrong? Just imagine this: You're an Security Officer for the ship, your job is to handle the weapons and keep lifeforms out of the ship, but the whole mission has gone to shit. The nuclear reactor is failing, the lights have gone out, the navigation systems are dead, and you are armed with your trusty revolver, and a flashlight. As you slowly creep around the decrepit hallways of the submarine, you hear a scratching noise coming from the medical room, you quickly climb up the ladder and peak through the window, you can tell it's a person but you can't exactly make out who it is. You open the door, assuming they were stuck in there, but as this 'crewmember' turns around, you see their helmet is cracked, long tentacles poking out of it, their suit is torn and they smell of decaying flesh. That 'thing' is certainly anything but human....

Overall, Barotrauma is a great game made 10x better when playing with friends. The idea of your submarine being stranded several kilometres underwater is terrifying, and it makes you have to think on your feet when there are leaks in the ship, or terminal cells, mutating and corrupting your ship from the inside out. You will die many times in this game, but each time you will gain some new knowledge on how to adapt and beat this problem next time it comes around. And there are so many cool items to mess around with. I got the game while it was on sale, $20 down from $50. I would recommend waiting for the game to go on sale because 50 does seem a little high to me, but if you have money to throw away then getting the game for 50 is not a bad idea.

Best submarine stress simulator EVER


The story I have is of a crew where i was the captain of a sub, and we had one simple mission:
fix a beacon station and get to the outpost. Simple.

We started, mined some ore, fought some eldritch horrors, the usual. Until we got to the station.

In the station, while we were repairing it (and where i died once) our engineer informed us that we only had a single fuel rod left, so we needed to hurry.
We finished fixing it with our last fuel rod (great mistake) and we tried to dock on the outpost, but a group of monsters attacked us and thanks to them (and my severe case of skill issue) we got pulled down and sank FAST
thankfully, the batteries on our ship were charged, so we managed to repair our ship, and with the idea of a mechanic, we drained the ship of all water, and let the buoyancy of the ship push it up

...this didn't go as planned, because we hit a rock and we were stuck, so we managed to come up with a desperate final plan, we were NOT giving up.

I got out of the sub with an underwater scooter, and went to the beacon station that we fixed to get the fuel rod we left there, i managed to get it, and even used a fire extinguisher that was in the station to propel myself once the scooter ran out of battery!

And in the end, we failed.

Opening the airlock to exit the sub made it sink, and with no power to get the water out, the sub with everyone inside sank until a group of monsters spotted them, destroying the ship more and making them sink to 5000m, making it to crush depth, and all dying

And while ALL OF THAT was happening, i was trying to return to the ship, fuel rod in hand.
Eventually i began to run out of oxygen, and as i saw name tags disappear off the HUD, I accepted my demise.

I got out of my suit, and smoked my captain's pipe one last time as i died.


Remember kids: always bring extra fuel rods, or you will die horribly.

The game has come a long way since the start of it's early access on steam, there are tons of incredible mods, and the developers are still adding major content updates like the rework to traitors mode. There are occasional bugs and annoyances (Like: Sometimes people recruited from random events will not have a proper ID card, so their name will change every round), but the experience is overall very solid. The editing tools given are very well made as well, so it's very easy to create your own ships / mods.

The price tag is a tad bit high, but the game goes on massive sales occasionally, alongside free weekends (usually around major updates). Definitely try the game during one of these events if you are thinking about buying.

UPDATE: THEY FIXED THE PERFORMANCE ISSUE!!!

Newly introduced performance issues since the Rising Tide update has made the game quite literally unplayable for me and hundreds of other players. This issue doesn't seem to be high priority for the devs as they've closed a megathread for newly introduced performance issues after referring people to the thread and closing other threads as "duplicates" but the main thread was closed as well.

I love this game, it's one of my favorite games, but despite being well above the reccomended specs and previously being able to play the game at 144FPS, I'm still completely unable to play because of these issues. I want to change the review and I absolutely will once (IF) these issues are fixed. I'm getting a sinking feeling the devs aren't going to fix them. I hope they prove me wrong, I love this game so much.

Outdated Update: Honestly I've lost all interest. The updates have been terrible, making known problems worse and just overall being downgrades to the game. I'd happily play older versions of the game but the live version has lost it's vision. It feels like the devs don't know what they want the game to be anymore. They'll add some interesting new feature in one update, then the very next one completely change it, usually making it worse in the process and not providing any ways to revert the changes in custom settings. You must play the game the devs want you to play unless you want to spend hours setting up mods. They don't understand that this game needs nearly everything to be custom tailored per player/per campaign.

This is a good game. The concept is interesting and fresh. It takes time to learn the basics (I highly recommend completing the tutorial and trying single player first), but once you get the basics down, the game is fun to play.

But... I wouldn't recommend this game if you don't have friends to play this game together. You can play with random people, but it's quite difficult to find a good server.

Most hosts don't care if you are a beginner or not, and won't bother to teach you. Not to mention the type of host who likes to just kick people for no apparent reason, or when you make a mistake because you're still a beginner. This game can be played alone, but of course it's not as exciting as if you play together.

So, before buying this game, try asking some of your friends first, maybe someone wants to play this game with you.

This game is difficult to deal with, and i want to see changes before im willing to give this a positive review. The AI seriously, SERIOUSLY needs to be revamped. You need to be able to give orders that think ahead, like telling crews to put on diving suits or grab extra oxygen. Bots shouldnt leave their suits lying around or waste expensive meds on minor injuries. Sending them out on excursions with respective mining/repair/salvage/guard roles would also be a fantastic addition. Maybe you could even implement a simple command-script building to make repeatable chains of orders at once. And we need drydocks- Places where we can park our sub so we dont have to worry about water when we cut it open to make minor changes to the wiring. Either that, or some kind of 'access panel' that acts as a wall, but have a small door to access hidden components.
Undertow, I love your game. It is so so close to being perfect- And thats what make these drawbacks all the more frustrating.
So unless you already have a handful of friends you already plan to play this with, with no accompanying NPC AI help, and are ok with sticking to the same 2-4 subs the whole game, sorry- But i dont think this game is quite yet finished.

June 13th, 2022: Normally I do not play 2D games as often anymore, but this is heck of an exception. It took me by surprise just how much content is actually in the game & then there is additional Steam workshop support. If anything could be a 2D Garry's Mod, this could be it.

I hope the game continues to receive support & content.

Edit January 10th, 2024: It's annoying that you still can not free yourself from handcuffs. Additionally, not sure why they changed the sprites (ragdolls), they behave & appear less appealing than before.

Edit January 11th, 2024: Apparently you cannot rename crew bots; it does not seem to be functioning properly unless you are buying or discarding an NPC crew-mate at the same time of renaming another. There appears to be no persistent objects other than what is on your submarines & your crew, which is annoying when you want to feel like your actions & choices have an impact on outposts/stations & the environments.

Edit January 13th, 2024: After having played the game as a returning player, honestly, the game feels like a downgrade with the changes they have made compared to older versions. After the amount of time this game has had in development, there just is not even enough vanilla/base content to consider the price of this game as worth it at all. Most of the content comes from the community, both from playing with other players & from their efforts on the workshop. Changed my review from positive to negative to reflect the changes the game received; a reluctant change of my own on what could still become a great game.

Really neat game, with in depth mechanics and world.

But With the combination of mechanics that lean toward group play and a steep learning curve, the community develops this barricaded feeling that ostracizes new players and makes the game and community a bit unwelcoming, a problem it shares with games like foxhole.

and I although i admittedly havnt gotten far into the solo campaign, I dont think it is really one of those things that will speak to most people or keep them hooked, despite its in depth mechanics, trying to breach the surface is like staring at a lake from a cliff, you know it would be really cool but making that jump is a nigh impossible task to do alone.

for these reasons I cannot recommend this game to most people, but think it would probably be worth trying to see if it scratches an itch for you.

Looking at a bland Sonor-Screen with Game&Watch-style graphics my heart is pumping pure adrenalin through my veins. Why? Because i know what it means for me and my crew if these little moving points get any closer to my sub and the moments were it happend and those horrors from the deep breached our hull flooded me away from the controlls and ate my brother were as intense as gaming moments can possibly become. The quirky visuals only add to the fun, but never take from the intensity. 

Truly one of the best multiplayer coop-games I played so far. Every role is important and different, it's relativly easy to get into but incredible complex and deep if you want it to. In the end I spend hours and hours rewiring and optimizing my subs every door, weapon and function just to get the edge on those uncanny creatures straight from "The Thing" that want to breach our hull and shashlik my friends and family. And if you have  enough of your regular run of the mill sub experience just download some mods and roleplay the matrix or atlantis. Everything is possible. 

A true pearl from a lovely dev-team with a great community who match each other in dedication and heart.

Since nobody is going to read my review, I'll just say this:

I Own a musket for home defence, since that's what the founding fathers intended. Four ruffians break into my house. "What the devil?" As I grab my powdered wig and Kentucky rifle. Blow a golf ball sized hole through the first man, he's dead on the spot. Draw my pistol on the second man, miss him entirely because it's smooth-bore and nails the neighbours dog. I have to resort to the cannon mounted at the top of the stairs loaded with grape shot, "Tally ho lads" the grape shot shreds two men in the blast, the sound and extra shrapnel set off car alarms. Fix bayonet and charge the last terrified rapscallion. He Bleeds out waiting on the police to arrive since triangular bayonet wounds are impossible to stitch up. Just as the founding fathers intended.
Playing with friends is a fantastic blast be sure you get four or more to hop on the crew, though.

Just okay. Not nearly as fun as it should be when shit hits the fan, and not nearly enough ways things can go wrong. One of those games where as you get better, the game gets worse, as you know exactly how to deal with everything. I feel like people are obsessed with games being "fair" and it keeps developers away from making games more unpredictable and treacherous. Rather than interesting things happening, people just want to win.
SQUID GAME!!!

Barotrauma is a strange game. It has elated highs and catastrophic failures, parasites and clowns, and just the right balance of seriousness and silly. I'd love to describe it in further detail but words would be a disservice, I can't really compare it any way except saying it's a more complex "We Need to Go Deeper", which is still a disservice to what this game is. 

200 hours ago I thought this game was stupid, and I now realize that this game is stupid and wonderful. It's a steep learning curve, but if you can dedicate the time to google a few things on the wiki you'll find this game is well worth the money. I rarely play games until the end, and rarer still do I review a game. But this one deserved it, and it deserves a try from you. Give it a shot, and thanks devs. It's been a while since a game made me feel this way.

I'll be honest here and say this game definitively isn't worth full price, the price increase for the 1.0 release was abusive, this game is fun and all, but it's definitively very light on content to be considered a 50$CAD purchase.

But it does go deep in sale, so feel free to get it at the reduced price! This game is a ton of fun to play with friends, we had a blast playing it. My main complaint about this game is the lack of diversity to ship tasks. Yes you'll have different ships during your journey with different layouts, but it's more of the same. Piloting never changes, it's the exact same from hour 0 to the end of the game, repairing is always the same minigame, dealing with the engine is always the same process.

Just feels like there should be a little variety between all the ships in the tasks that need to be done.

This game feels like it's just a little short of content to be an infinitely replayable experience. It's like Slay The Spire with only 2 playable classes, or the finals but each character only has one weapon.. there's a little something missing.

Spiritual successor to Space Station 13. A game where most of the tension comes not from what's on the screen, but from the knowledge that there is no difficulty scaling at all, and like real life, if you're inadequate to the semi-random difficulty challenge coming your way, you just die with no exceptions.

After 630 hours of gameplay, most being goofy, and a tad serious, here's what I've got to say :

-Game modes

As of today, start of 2024, there's only two real modes, solo, kinda boring, flat, submarine pilot simulator 2024, and multiplayer, multiplayer being the most GOOFIEST SHIT I ever saw in my entire life.

Solo is good, good while listening to music, ai is half braindead, can still shoot guns with decent accuracy, (use pulse not chaingun), and well you travel from there to there, make your money etc, then upgrade, lacks introduction to others classes, and you're stuck being the captain, the ai being unable to dock by itself, or even fine a path if there's an ice spire in a 509 meters radius.

Multiplayer, is like putting 6 monkeys in a nuclear reactor, and give em a shit ton of bananas, you gonna die, you gonna explode and be reduced to atoms, but it's gonna be the best fucking moment of your life, either while clowning around, or fighting mudraptors with a diving knife, while under all drugs known to man, it's never boring and definitely worth trying it.

-Performances
Do not, and trust me, DO NOT play this game with an I3, without a graphics card, it litteraly burns (real), otherwise the game lacks optimization, as soon as I hit the 2k items it starts to be worse, and well trust me on that, fuck the crystals, these being in one of the lasts zones just make it worse, as when you're here you're in a tier 3, and it makes it even larger, and with added mods for ammo, items, or simply guns / ships, you're gone, can't be finished.

-Community
50/50 deal, either a chad who carries you because he got five times your hours, or a guy that kicks you either because you have a name he doesn't like,  or because he doesn't know how to put a game on private, having payday 2 feelings on that, either way, finding people easy, good one less, and the discord is just completely overrun, impossible to find another if you're a beginner.

-Conclusion 
Game is good, worth to buy, even more with sales, just way better with mates, even inexperienced, (or unemployed), assistant is the meta, and praise the honkmother.

Observe the amount of time I spent in this game, this game is very easy to run even with low end Hardware which I had at the time even with the technical limitations it was still very entertaining to me. The single player of this game can be at times difficult, even in easy or normal settings, and the multiplayer can make you go on for hours on end that is not including mods which there are some very well developed mods. I will name a few here, Real sonar, Improved husks, Neurotrauma, Immersive diving gear, Enhanced armaments and the list can go on. I highly recommend you pick this game up and maybe you might come across someone that you will call your best friend. I will continue to play this game with or without friends whether it be making submarines or occasionally playing on random campaigns it is fun all the same.

I highly recommend buying this game if you have friends to play it with, or are willing to play in a public lobby. however if you are playing it for single player the single player is just kinda meh. This game is one of those games where the emergent game play is so dam good you wont be able to put it down.  Here is a few stories from my stupid amount of time in this game.


I was in a public server once where one guy insisted on fighting everything we came across with a crowbar. It was a funny bit until we got attacked by a abyssal creature which if you don't know what that is just picture a creature the size of the submarine. Now we were loosing this fight badly, we were about 200M from crush depth and one more hit from the abyssal creature probably would have sent us past crush depth. AND YOU KNOW WHAT THIS FUCKER SAYS, "Let me at him I can take him." and he then proceeds to leave the ship via the airlock and activate a sonar beacon to lure the abyssal creature to him. He managed to distract it long enough that we were able to run away. (obviously he did not live) 

Another time I was in a server with some friends and we were running a mod called hazardous reactors for the first time (which changes the way that reactors work). Now my friend who usually plays engineer was overconfident and refused to read the manual the mod provided in game. Then the reactor started leaking radiation and right before repairing the reactor he confidently says "See I don't need a manu--". I then saw him fly halfway across the ship past me as I saw the reactor ark flash him.

Just finished the [b]Submarine Editor[/b]'s tutorial.
Now I feel like I can finally play the game [spoiler][strike][b][i]as it was intended[/i][/b][/strike][/spoiler].

You and a few of your buddies head out on your sub. The captain is barely conscious with how drunk and high he is. You're just trying to keep the ship's lights on till you can dock. Then you hear over the comms that there's incoming enemies. Security runs starts blasting the ship's weapons at them. Then you hear the scratching as they tear their way through the air locks and hull. They look like giant raptors and rush at you. You grab your trusty crowbar, slap your diving mask on, and rush at the monster. Your medic brings you back from the dead using enough mummies and morphine to mummify an elephant. You get up and repeat until you get to the next station. Rinse and repeat. 
All of this is just the first biome. You're lucky if the creatures an get into the sub. 
Welcome to Europa son. Everything is trying to kill you.

This game is a perfect example of what can happen when dev companies put gameplay first. It's an absolutely beautifully fleshed out game down to it's smallest mechanics, and it's FUN!

One thing for new players though..I HIGHLY recommend going in to the workshop and subscribing to a a couple different fan made submarines, specifically the T1 R-26 "Tara" and the T2 "Rastoc". The default vanilla subs were made years ago and it really shows. The two ships I've highlighted are not OP or make the game easier in any way, they just add a level of immersion that really adds to the experience. Also, the game generously lets you apply most mods mid playthrough, so you can download ships from the workshop as you go.
fucking mud raptor

This is a well built 2D game. You drive a sub deeper and deeper. The deeper you go the more mayhem happens. The creatures are relentless and will stop at nothing to eat every last person. Playing solo can be a nightmare, but so can playing with random players. There are no rules. Everything is destructible. Sometimes the random players can be more dangerous than the creatures in the sea. However, you can hire bots and program them with specific commands that completely replace players altogether. A solo/Bot run is completely viable if you are tired of trusting random players. Playing with friends is highly recommended because this game really shines from teamwork and communication. Modding is built into the game. You can completely create your submarine from scratch and bring it into a new campaign. You can also bring it into an existing campaign through a 3rd party save editor. This game is good to replay as well. You can go for New Game + which increases difficulty automatically each play through or you can start completely fresh with a completely new generated campaign map. There are multiple routes to take making each choice a new experience. Also the Toy Hammer is the best weapon in the game. I bonked a latcher to death with it. You'll find out what a latcher is when you play. It likes to give out free hugs and take you to the sirens lair at the bottom of the ocean. 10/10 I partied hard with the latcher and the sirens. Don't forget to bring your funbringer 1000 with you. Praise the Honkmother. Oh and if you like dark and twisted being a husk is not so bad. You turn into Dracula and can turn everyone else into husks. Has a type of play through for everyone. Just don't try to manually "ascend" to soon. You might not get your sanity back and your crew will bury you at the bottom of the ocean with the latcher and the sirens. Also the sirens only exist if you are "crazy" enough. Welcome to the Ocean Gate simulator. Too soon?

Overall: I highly recommended Barotrauma if you like coop games, submarines, cascading failure, horrible monsters, and/or the cold depths of the ocean.

It makes me troubleshoot, eats me, puts monsters in the ballast, gives me a periscope and flares. The lovely, lovely flares. They light the dark in red circles, and there is so much dark. There are so many strangers in my metal ice-travel tube. They have their own wants and needs. They do not have the flares. I have all the flares.

Barotrauma strikes a balance between simplified and simulated that births predictable unpredictability, and is brilliant with a barnacle-encrusted crew of friends-turned-undersea-under-ice-psychopaths. Less recommended if you don't have friends to play with, though the campaign is fleshing out nicely, and the game has been continuing to get meaty updates. 

I picked up Barotrauma because I loved the idea of being stuck on a submarine while compartments filled with water, opening doors and being crushed under the surge, sealing compartments to contain the leak. It does this very well.

The submarines feel creepy, cold, and gross, an atmosphere lightened by the game's subtle-but-persistent sense of humor and humanity. You can play an accordion. Clowns drift around outposts and infest the occasional multiplayer lobby, carrying with them a strange and chaotic folk religion.

Barotrauma is hardcore in that a single mistake can get you crushed, burned, lacerated, or parasitically transformed, but at the heart of the game is a submarine sandbox built around having fun in a challenging, occasionally terrifying environment. It gives you a whole lot of tools (from bike horns to handcuffs to C-4), and a whole lot of permission to use them. You can unwire critical systems, turn some gun emplacements against the submarine itself, smear the walls with spray paint. The level of freedom it provides is the beating wet heart of the game. (It's also the thing that necessitates multiplayer to some degree.)

It's not a game for everyone. (But boy is it a game for me.) 

It's not a deep simulator. It's not a purpose-built single-player game. (Updates have improved the solo experience immensely over the last few years, and it's something I've had a lot of fun with personally, but that's still not where Barotrauma shines.) It's easier to understand than I was expecting going in, but still has a steep learning curve at the beginning. The controls are simple, but survival and success depend on knowing how various submarine systems (power, batteries, ballast, engine, etc.) interact, how to prioritize tasks, and so on. There's a lot to learn.

Slow at times. Successful missions on easier difficulties mean consist solely of 10+ minutes watching pitch-black cave water pass around the hull of your submarine, squinting at radar pings and clicking on junction boxes to fix them. And that's it.

Disaster is sudden. A single enemy can bring your submarine to the sea floor within seconds, in increasingly desperate need of repairs. Learning your sub's systems (each is wired differently, and the wiring matters) is necessary to repair it effectively. The margin between a working submarine and a deep sea paperweight is narrow, sometimes frustratingly so, and the gameplay can easily fall into loops of click-thing-until-it's-fixed when your boat takes damage.

This is all stuff I either enjoy or don't mind too much, but everyone's wants and tolerances are different, so I think it's important to mention the big sticking points. Barotrauma is doing something weird and cool and different, and delivers an wandering, immersive experience and a fuckload of atmosphere.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my Son, who is 16 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 160 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his girlfriend or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me in the campaign. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

Barotrauma – это захватывающий заморский мир полный невероятных приключений и неизведанных глубин океана. Если вы ищете увлекательную и уникальную игру, то Barotrauma – именно то, что вам нужно.

Глядя на подводные пейзажи, вы ощутите волшебство и красоту подводного мира, который полон загадок и тайн. Вас ждут удивительные морские создания, подводные пещеры и рифы, которые просто впечатляют своей масштабностью и изумительной графикой. Красочные эффекты и великолепная детализация окружения позволяют вам полностью погрузиться в атмосферу этого мира.

Barotrauma предлагает потрясающий мультиплеерный опыт, где вы можете объединиться с друзьями и отправиться на захватывающие приключения вместе. Ваша команда будет состоять из разных специалистов, каждый из которых является неотъемлемой частью успешной операции. Вы сможете действовать совместно, для того чтобы преодолеть препятствия и справиться с любыми непредвиденными ситуациями, которые встретятся на вашем пути.

Игра также предлагает глубокий и затягивающий геймплей, с элементами выживания и стратегии. Вам придется балансировать ресурсы, следить за кислородом и энергией на корабле, устранять утечки, а также справляться с бесчисленными опасностями океана. Вы будете испытывать на себе адреналин и волнение, когда ваша команда будет бороться с монстрами и другими угрозами, которые поджидают вас на каждом шагу.

В целом, Barotrauma – это прекрасное сочетание красивой графики, захватывающего геймплея и возможности взаимодействия с друзьями. Это игра, которая заставляет вас продолжать исследовать, преодолевать преграды и находить новые приключения. Если вы хотите окунуться в мир фантастических подводных приключений, то несомненно попробуйте Barotrauma – вы не пожалеете!

Singleplayer this game is great. Only issue I can find with it is that it's a bit on the punishing side. If you don't do things well, you might get screwed over. It's often better to play very passive than very aggressive (as the Captain's role, arguably the one you'll play most in Singleplayer.)
Once you know the mechanics and AI though, it gets much easier. You can predict creatures much better, and it's overall so much easier to deal with everything.
There is also a multiplayer side, and for the MOST part it is well done, but there are a couple major issues.
First off, you don't get to control AI in multiplayer. If you want some perks like crafting the best tools, but you don't have an Engineer PLAYER (not NPC) you're out of luck, and have to settle for the next best thing. This goes for everything.
The other gamemodes are great though. Campaigns are long tho.
Overall a good game. Just hard, and harder without friends.

Welcome to Barotrauma, This fine specimen, is a game.

Have you ever wanted to be a sea dweller in the depths of Europa?

To have fun with your friends?
To work overtime in a shitbox you and your crew call a submarine?
To have a captain drunk on ethanol not tell you of a pod of hammerheads just outside the ship?
To be underpaid in any given situation even when the bank is full of money?
To question the morality of whatever the hell the doktor is currently doing to the mechanic?

If you answered yes to any above, Welcome abored to a (very short) lifetime of underwater shenanigans.

When you first come around you may consider going in single player, but I'd advise against it because you wouldn't have the full proper experience of a clown rigging a door with four tons of C4 and the following chaos where half the crew is infected with an alien parasite while the suspicious medic is currently running for his life from security, and at the same time the captain is being dragged into the ballast by the assistant for... unknown purposes. All the while the submarine hasn't moved an inch from the dock.

As you can see from this fun tale, multiplayer is significantly better than singleplayer. singleplayer is meh.

The game play loop is pretty great and its the players that make it better, it goes as follows.


- don't die
- prepare to go a mission, transporting goods, peoples, chemicals or hunting abyssal horrors, you name it.
- don't question what the clown is doing as the crew wont notice you missing.
- get shot at in the crossfire from the outpost security shooting at your medic for stealing all the meth
- nearly die
- go on mission
- ask about your 1% salary, the captain laughs and continues piloting the sub.
- captain says "WHAT THE F#*% IS THAT THING!?"
- get slammed into the roof
- submarine fucking dies
- everyone dies
- local mudraptors get lunch
Rinse and repeat until you get through to the next outpost, whoever made this game is a genius.

If you want to make a submarine that others can crash and burn in the vast sea, you can easily do so using the Editor, where magic and creativity prospers.
Ranging from everything and anything, you can make some great ships, or... some with questionable designs.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6VR7uNgwOeM

I'd highly suggest you watch some videos, download some ships and take em apart to see what works and figure out how to make a lump of scrap into a work of art, watch Initialdesu, he knows what he doin.

Anyways game is 10/10
Multiplayer is 10/-10
Singleplayer is 7 divided by Pi
Editor 11/10
Alive crew mates 3.5/8

Oh yeah if you plan on hosting a server, bring friends :) and don't tolerate the arseholes who will try to ruin your campaign, because they will grief and sap the fun out of it. advise from Mr. Troll.

Update:
To amend this, the problem I have with the update is the storage changes. If it only applied to new saves, I'd maybe consider trying out it. However, I'm currently balls deep in a campaign that I'm playing with two friends, using a series of subs I've made, with the previous storage system in mind, and the Treacherous Tides update colossally messed that up. 
Found a few mods to revert it, but the point still stands. Doing sudden major changes to how important mechanics work creates huge problems when you're hours into something.  Ironically, with the combination of those mods and the update, we end up having even more storage space than before...

As for the big thing in this update, the traitor system stuff, that part might be fine for those that enjoy that. Dunno. I don't play, and have no interest in playing the traitor mode.

Not all games give players the ability to be eaten by massive ocean worms, while wasted on raptor bane rum, injected with every drug sold in the market, produce disfigured people with genes of fish, or dominate the seas with a crew that has found symbiosis with diseases that turn people into zombies, and a sub with more firepower than the Peruvian military, growing tobacco and manufacturing of certain blue hyperactivity drugs inspired by a drama television series, all of this with friends make for interesting rounds, with multiplayer you could sabotage strangers by rigging up the submarine to explode upon entry, or just swap all oxygen masks with welding fumes.

Let me say this....I've had the most unforgettable gaming experiences playing this. 

I started playing as all the roles except Captain. I found some solid funny groups that worked together and had a captain that would talk and give orders. When the crew is working as a team it can create positive moments, you really do feel like you're in an underwater sub on another planet. But it's pretty hard to find that good mix of people that talk and really get into their roles.

So I started to create/host games because I was tired of being matched with people without mics. Then I started to play Captain and that's where the real fun began. It's stressful at times but its nice to vet people without mics and also playing as Jean Luc Picard in a sub is awesome. Create dive teams, go on inspection checks, tell someone to grow tobacco plants so I can smoke more and give individual tasks to keep them engaged and busy. This is the only game that really captures the captain & crew feeling. You almost NEED a talkative captain to have a decent experience because without that voice, the crew becomes disorganized and runs out of things to do faster imo.

It's scary outside the sub. Combat is janky and funny. Enemies are wide in variety and terrifying. Husk infections can infiltrate your crew like a plague and sometimes forces you to make some crazy decisions like locking a crewmate in a room or maybe depressurizing a room to kill a traitor. There's lots of custom subs on the workshop that can really cater to any kind of sub layout you want. I love having locked doors on my captains quarters because i like having some peace and quiet sometimes. Also I like giving the security or medic a master key just incase I lock it and somehow pass out in there.

Barotrauma is, for my money, the best horror game on the market. I have never encountered a game that is so fundamentally nerve-wracking to play.

You are a potentially suicidal lunatic whose job is to pilot badly-designed submarines in the freezing subsurface oceans of Europa. The subsurface oceans of Europa are full of two things: vast mineral resources, and monsters made entirely of teeth. You usually have to go into caves full of the latter to find any of the former.

The only way you can see the monsters is with your fragile human eyes or with sonar, which only tells you where they were a few seconds ago, not where they are now - a question to which the answer is always "closer and now they're even more angry." 

If you want a premium horror experience with very deep gameplay, I cannot recommend this game enough.

Barotrauma is an eldritch gift from the depths, and much like H.P. Lovecraft's fear of the deep, YOU TOO can enjoy the same phobia. Barotrauma is deceptively simple in its premise, and even its 2D art style. Easily one of my most favorite games on Steam, and an absolute blast with friends, this game is an absolute jewel and should be played. It isn't perfect, mind you, but the devs are always engaging with the community and working on sizable patches to solve such complaints and in the meantime the community makes their own solution thanks to the Workshop. 
The game play loop isn't complicated, which might make you think that the game isn't. Boy would you be wrong. 

Man a submarine, do simple tasks, make profit, trade profit for men & materials at the next outpost... repeat. 

However, things go south very very fast. In a sense, this game is the spiritual successor of Space Station 13 (complete with Traitor mechanics) because things do go south, incredibly fast, and the enjoyment is in trying to duct tape a bad situation into something serviceable. The hectic, chaos filled hell you put yourself in here is the fun of the game, and you will keep coming back to it time & time again like some domestic assault victim. I'll see you in Europa.

Game is a fun concept, and the gameplay is fun. It could be much more fun if it did not have Skill Loss on Death and The Reapers Tax, a special debuff that punishes you for choosing to respawn and help your friends and other players instead of staying dead until they die or reach the station after finishing the mission. That is two things that punish a players hard-won skill progression on death, which can happen rapidly and with minimal warning, and even happen from other players trying to save your life. As hilarious as such things would be if it was harmless, the fact that it can cause a massive reduction in your stats and a slow degradation of your character to worse than fresh-spawned basically ruins the gameplay if you plan to spend more than a few hours on it or want to enjoy the more indepth parts without a serious and serially succesfull crew to boost you. 

It is really rough to be playing and realize you have wasted hours working on your character, only for them to be worse than if you had never touched them. The Devs need to curve their artificial difficulty boner before I will recommend this game.

It has its serious hard-core player-base, do not be surprised when you find that you are not secretly one of them that missed the message about this game. It is a game for a niche group of people, although very fun, the excessive death punishment makes it nearly intolerable to a newer player trying to explore it. But that is just my personal feelings on the situation. From what I have heard the game devs believed it was too fast to gain skills so they set things up to prevent that, I don't know what too-fast means, but if it takes me 10hrs to see the first few levels of progress beyond token skill boosts in a game like this, I wouldnt call it too fast, I would call it cripplingly slow.  Perhaps there are extremely good builds out there that help you progress quickly, but they aren't ones that I stumbled upon. 

Summary: Game is fun, gameplay is fun, Death is doubley punished, extremely common, and makes advancement near impossible in game without a serious amount of player experience. 4/10 Fun Until You Try To Play Seriously and Explore. Pick up if you are a masochist that likes to watch your stat-grind get reversed by excess waterpressure.

I spent several dozen hours and was effectively discouraged from going further. Even on the easiest level, after some time, completing a few missions and reaching the next base is a great success. Most often you have to start from the last base many times. The game is deliberately set up in such a way that a person practically falls over his own feet and dies unexpectedly. And it's hard to find any rule here, except that the rule is that it has to be tedious, and that's actually one of the main attractions of this game. Even when you want to make a key move at the moment of attack, the game is set up in such a way that something turns off or you fall. It's supposed to add atmosphere. However, this is completely unrealistic. Where, in what world, in what environment, in what work is a person exposed every second to so many dangers and to such bad luck? With almost worthless security measures. It's as if a person goes to work every day and has to repair his car several times on the way, and in the end he will die because in a moment a bird will fly into his windshield and then his wheel will fall off. Do planes not reach their destinations or do submarines sink every day? The uboot crewman at the end of the second war is a real king of life with a full range of occupational health and safety, compared to the mediocre crewman of this game with an average lifespan of just a few minutes. Of course, you can start again and again until you finish to learn the entire plot of this game. Unfortunately, it is very reminiscent of the plot of the movie "Groundhog Day", with the unpleasant difference that in this movie everything was determined and you eventually reached your goal, while in this game, unfortunately, every day is randomly different and always to your detriment.

This game's save system is fucking garbage and wasted so much of my time.

It is definitely a Multiplayer-Oriented game but it's totally possible, personally even fun, to do solo. The bots in singleplayer are a bit stupid at times but they're serviceable, and you can [u][b]["ASSUMING DIRECT CONTROL"][/b][/u] over them at all times. It is a very very atmospheric and gorgeous game, even though it gives big Flash game vibes. The music and sound design are impeccable. It's very clearly been given a lot of love and passion. 

The Sub Editor is also amazing, if unintuitive. There are a lot of guides though, including stuff posted on the official wiki site. You can make some gorgeous things with practice, make an overpowered FUCK-THE-ICY-MOON ship, or just customize a personal and handmade vessel for your exact needs. 

The gameplay is weirdly fun for boiling down to a maintenance game. Click button with good timing to make bar go faster. Shoot leak with proper fire gun. Don't crash the ship into that goddamn iceburg. Apply morphine in every situation possible. Apply morphine in every situation [i]regardless[/i] of possibility. You can also harvest plants minerals which is very fun as well. All of them are really quite pretty. 

The combat is very, very tense. Catastrophe is common and frankly a lot of the more chaotic parts are about fixing the catastrophe. One leak can spell your doom and there is very often more than one. The weapons, however, are really damn fun. There's railguns! Miniguns! Shotguns! .61 caliber revolvers!!! It's amazing. 

The perk system is satisfying, and most of them are genuinely worth considering over the other. The perk points are rare enough to be very, very exciting when you get one. 

I haven't played the multiplayer yet, but I'm told it's very very chaotic. In contrast, the singleplayer is described as relaxing, and I must say I agree with that statement. Outside of combat, you have total control over the situation at all times. You go at your own pace, get all the money yourself, choose where to go, and answer to noone. It's nice.

Overall I'd highly recommend it. The asking price is practically a discount as is, and on sale it's a must-buy.

In the dimly lit control room of my submarine, as the sonar pinged rhythmically, and the hum of the engines reverberated through the hull, I found myself immersed in the hauntingly beautiful world of Barotrauma. This underwater odyssey transcended the boundaries of traditional gaming, offering an experience both creepy and cozy that captivated my every sense.

As I took on the mantle of captain, the weight of responsibility settled on my shoulders like the depths of the abyss itself. The eerie ambiance of the game painted a vivid picture of the unknown, with every creak of the submarine's hull and flicker of the flickering lights adding to the suspense. Yet, in this unsettling atmosphere, a strange sense of coziness emerged – the camaraderie among my crew, the warmth of the dimly lit cabins, and the shared struggle against the unforgiving depths forged bonds stronger than any naval alliance.

The brilliance of Barotrauma lies not only in its atmospheric design, nor only in the reliance on team communication, but also in the seamless integration of mods that elevate the gameplay to unparalleled heights. From enhanced submarines to terrifying sea monsters, the modding community has breathed new life into the game, allowing captains like myself to tailor our underwater adventures to our wildest imaginations. I personally think Barocraftables is the best mod due to it allowing a crew to completely change their ship throughout the campaign. The mods transform the already gripping narrative into an ever-evolving saga, where each playthrough feels like a fresh exploration into uncharted waters.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Barotrauma: A Deep Dive into Thrilling Underwater Adventures
I recently submerged myself into the enthralling depths of Barotrauma, and the experience left me captivated and eager for more. This game combines the intensity of survival with the thrill of exploration in an underwater world filled with danger, and it's an absolute triumph.

Immersive Underwater Atmosphere
Barotrauma's atmospheric design is nothing short of breathtaking. The dark, foreboding depths of the ocean create a sense of isolation and tension, perfectly setting the stage for the challenges that lie beneath the surface. The ambient sounds and visual details contribute to an immersive experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

Cooperative Chaos
The cooperative multiplayer aspect of the game is a highlight. Working together with a crew to operate a submarine adds a layer of teamwork and chaos that is both exhilarating and unpredictable. The need for communication and coordination creates memorable moments of triumph and hilarious mishaps, fostering a sense of camaraderie among players.

Varied Roles and Responsibilities
The diverse roles players can assume on the submarine add depth to the gameplay. Whether you're a captain, engineer, medic, or security officer, each role is vital for the crew's survival. This diversity not only encourages strategic thinking but also provides a unique and dynamic experience with each playthrough.

Deep Crafting and Customization
The crafting and customization system allows players to modify and upgrade their submarines, adding a strategic element to the game. The depth of options for tweaking and improving the vessel ensures that no two expeditions are the same, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging.

Developer Engagement and Community Support
The developers' commitment to the game and the community is evident in the frequent updates and responsiveness to player feedback. The dedication to refining and expanding the game shows a genuine passion for delivering an exceptional gaming experience.

Conclusion
Barotrauma successfully combines gripping survival elements with cooperative multiplayer dynamics, creating a unique and memorable gaming experience. The underwater world it presents is both beautiful and perilous, making every expedition a thrilling adventure. For those seeking a challenging and immersive multiplayer survival game, Barotrauma is a must-play that continues to evolve and impress with each dive into its depths.

Barotrauma is a great game to play with friends. We've collectively sunk hundreds of hours (and probably tens of subs) into it. 

Every playthrough is completely different. From what we encounter to how we handle those encounters. Sometimes we can be real stupid and silly and rampage a station. Other times, it requires serious coordination among the 4 or 5 of us to ensure we don't lose the sub. There have been times we've had tons of gear and can progress quickly. Other times, it's slim pickins' and we're just scrounging everywhere to find enough fuel rods. We've tried different subs. We've created our own subs. We've done tons, yet I'm not sure we've done it all quite yet.

So yeah, Barotrauma is worth every penny.

[b]Preface[/b]

I have a friend who likes Space Station 13 — a niche 2D pixel-art multiplayer game with a lot of deep gameplay mechanics. It's also very role-play-oriented, and I think most of the servers would ask you to play the role you chose (say, a civilian bartender) not to ruin everyone's experience. I'd say it's not exactly user-friendly, maybe even difficult to play, but it's quite a unique experience due to how all of its gameplay systems work together.

[b]Early Access[/b]

One day, that friend of mine introduced us to Barotrauma. Back then, it was still in early access. And despite being quite different from SS13, you could tell it was inspired by it. And even back then, it was an adventure.

The developers were releasing updates from time to time, and, over the years, we have gathered our old team to have another adventure 2-3 times. Since the campaign wasn't completely done, our adventures were never really finished, but each took at least a few sessions, every session being 3-4 hours long.

[b]2023[/b]

In March, the game left early access. For this occassion, we have gathered our old team, and a few guys who never played the game before. Due to timezones and work, the most difficult thing for us was to find the time that suited us all, so our sessions were not really regular. But, after around 80 hours (so, months after release), we did beat the game after all.

Like SS13, it has a lot of deep gameplay mechanics (like electrical signals wiring; health/medicine; crafting; water, oxygen and fire simulations) and is coop-oriented. Unlike SS13, it's more user-friendly, modern looking, and overall slightly different from it in its core. This, and thick Lovecraftian-like atmosphere, all mixed into a long, and sometimes challenging or even unfair, campaign of exploring the depths of an ocean, fighting monsters of various sizes, and overcoming emergency situations on and off your submarine.

And even after release, developers still continue to work on the game, making content updates, bug fixes and quality of life changes. On top of that, it supports Steam modding, and community has all kinds of things there. And with in-game submarine editor, you can also make your custom build and share it with other players.

If you have the friends to play this with, this is a game that totally worth at least trying it.
