[b]Pyreview:[/b] This game shows you how much you can truly trust your friends. In conclusion: truth is subjective, a European Handshake is not.

[h1]Nitty-Gritty[/h1]
Turns out, the first three people I'd choose to hang out with on a submarine in an inter-planetary post-apocalypse are the last three people with whom I'd like to be trapped on a submarine in an inter-planetary post-apocalypse. Funny, eh, life's coincidences?

It has its fair share of public griefers, hackers, and trolls, but overall it's a good, fun game, especially in private servers. The in-game tutorials don't walk you through everything they could, and you have to walk through them all subsequently, and I do mean [i]walk[/i], but they're a good starting point to establish your preferred role (even though someone must always be the captain in a server). There are now well-functioning skill trees for your characters, which I greatly appreciate, since it used to be if you weren't an electrician, you were basically a toaster, and if you weren't a medic, you were Edward Scissorhands.

Genuinely intricate DIY sub-building. I can see why they put the videos outside of the game instead of loading them into the files; you can copy-paste bits and pieces, just fine but a good 10 hours of my play time has been spent trying to figure out how to jerry-rig two pre-built minisubs onto one unholy abomination of what constitutes a military-ready transport-class deep-sea submarine, because when you give me multiple choices, I usually select them all. Also, you can infect your friends with parasites, steal their IDs, and walk around in a suit to impersonate them and their permissions.


The Security team AIs can stuff it--literally all of them, every single one; just strip them of their gear, confiscate their weapons, and lock them naked in the airlock before opening the external doors--the Assistants are pretty much worthless if you're the captain, and the engineers and electricians can barely function without supervision over simple instructions like, "For the third time, don't blow up my goddamn nuclear sub, Harvey!" or "DAMMIT BARBARA, I SAID FIX THE REACTOR BEFORE THE CONSOLE." or "If you don't want to be beaten with a crowbar, don't be an idiot, Elliot. NOW GET BACK HERE!" Medics are pretty good, though; just tell them to follow you so they don't go chasing your jettisoned security officers.


[h1]Take-Aways[/h1]
Seriously, though, being able to disable the handcuffing from AIs, or being able to handcuff AIs would be my greatest recommendation to the devs, because even setting one's server to chaos does not stop the captain's own crew from imprisoning him and his friends, who cannot in turn imprison them.

If you've got friends to play with, I can recommend this game at full price, even with the supporter pack; if you're playing alone, I'd say go for a 50-75% sale, though, because the best parts of this game are played in groups and you probably won't feel your money's worth otherwise.

Barotrauma is one of those games you can enjoy more while playing with friends. Not only are there more shenanigans and "misunderstandings" that are happening. You also get that dreaded feeling of being at risk at all times. AT ALL TIMES. One single moment of not paying attention can lead to the demise of the whole crew. But that's the fun in it.

So much for an introduction. The game itself is somewhat complicated in the beginning, but as you progress and pour more time into it, you get to know a little more everytime you play. And at some point your sub will look more like a makeshift mover than a submarine, because you always find something you can "improve".

The only thing I find rather annoying is the resource management, which can sometimes get rather tedious. Other then that, you should definitely play this game if you want to steadily feel "under pressure" in a somewhat challenging submarine game.

This game has been around for a while now after having initially drawn inspiration from another popular game, Space Station 13.

At first I was skeptical. So many clones of SS13 have been attempted (myself included) and have failed (also myself included).  And there wasn't a lot to see when this game first came out.

However, here we are today, after many years of early access, and I have to say, the game is absolutely amazing. I wouldn't call it a predecessor of SS13. It has similar mechanics (deep learning curve and simulation, sabotage, small confines of a ship, etc.) but it's unique in it's own way. Everything it does it does well and when you have a good group of people to play with, it really is a lot of fun.

Having an unknown traitor on board as one of your friends is truly a fun mechanic. Many games have replicated this traitorous mechanic and I feel like this game could have been a lot more successful if it was a lot simpler. Other games with traitorous mechanics usually have very simple tasks that are supposed to be minor distractions while the traitor(s) go around completing their tasks, but Barotrauma forces the player to really focus on their tasks and the traitors end up being a minor distraction given the depth of the jobs each player has to focus on.

This game deserve a lot of recogniton. It hat a lot of depth (no pun intended) and very thoughtfull mechanics. Multiplayer is just awsome an pure Comedy an Horror. And if you have a friend, who can use sub-Editor you get a whole new experience. 

This game is recommended for people, who want to thing for themself and who like to dive deep.

You will be doing your first basic mining or Fedex mission and the submarine hull will breach, a lot. You will be trying to weld repair and one of your crew will drown. And then, your sub will get boarded by a couple deepwater razorclaws and you will bleed out after trying to shoot them with a welder and stab them with your screwdriver, because the mission asked you to buy 6 bullets, which is not nearly enough. 

This is not clear when you buy the title. It looks a lot more fun than I had and there will be rage quitting. This game is awesome for the right twisted individuals and I am glad these developers exist. I just hope they get the help they need. I will not be traveling to Scandinavia.

Great game singleplayer and a very good game with friends. 
Singleplayer has its benefits and a lot more atmosphere than multiplayer. The issue is you're essentially running a daycare with AI and while they mostly work fine it can get pretty limiting when you move out of the submarine.
Multiplayer with a good crew you have everyone knowing what they need to do or in the process of learning. Better than AI every time and can help track supplies the ship needs along with handling resources. Again singleplayer you have to do all the higher level thinking stuff on your own and that's taxing. So sharing the burden between players is great. Only thing I'll give AI is that it's much better at monotonous tasks, because no fucking human wants to do that.

Overall great resource management submarine survival simulator. There's a lot of variety in work along with encounters with sea life. Inventory can be a hassle but I take it as part of the charm of inventory management.

An atmospheric submarine simulator sandbox that feels a bit like FTL, if director/producer Ridley Scott and writer Arthur C. Clarke had developed it. Barotrauma is very much its own thing, but with pings and echoes from other sci-fi classics.

It is a unique simulation unto itself with a smorgasbord of features including character development, crafting, factions and unique storyline that develops as you progress through the single player campaign.

Other features include:

+ Steam Workshop/Modding support adding subs, creatures, QOL and total conversions

+ Hilariously fun multiplayer, but get to know how to play in single player mode first

+ AI crew, that can succumb to stress, crises and parasitic infections

+ Random crew chat dialogue that adds to the atmosphere

+ A look and feel unlike anything you've tried, this one is in its own corner

You can spend hours on it, finding the perfect combination of sub and crew, or you might just pop in for a mission or two like I do, between other life activities or software.

Highly recommended for fans of FTL looking for something along the lines of an adult graphic novel inspired FTL, though don't expect FTL.

The Ocean has its silent caves,
Deep, quiet, and alone;
Though there be fury on the waves,
Beneath them there is none.

The awful spirits of the deep
Hold their communion there;
And there are those for whom we weep,
The young, the bright, the fair.

Calmly the wearied seamen rest
Beneath their own blue sea.
The ocean solitudes are blest,
For there is purity.

The earth has guilt, the earth has care,
Unquiet are its graves;
But peaceful sleep is ever there,
Beneath the dark blue waves.

Barotrauma is a really fun game. I have played BT since legacy and I still enjoy playing it with friends. There are a lot of things to do in this game such as crafting, killing monsters, stelling supplies, or trying to take over a station most of these features weren't present in the legacy. I do admit I still have the best memories from BT legacy because it is free and the only downside to the steam version is the steep price but luckily the game is often updated with exciting new content and is also often on sale so you and your friends can pick it up. If you are planning to play alone I don't recommend it as it is not nearly as fun as it is with friends.

Edit: Steam awards 2021, hopefully this game will win as it is still easily one of my favorite games the updates have never disappointed me or my friends.

Edit: Steam awards 2022, Barotrauma is still one of my favorite games. There were few major bugs but the developers have fixed them and introduced a lot of QoL features. The best part about this game is the modding community that expand the game unimaginably.

Edit: Steam awards 2023, after so many years I am sad that this game still didn't win the awards, the game has evolved a lot and this game has brought me a lot of fun over the years, the only thing that I don't like is the high price tag.

It has its bugs, flaws and other quirks, but with few+ players, plenty of fun was acquired already from one co-op playthrough. Be prepared for some restarts and relogins in multiplayer due to all kinds of weird glitches - which seem to be actively under fixing, so should be happening less and less in future.

The game does have a bit of learning hill in the begin, but half way through our campaign most of us had already learned most of what was needed and it was mostly smooth sailing. Hmm, smooth diving. And with smooth I mean amount of shaking, explosions, leaks, burning reactors, hallucinations, etc. was being managed without too many deaths. (Not counting assistant deaths, of course.)

NPCs are (or at least were) idiotic, but after a bit of trial and error, we managed to figure out what tasks and settings gave best results and least issues from them, and which tasks were best left to us humans.

I'm writing this review after 3 walkthroughs with my friends. Barotrauma has a certain problems but this game is still good. There are a bunch of bugs, there are bad quality textures, randomly generated caves looks bizarre. Despite all this Barotrauma has amazing cooperation gameplay, interesting story, a lot of high quality mods. I liked this game and will play it time to time.

I enjoy the atmosphere a lot. It is a nice mix of story, exploration, combat, and resource management. The game is difficult. It can be near impossible at parts if you do not plan ahead or are relying on an AI crew. There are creatures who are extremely dangerous, basically instant sub sinkers who can ruin a run in a single encounter. If you enjoy challenge and an interesting setting this game is for you. If you have a group of friends who wish to play together, this game is super fun and engaging. Playing alone is not recommend, but definitely playable and enjoyable. The game has a dedicated development team who are fans of their own game. If you play it and don't like it now, just wait a bit. The game has only gotten better since I purchased my copy.

-The following is based on the true story of my earliest play through of Barotrauma's campaign, with some dramatic liberties taken for the sake of storytelling.-

It was my first time playing this game, I barely understood how to control my submarine as my two AI controlled crewmen kept it from completely falling apart from my naivety behind the helm. The reactor growled like a hungry animal, gnawing on our fuel reserves. I knew resources were short, however, and my sonar had just picked up what looked like the wreck of another submarine just below us! There *had* to be some fuel rods on board, and we did not have many, so naturally this was a stop that seemed *critically* important. I gathered a bit of courage, knowing full well my thalassophobia would try to kick in if I left the safety of my submarine, but the bots certainly weren't going to handle it for me. So, diving suit on, extra air tanks grabbed, and my trusty harpoon gun now in hand, I opened the airlock and stepped into the cold, briny expanse beyond my cozy metal diving can.

My swim to the wreckage was thankfully brief, hair standing on end a bit already as my visor light pierced only a few feet into the seemingly endless black of Europa's vast sea. My feet touch down on the top of the rusty old plating with a echoing metallic *thud*, the sound of my plasma torch muffled by the heavy water pressure around me as I cut through the docking hatch. The sound of water rushing into the previously empty hallway of the seemingly ancient derelict was all that greeted my entry, quickly returning to near perfect silence as the room was claimed by sea water. The dark, rusted interior of the vessel did no favors for my anxiety, but I needed fuel rods, and a little rust wasn't going to scare me off.

I went right to work, my oxygen meter slowly ticking down and keeping my mind on task, knowing that taking in the scenery for too long would leave me empty handed, or worse, with empty lungs. The cabinets of the airlock hallway offered a few trinkets, diving knives, old clothes, simple gadgets my own sub had in abundance already, barely worth taking for scrap. Cutting through another bulkhead door, I was shoved inside by the water as it dragged me into another formerly vacant space, and panic briefly caught hold of me. My harpoon gun is immediately and held forward, ready for whatever appears from the shadows! But after a few seconds... nothing. I am still alone aboard this dysfunctional vessel, and with a bit of luck, it will stay that way. Continuing to scavenge and scrounge whatever my pockets can hold, I descend deeper into the metal beast, checking it's flooded ballast tanks, it's empty medical bay and it's busted O2 generator, it's main airlock blown open and exposed to the sea beyond, until finally i find it's reactor room!

I almost dive onto the control panel of the hulking generator, popping open the fuel ports and ready to salvage that nuclear gold for myself, only to be left frowning at four empty slots. Did someone else find this wreck first? Did this submarine run out of fuel and sink, unable to crawl home after whatever blew open the airlock? The questions piled in my mind as I looked around the room, nearby cabinets offering nothing but a few old engineering suits. Rad resistant, yes, but useless to me now. Sighing in disappointment, I remind myself that I haven't searched the whole ship yet, there could still be a fuel rod around here somewhere! Resuming my search, I climbed back toward my entry point, intending to check the other path I had initially ignored. An old, faded label along the wall informs me that i'm nearing the helm of the ship, and ahead lies another bulkhead, this one with a aged porthole resting within it's rusted frame.

The faded, reinforced glass glares my visor lamp back in my face as I approach, but after getting close enough, I finally see a few feet into the helm. Suddenly, a silhouette of a diving suit fills the porthole, a second one at it's back! Survivors?! My plasma cutter finds its way into my hands almost instinctively, and I start to cleave into the bulkhead's protective sheets. The figures watch me through the glass, seemingly just as desperate to leave this God forsaken hulk of metal as I am. It was annoying, not being able to see the faces of the people I was saving, but i had to act fast, they couldn't have much air left down here and their suits look as old and derelict as the submarine!

That's when my face went pale, and realization hit me. The electrical systems have clearly aged beyond repair, the oxygen generator was destroyed when i saw it, there's no way air is still flowing in these flooded confines. And their suits, while old, are the same as mine. The visor lamp is, to my knowledge, bio electric! It would run as long as an at least *recently* living entity was wearing it. Meaning whatever is in there... My morbid curiosity gets the better of me as i stare closer from my presumed safety, just as one of the figures *slams* into the bulkhead, shattering the visor of it's suit against the viewport! The face inside is mutilated beyond recognition, sharp tendrils scrap their barbed tips against the glass as they violently attempt to lunge at my throat! I step back in shock, my mind kicking itself over the fact I almost let those things *out*. Then the question that tips my anxiety to the boiling point enters my mind, where are the bodies of the crew? This ship has been empty of any and all remains, it's airlock is completely obliterated, and yet only these two "bodies" remain? That was the last straw, this submarine was hiding something sinister and I was not about to fall prey to it and leave my crew without a captain. So I grabbed what I could and climbed out the docking hatch once again, returning to my own submarine's somehow welcoming groans of hunger. I've still got a mission to finish on my way to the next port, and maybe this scrap will sell for enough to buy the old girl some food instead. So with a sigh of relief that at least I didn't bring any trouble back with me from below, I took my seat at the helm once more, and set sail toward another job.

-End of story, actual review time-

Barotrauma does many things right, in my opinion. It's mechanical depth allows every player to feel like part of a crew even if they aren't directly piloting the submarine. Everyone has a job to do, and together it can be done. But beyond the thin walls of your assumed safe space the seas of Europa are hiding some terrifying things far dangerous and often vastly larger than encountered here. If there is any one thing I would say this game does best, however, it's in it's atmosphere and aesthetic. Europa is an oppressively dangerous place to live and work, with each port giving you a small breath of tension free air and offering a few laughs thanks to the game's sense of humor. 

Often times your submarine itself is a good, relaxing ride, shipping cargo between ports and mowing down a few swarms of crawlers or the occasional mud raptor. But when you dare to leave your submarine, the tension grows thick. You cant see very far, and we humans are not designed for life thousands of leagues deep. Your ability to breath is on a timer, you can die easily, and you are most certainly *never truly alone* out there, somehow *especially* when you're the only crewman outside. 

Once you learn what lies below the cozy ice sheets the main routes travel through, that terrifying moment when your little blue sonar ping is returned with a loud, large orange ping from something *far* bigger than you? You'll learn quickly if you have a fear of the deep. Or maybe if you're unable to resist the urge to go deeper, find a way past depths that would normally crumple your submarine like a soda can, build better submarines that make the process easier (or harder, you glorious rebel), you'll find something worth your trouble? I, for one, found a new favorite game for my list.

Incredible concept, fitting design, endless hours of fun and a steady income of updates. Great game that's being taken great care of, and helped grow.

In case it's not obvious, you're a seaman on a submarine. In space. Not quite in space, but a moon of Jupiter, so definitely not Earth. Everything out there is trying to kill you, while you're just trying to make a living, sometimes including other humans. You can side with different factions by completing their quests (only a handful of them right now), earn money for... basically housework of the submarine. Restock on ammo, improving guns, appliances, and all that business. 

Immense opportunity of roleplay, even with just 2 or 3 other friends. Getting a full, 10 man sub full of actual players and setting up a chain of command between you is undoubtedly hard, but it can be SO MUCH FUN.

10/10, can't wait to see what's next for Barotrauma.

So, to start off this review im gonna say that this game is for socially active people, if you dont have friends or cant talk to strangers on public servers than this game is not for you, yes you can play it solo, but it is VERY boring without a group of people to play with. With that said this game is an absolute BLAST, a lifefull campaing full of adventures, losses, and stories to tell. Vanilla game is such a masterpiece that i can't even START to explain how good it is. Mods for this game are good too, for those who are bored of Vanilla map, outposts, and locations you can try Dynamic Europa. Got bored of same old ungodly monsters from deepest corners of the abyss? try Barotraumatic. Getting tired of firearms and armor Variety? there are so many weapon and clothing mods that entire book won't be enough to count all of them. Want to try a new submarine? there are tons of those in the workshop. Need a new job to play with? try Warden or Diver or any other job that you can find at the workshop. My point is that no matter how much you play this game the possibilities are ENDLESS, you can play and act however you want, and that in my opinion is what makes Barotrauma, Barotrauma. No matter how many times you play this game, you will always find something new for yourselfs and friends, so stop reading this review and buy the dang thing already! join the others at the journey to the eye of Europa and prove that you are worthy of this crew!

I admit it took a little while to fall in love with this game, as the mechanics were different than what I was used to. However, after learning each role, I truly love this game. I think many would, and I HIGHLY recommend checking it out. 
Pros:
Creepy Atmospheric Music
New game style with in depth innovation. 
Each multiplayer game is totally different, it's always something new that will happen.
Mods and community have made some great templates for ships, mini subs, maps, game styles and more.
The option to play entirely solo game, or multiplayer. 
Pretty good graphics. 
Constantly updating. 

Pro\Con:
You MUST work together, or die together. This is with exception of having Traitor enabled, which allows you the option of ending alone, or killing everyone.

Cons: 
Learning curve (take the tutorial, for others, if not yourself), both in game and with the game interface itself. Some mods can become out of date, and require PC knowledge to go and manually delete them to avoid constant error popups when starting game(s).
Solo AIs aren't very intelligent, and even cannot perform some basic things without taking direct control of them. They also are even worse on mod created ships. 

All in all, I would recommend this game to just about anyone. It's a total trip.

Our gunner was manning a railgun when some giant monstrosity from the depths attacked us from below. Unbeknownst to the gunner, the railgun was loaded with nuclear ordinance, and when fired, disintegrated the bottom left corner of the ship. Four members of the crew were instantly vaporized, a dozen junction boxes blew up. all of our cargo spilled out the now gaping hole and the ship flooded in an instant. Our reactor failed and without enough diving suits people began to drown and be crushed by the rapid pressure change. I crawl out of a closet to find myself and one of our AI crew members to be the only survivors. The dozen other crew members having died in under ten seconds. Assessing the damages, the only reasonable course of action left was to take the AI down and swim out into the murky void. Surrender to Europa.

Praise the Honkmother!

Introduction: Barotrauma is a survival submariner game set in an alien ocean on one of Jupiter’s moons. You can enjoy playing it solo, with friends, randoms and as a horn honking clown!

Multiplayer: Up to 16 players can all man a submarine at the same time.

Solo: Exactly the same as Multiplayer but you are ALONE, real fun for people who likes survival single-player games.

Mods: There are endless mods for Barotrauma, submarines, weapons, player models, more aliens, scarier experiences and more dangerous elements to the world.

Role-play: The Role-play is really fun, the game has a trait system so every time you create a new character on a server they will get a random role-play trait. If you act according to the trait you will have a fun experience.

Skills: The skill system is very good, there is a lot to choose from.

Final thoughts: If you enjoy Survival games, either Solo or with Friends or Strangers. Then this game should be very fun for you!

Do you have a fear of being deep underwater? How about a fear of the dark? Perhaps a fear of deep sea monsters sprinkled ontop? I highly recommend this game in that case! And even if not, I still recommend it! The game can be janky at times, do be aware of that. But its a fun kind of jank most of the time! It's not a perfect game, but it sure is fun as all hell. Control your submarine on your own using AI crew, or get a human crew and embrace the chaos of hearing your friends scream as a deep sea creature has eaten its way into the ballast tank.

The game has a submarine editor where you can build your own submarines as well completely from scratch! Or if you just want something flashier and fancier than vanilla subs, you can download some via the steam workshop. Alongside tons of mods to spice up your gameplay! It's not for everyone, but if you've had your eye on it, I highly recommend checking it out. It's well worth the price in my opinion!

Very unique game with an original gameplay that is sure to give you many hours of fun. The adrenaline rush you get from trying to overcome the many creepy creatures of Europa is addicting but a lot of times you will also find yourself laughing as you mess around with your friends. The game structure allows you to roleplay as well if that's something you enjoy, thanks to also having the proximity chat feature.
The wiring system allows you to customize some features inside your submarine but you can also create the entirety of it by yourself thanks to the Submarine Creator. It's definitely not a feat for beginners as it is quite complex, but can be fun and provide new challenges when you're looking to start a new campaign with more knowledge.
All in all, a solid game that is definitely worth playing as it offers endless replayability if you enjoy immersing yourself in the world of Europa, be it through joining an online campaign or pushing your limits in an endless playthrough.

Barotrauma is an in-depth game and is very fun with friends but is alright in single player with the help of bots, the game is set under the crust of Europa, one of Jupiter's moons. You traverse an ocean inside of various submarines that can be chosen from a list of vanilla or workshop subs you can download.

Barotrauma is a game of many features:

Weapon variety and Combat, you can kill enemies and your friends in many ways which can vary from guns mounted on subs, to handheld firearms, harpoon guns, melee weapons, and an assortment of grenades types. Harpoons guns can have their harpoons recovered after firing. Revolvers are a good backup weapon and can be used with one hand. Assault rifles take up a backpack/toolbelt slot but are all rounders and do good damage. The HMG is the ultimate handheld weapon with a massive DPS but has expensive ammo, but the cost shouldn't be an issue at the point you acquire it. For melee, you can use knives, two handed boarding axes, stun batons, and even using your tools in an emergency.

Traitors can be enabled in multiplayer servers in which a player will be selected at random and must complete a separate objective that is either to sabotage or kill the crew, the normal crew can choose to either kill or restrain the traitor to prevent another appearing, as if the current traitor dies, someone else is selected as traitor.

The health system is in-depth, there are many healing items, poisons, buffing drugs and chemicals in that can be good, bad, or cause side effects, there are many poisons that will kill you or do other things, there are items that will speed you up or make you stronger. The health system is limb based which will affect your performance relating to the location. Once you lose your health, you go into an unconscious state where you stop breathing and lose control of your character, players will have to perform CPR to revive you from oxygen loss or use medical items to heal you to sufficient health for you to regain consciousness.

Classes, there are different roles and sub-roles. The Captain sails the ship and commands it, engineers operate the reactor and repair electrical items, mechanics repairs mechanical items and fix hull breaches, security officer are effective at attacking hostiles in the sub and aiming turrets, medics which heal people and an assistants which are not very good but are decent at all skills.

Alien Creatures, there is a good amount of creatures that inhabit the ocean with some having variations. They vary from small monsters that can enter your sub and kill your crew from the inside, to massive behemoths that can destroy hull segments in one hit.

Barotrauma is one of those games where many new player’s struggle with the initial learning curve. While the tutorials cover the basics, there is still a lot left for the player to learn on their own. Some may view this as a bad thing, others may view it as an experience, encouraging the player to try new things (and fail horribly at them).

This game is best played with a pal or two, while public lobbies are dandy, it’s best to play with people you can better coordinate with to save a lot of headache. This brings me to the game’s current price of $34.99; a price tag daunting like this makes it difficult to convince friends to purchase. I believe adding a bundle option would help mitigate this. Think of a 4 copy bundle which you receive a discount for.

This game captured my imagination and thus far has taken over 1,400 hours of my life from me, and while I can't say I've honestly enjoyed every single minute of that time, I've certainly enjoyed close to 95% of them.  Multiplayer can be a blast, it can also be a terrible gaming experience (mostly due to the selfish actions of a few players) but that is probably going to be true for any online multiplayer gaming experience with random people where there's the possibility for mischief.  Solo and the sub editor are great and both very relaxing ways to play.

Thousands of hours and many trips to the eye of Europa later, I still love this game. I play captain and I host. For me its about the crew I meet and providing good content and sessions. But everyone who plays this and stays finds something to fascinate them. The game is very community based and there is a lot the game itself will not teach you. Join the community and ask a lot of questions is my advice. Learning in a vacuum is no good. This is especially true if you decide to mod or touch the sub editor. Lots of little rules that would catch you by surprise if nobody told you about them. Excellent game with a lot hidden under the hood if you bother to look and learn.

Average session of Barotrauma: You start out with all your mates, feeling safe and content, exited for a new journey. Go investigate some odd readings your mission says. Ok, doesn't seem too dangerous. You dawn your clown suit and go to terrorize your crew with a bike horn until a swam of angry minnows attacks your sub. After fending them off with your deck guns and repairing the damage you arrive at the site. Since you've picked engineer you stay on the sub to manage the reactor, watch the sonar, check the guns and perform general maintenance. While your crew is gone something attacks them. They come back and while you try to enforce quarantine they brush it off as nothing. Queue a tentacle erupting from one of your cremates throats as they lurch towards you. You gun them down thinking that to be the end of it. But nooooo a giant screw off Xenomorph that another crew member had been hatching from an egg charges through the door and kills you. You watch helplessly as the rest of the crew fights to keep the menace down. You respawn in a small rescue shuttle and make your way back to the ship. As you dock both ships are enveloped in a nuclear fireball because you were the only engineer and no one else decided to check on the reactor. You all laugh, you all cry, you all promise that you wont make the same mistakes next time. If that sounds like fun to you, then you're a masochist, but also you might like this game.

The submarine is approaching crush depth and the repairs will not stop the rapid descent of the ship. What do you do?
a) Desperately try to save the ship (in vain)
b) Man the turrets and make sure the fucker that put you in this situation is coming down with you
c) Forget how the laws of physics work and take a dive suit and try to escape the ship only to pop like a balloon anyways
d) Go on a murderous rampage by committing acts of violence against your crew since you'll be dying anyways.
If you answered with any of the responses then you may be qualified to join the crew. Welcome to Europa! We don't have life insurance and never will. Wages on the submarines are below the minimum wage of the most impoverished countries back on Earth. All employees are expected to be armed and protect themselves because we can't always expect security to be able to do their job properly. Any work related incidents are not covered by corporate and you will be expected to pay out of pocket if you seek medical attention at a station's medical facilities. If these things haven't dissuaded you then I welcome you to Europa on one of the least safe jobs on this moon!

A fun submarine management game with an interesting setting. The gameplay is somewhat simple where you are piloting a sub from point A to point B in small sections while completing selected goals along the way. The missions are fun with many forcing players to leave the relative safety of submarine to complete the tasks. Enemy encounters have a wide range of difficulty from easy to "where did our hull go?" Customization and creation of submarines looks complicated with a steep learning curve, but can generate some excellent works as seen in the steam workshop.

Playing multiplayer is definitely recommended as bots are kind of dumb on path-finding and task priority, but good enough for basic functions like repairs/weapons/reactor operation. In the current state, the mission variety is fairly limited and can get repetitive after a while.

Overall it's a good game with lots of potential when it leaves early access

Avast, me hearties! Gather 'round and listen to me tale of Barotrauma, a game that be like a treasure chest brimmin' with pirate humor and high-seas hilarity. 'Tis a whirlwind adventure that had me chucklin' like a parrot with a belly full o' rum. Arr, brace yerselves, me mateys, for a jolly good time!

Imagine this, me scurvy dogs: ye be sailin' through the depths o' the ocean, seekin' booty and dodgin' sea monsters, aye? But here be the twist – yer navigator, bless their peg leg, be readin' a map that looks like it was drawn by a drunken sailor with a shaky hook hand. We be gettin' lost in Davy Jones' locker, navigatin' in circles like a confused crab!

But it be gettin' even better, me hearties! The crew in this game be a rowdy bunch o' scallywags. Yer engineer, he be sayin', "I'll fix this leak," and next thing ye know, the whole ship be floodin' like a breached galleon. We be swimmin' with the fishes, tryin' not to get shocked like a landlubber touchin' an electric eel, while the engineer be scratchin' his head like a parrot solvin' a riddle.

But the true gem, me buckos, be the communication system. 'Tis like decipherin' a message in a bottle from a long-lost pirate. I be shoutin', "We got a leak in the engine room!" and what reaches the crew be more like, "Avast, we be throwin' a shindig in the engine room!" The next thing ye know, we be celebratin' with cannons blastin' confetti while the ship be sinkin' faster than a cursed treasure chest.

Now, mind ye, Barotrauma be testin' yer patience like a stubborn sea serpent, but 'tis the kind of frustration that be ticklin' yer funny bone like a mischievous kraken. 'Tis like watchin' a slapstick comedy unfold on the seven seas, with jokes flyin' faster than a cannonball.

So, if ye be yearnin' for a game that be tryin' yer mettle, makin' ye laugh till ye snort like a blowhole, and remindin' ye that life as a pirate be one riotous adventure, then set sail fer Barotrauma. But heed me warnin', me hearties, this game be leavin' ye in stitches like a tailor with a blade at hand!

[h3]An absolute banger of a game, total masterpiece 🔥 🔥 🔥 [/h3]

Meant to be played in groups though, and I've only played with friends. The game is hard to learn but easy to master. Features unique visuals and exotic music which builds a cold alien atmosphere usually not found in different games.

As a crew member of a submarine traversing vast oceans of one of Jupiter's moons, your responsibilities come down to two things and two things only:
[list]
[*] One is to contribute to the ship by repairing it, shooting ship's cannons and managing resources. Your goal is to survive and your most crucial tool is teamwork. Someone has to steer too :D
[*] The second objective is to fool around during the time in between encounters. In other words - have fun. This is easily achievable thanks to provided musical instruments, non-lethal weapons or other means to troll your crewmates. Barotrauma lets you ragdoll yourself in a silly matter. It's hard not to enjoy all those crazy scenes that you and your friends play out spontaneously. Yo, there are even clown outfits among other clown things 🤡[/list]

Anyway, game's super fun. Sometimes you chill, sometimes you're fed adrenaline. Every adventure is amazing and produces some cool memories. You'll face some difficulties at the beginning though. And they might leave you traumatized.
based game

Lovecraftian underwater horror. best played with a few Friends. if you can convince them to play once for a few hours and you have a disaster on your sub they will be hooked in the surprisingly intense struggle to survive

Every time you play you will find new ways to get crushed, mauled, incinerated, asphyxiated, drowned, eaten, zombified, eviscerated, friendly-fired, not-so-friendly fired, drugged, shot, ""saved"" by the ""medic"", electrocuted, driven insane, exploded, imploded, and more.

Your friends will help you survive... or perhaps facilitate your death. Could go either way really.

In either case it will be hilarious. Best with at least a couple friends, competence absolutely not required.

i'm really on the fence with this one. It has a lot of amazing qualities and multiplayer seems like an absolute blast, but I'm playing single player and it's been quite awful. The crew AI isn't just bad, it's maybe the greatest enemy I've had to face in the game thus far. I just lost a sub because my captain decided he didn't want to pilot anymore. If he's not at the helm he's not flagging hull breaches, which meant our ship was attacked by god knows what and then we fell about 400 meters to the bottom of the ocean when we flooded from the breaches, which further devastated our sub. What was he doing? Nothing. Literally nothing. Just standing in a spot likely with his finger firmly up his own ass. He ignored all of his directives and just stood there, mouth agape while our sub was shredded mere meters away from the next station.

And this is just one instance. Managing multiple crew members is like herding a group of angry, coked out cats. The SECOND you click off of one you're using they take off to wherever their dumb little hearts desire. So imagine: you're trying to mine for ore. You control a crew member and head out into the pitch black sea. The game doesn't tell you exactly where the ore is, just a general area. Okay, I'll switch to the captain, do a quick sonar scan and see what the landscape looks like. That should help me get my crew to the place to mi--welp. My miner is already back on the ship... I've been on the captain for less than 60 seconds and my miner raced back to the ship the second I clicked off of him. And the amount of times my engineer just decided to stop managing the reactor is incalculable. Remember: no power means sink straight to the bottom of the ocean to suffer massive damage to the sub.

I understand this is meant to be a multiplayer game, but I honestly would have preferred they didn't add the single player content at all if the AI was this awful. I could've save my money and time if it was listed as exactly what it is: a multiplayer game. It's genuinely got the makings of a great game and it probably is in multiplayer, but the single player experience is just miserable and it's completely because of how impossibly stupid and frustrating the crew AI is.

Get a group of friends or watch The Hunt for Red October--you'll have a lot more fun for it.

I had this game on my wishlist for years because I never had the friends to play it. Then suddenly we all bought it at once for some reason. Our first session lasted 1084 minutes, according to the Steam overlay. Some of us went sleep and woke back up again to rejoin the same session they'd left six hours earlier. This game is bloody amazing!

After 100 hours (of which at least 24 was spent in the submarine editor - the BASIC submarine building tutorial is like 2 hours long and it's considered speed-building if you whip together a decent one in 8 hours or less - if you can design a functional submarine in this game you can probably design one in real life) we finally reached the Europan Ridge. The second biome-area in the game, out of about five, apparently. 

Within five minutes we had submarined into...something horrifying. It took over our ballasts. It then spread to the reactor directly above it, and all of the junction boxes within. It then proceeded to cook the Engineers and Electricians alive. It then erased the Medical Officer from existence while trying to save them. The Captain finally left the bridge he'd grown so attached to after realising his Navigation Terminal was no longer working (unerringly reminds me of kids only surfacing when the wi-fi turns off, actually) and for once, the problem didn't go away because the peasants in the lower decks fixed it. He climbed down the ladder and was instantly destroyed by the horrifying thing that had now taken over half the submarine.

We all agreed that it was a fantastic time, joy all around. Jolly good fun! The submarine that took 24+ hours to make is going straight back to the drawing board!

Along the way we sedated an entire Military Outpost before robbing their armoury of everything they had on them, explored more caves than I can count, salvaged multiple wrecks  and a few hostile submarines, slaughtered leagues of Europan wildlife (all of which deserves it by the way), experienced the riveting delight of the enemy within due to rampant husk infestations, witnessed a grown man cry when his pet Mudraptor was summarily executed on deck, watched horrified while a Clown birthed multiple baby Mudraptors in a civilian outpost for "the fun of it, Captain!" and ultimately discovered why you should be afraid of the deep dark.

At one point we were battling a giant Black Moloch (I call them Bollocks for short, which perfectly describes them) who beat us up so badly half the submarine was missing or ruined, and our submarine sank 1000m into the abyss - on the precipice of reaching total crush depth - before we got it running again. On the way back up, we encountered something bigger than our entire submarine. I'll never get the stains out. Our engines and reactor gave EVERYTHING they had to get us out of that hellhole, and somehow we managed it, being smashed around up and down, repairing the hull constantly while the Captain pulled us out of hell itself. On the way to the nearby Outpost we encountered thee Black Molock again, and our valiant Captain decided to shoot it with the Railgun. That was loaded with a Nuclear Shell, and stuffed full of C-4 explosives. At point blank range. The entire front half of the submarine was obliterated instantly - everyone in medbay who were recovering from the fight with the abyssal horror died almost immediately, crushed to death by water pressure - but the sacrifice was necessary, for the Black Moloch was slain along with it! 

There was much jubilation. Vengeance has that kind of effect.

We limped back to the nearby Outpost and ended the round. A round that was supposed to be a simple delivery and beacon activation mission that would take no longer than ten minutes. Instead it took two hours, killed most of us, eradicated all our supplies, caused multiple breakdowns through stress and soaked my clothes through with sweat. 

100 hours. I only bought it like a week ago. I don't even feel like I've even been playing it. Where did the time go? I normally only review games when I finish them...but with this one, I don't even feel like I've started it. How?

I love this game.

The diving part feels great too. There's just something about rushing to the diving suits, gearing up, grabbing your plasma cutter and then jumping out of the airlock of your submarine with your crew in tow to explore some subwreck, or a cave filled with horrible stuff, positioning yourself while floating in the brine to mine some ores or gather some flora, it's just very cool all around, for truth. 

Thank you very much Space Station 13 and FTL for making me interested in this game! If you like those games, you'll love this.

Some sketchy updates post "release" though, which has soured my opinion a little of the games future lifespan, and has made my friends quit the game entirely, but oh well. I had my fun while it lasted. Still worth buying if you weren't playing before the "updates" - ignorance is bliss!

It says 5 hrs played but in reality most of my playtime has been offline and not counted to that total. There is a TLDR at the bottom of the review 

You pilot a submarine travelling through the deep ocean of Europa, one of Jupiters moons, trying to make a living doing whatever you can. Be it mining, mercenary work, scavenging, stealing, anything you can to get by. The works actually feels alive, with its faction system that requires care being put into who you help and who you hurt, the broken down submarines that you can scavenge or just ignore (maybe you can repair them and even get them running again, but I haven’t tried), the random encounters with monsters, and different factions reacting to what you do. On top of that, the game seems to have been built for multiplayer but if you don’t always have internet like me, there is ai that actually makes the game not only playable, but fun when alone. 

It was built for kb+m, there are great communities made steam deck input maps that make it so enjoyable, I played it exclusively on my steam deck for months before installing it on my pc. 

The game has a constant sense of tension as you need to decide between having your sonar on but risk being spotted by enemies, or turning it off and being blind to your surroundings. Sometimes they’ll crack your hull and send you to the bottom of a cave as you frantically try to get them out of your sub/kill them, repair the holes, fix your machines to pump the water out, refill oxygen tanks if you’re under water, and keep your crew inside the sub and alive. At least when you make it to a station, you can pay a small fee and get the whole sub repaired for you and your crew back to health. You get missions that can change what happens on your next expedition as well. These missions are pretty much mandatory in the early game, as there aren’t a whole ton of options, but later in the game you can make do with mining+scavenging+killing aliens. 

Terrific mod support, you can get anything from a new submarine to a game look overhaul on the workshop and easily choose which mods take effect, and even which ones take priority over the others. 

Also, the soundtrack is very good and sets the stage and mods very nicely. I’m no expert on music, so not much I can say other than it sounds nice. 


TLDR: games fun, works on controller, you pilot submarine on moon ocean kill aliens and maybe people, it good steam deck, game tense.

Story 1

Went deep diving, Fighting a possessed ship, locking us with harpoons and shooting our hulls.

Punched through their hull with a railgun and fired a nuke into that ship, scared everyone with a flash of light but we survived.

Story 2

Went deep diving again, a creepy spider came at us, sunk our ship at crushing depth, each resigned slowly to their death as they slowly run out of air.

Some took their last stand with a weapon to face the beast only to be eaten in the dark. I will be joining them soon, in the belly of the beast.

If it weren’t for a group of friends who can't easily agree on a different game, I would not have played this for more than an hour. A group of more than four friends who like to sail together might give this a try but playing it with bots or random people might be something that intelligence agencies utilize in black sites.

Let me say, though, that most of my criticism is highly subjective and I am generally happy that this game has been made, for the developers and anyone who might be inspired to make something that tickles my fancy more.

[h3] What I liked about this game:    [/h3]
- The general idea of manning a ship with different tasks is well done. The positions are sufficiently differentiated so that cooperation is necessary while interesting enough in themselves to not get tedious.
- The artstyle is nice and consistent.

[h3] What I disliked: [/h3]
- The decision to employ a ragdoll engine for enemies and characters not only makes the game look incredibly wonky, it also leads to clipping issues, imprecise movement and very chaotic firefights. Ragdolls should be saved for party games or a long overdue Team America game.
- The worldbuilding and “story” is just strange to me. The background and gameplay are so gloomy that the attempts at absurdity and humour fall totally flat while the fact that you are on Europa in a future where space travel is clearly possible never really impacts anything. Yeah, there are aliens. But it could as well have been some undiscovered deep-sea cave 20 years in the future instead.
- No manual saves. I get that this is somehow still a polarizing point in gaming and might be difficult to implement in a multiplayer focussed game. But the single missions can go on for quite some time if you run into trouble and we have had problems sometimes within the group with our allotted time. Would have been nice to just save and quit when you need to.
- The rougelike aspect isn’t my cup of tea and here it also clashes with the idea of trading which is implemented but doesn’t really make sense. Most of the time you need to move forward. Every mission and station that makes you go back is a risk that you will take 3-5 times at most (I assume). This becomes a gameplay problem, when you NEED to go back because you are in danger to softlock your progress because you ran into trouble and need money for a better ship or munitions.
- It is rather easy to get into a downward spiral. The game has several points at which you need a better ship for which you need money. Also, you need a lot of ammo which also costs money. So if you have a couple of “bad” missions, where you spend more ammo or resources than necessary or even fail them you might get to a point where you can’t really go on.
- More often than not, getting to the next station was more of a drag than fun, especially when random enemies just spawn without warning and jump you which could lead to a cascade of attacks that might add up 30+ mins of additional gameplay after completing some hard missions. Yeah, yeah, the soulsike groupies might see it differently, but especially in a multiplayer game it’s not fun to start over and lose an hour of progress just because of randomly generated levels/enemies. It’s especially bad if this happens (as it did quite often for us) within the very last few meters before docking.
- Whoever designed the last mission should work on sidescrolling shooters but not on this type of game. Or it was a sad joke that I did not understand.

There’s more but these are my main points. Have a nice one.

Silence... That's the beauty of Europa. Ever since my childhood I saw these waters in my dreams. Finally I'm here. It's strange that I've feel a connection to this place. Leaving the past behind me I will seek my fortune through Europa's endless ocean. I will be the Security Officer of the 'Unnamed Orca'. She seems in good condition. Our captain is Grand Admiral Yorick, he seems like he knows what he is doing but I have no idea who gave him the Admiral title. Our medical officer is Dr. Kane. he has bags under his eyes and looks tired most of the time even though he seems everywhere around the ship and helping out everyone. Plus he looks like he knows what he is doing too. We have Jeffrey the Electrical Engineer. he is a fun lad. From time to time he gets electrocuted but that's fine he is getting better and his will keeps him on the run. Our mechanical engineer is Jamal Kukri. He is seems like it's his first time in a sub too. He looks clever enough to figure it all out. It's a good crew. We can do it.
[b][i]16th September 2238[/i][/b]
We made a couple of cargo missions to keep our pockets filled. We got a few breaches, shotgun is my fav alien repeller at the moment. I got a new collage Officer Thrawn he seems like a silent man. All is good for now. Everybody is doing their best.
[b][i]22th September 2238[/i][/b]
Officer Thrawn died during a breach. He was in a breached room without suit, his head popped up instantly. The Ocean gave him a quick death. May he rest in peace. I took his body to armory. After this incident I stayed on Coilguns. Sweeping and searching through Ocean's endless void. At some point I thought I heard something, like someone singing. It was only for a moment I guess I'm hallucinating from exhaustion, I gonna take a nap, we are close to station anyway.
[b][i]23th September 2238[/i][/b]
It's AMAZING! Dr. Kane hatched an ailen egg. He seems cute, his name is Peanut. Dr Kane also gave me some methamphetamine gonna try it on my next trip out of sub. 
[b][i]25th September 2238[/i][/b]
We had a GOD DAMN NUCLEAR BLAST IN OUR SUB. We were getting attacked by swarms of Crawlers and Hammerheads around the sub. I was on the guns defending the ship. Suddenly I heard a big explosion and seen a spark on the sub even from the periscope! I went to Reactor room and it was fucked. Jeffrey's remains were all across the room. Poor lad was trying to fix the reactor but apparently, he died because of a nuclear reactor blew up to his face. I'm gonna miss him. While transferring his remains to med bay I saw Peanut eating the corpse of the Office Thrawn. I pulled my revolver and pointed it against the Peanut's face but he just smiled at me. I couldn't do it. Sorry Thrawn.
[b][i]30th September 2238[/i][/b]
We got 2 new engineers. Sigurd for electrical Jamal's cousin Kukri as mechanical. We payed respect to our dead comrades. The newbies seems to know their way in an 'Orca' which is a relief. The ocean has been violent lately. Grand Admiral Yorick died of barotrauma. I'm gonna miss him well. We got a new captain Grand Admiral Thrawn. He seems like a bureaucrat. I hope we will get along.
[b][i]2th October 2238[/i][/b]
I was on meth in a wreck to collect the logbook of the long dead captain. We contacted a husk and i got bitten by it. Dr Kane was with me and he quickly dragged me to the sub and gave me cure for it. He seems like he saw shit about this parasite but he would rather not talk about it. We are the only 2 survivors from the beginning we have an understanding between each other. Plus he supplies me with morphine and meth. It's the best kind of friendship you can find under the ocean of Europa. 
[b][i]8th October 2238[/i][/b]
We killed a Moloch. It was HUGE. It was a fast kill because we were prepared for it. I loaded the piercing ammo for coilguns cuz that I heard the creature had though armor. It indeed had. But as functional crew we made in no time. While gazing the beasts enormous corpse falling down to the bottom of the ocean to be a feast for the parasites of the bottom. I heard the same song again stronger this time in a language I can't understand. It was... It was soothing to see his corpse slowly fall down to abyss as the song kept on. I was frozen on the periscope of the coilgun. I refuse any allegations to my drug habbits. It was not a hallucination.
[b][i]13th October 2238[/i][/b]
Sigurdr died of Barotrauma. Our engineers have a bad habit of dying. It's like this ship has a curse on engineers. We hit an ice block and he hit his head to the wall of the sub which made him unconscious. So he couldn't move or said anything and as the water kept flowing the room. Poor lad couldn't get a suit and died of Barotrauma. We got a new Engineer Eman. He seems on edge after hearing the fates of our last engineers. Can't blame him. 
[b][i]15th October 2238[/i][/b]
Eman died during a breach. A Mudraptor got in the ship and tore him to pieces. I was too late to save him. I blew up the creature's head. Peanut drifted into the void during this breach, that was the last time I saw him. He got sucked into ocean. Hope you are good out there Peanut. You are home now.
[b][i]18th October 2238 [/i][/b]
Survived my 4th Husk infection. I love Dr. Kane. 
[b][i]20th October 2238 [/i][/b]
We got new engineer, Nino. Hope he survives. That's all.  Also I miss Yorick.
[b][i]25th October 2238 [/i][/b]
NOW I KNOW! I KNOW! AHAHAHAAHA! We were on a mission to get an alien artifact from some ancient alien ruins. It had a strange architecture. Strange cravings and traps were inside. Soon we found the artifact and as I grabbed it we swam back to sub. But during that time with the artifact in my hand and swimming in the Ocean. Looking directly into that abyss where no light reaches. I heard the song again! It's the most beautiful thing I have heard in my entire life. And this time...
This time I understood. I get it now. Message is clear.

[i]The Ocean is calling for it's children...[/i]
and
Sgt. Wolfgang is hearing it's call.

[b][i]29th October 2238 [/i][/b]
Eman and Dr Kane are dead. I can'T believe it. They burned to death under the biggest ocean we know. Sometimes I feel like this moon is laughing at me..

I am now afraid of both Europeans and fish.

first i must say that if you give this game a negative review, i will fight you:

This... this is like the perfect game, all big franchises are dying everywhere you look but at least we still have Barotrauma.... A Whole New World~

great mods but mods can be risky, IMO & the NPC/Bots are kinda useless sometimes they are tinkering with them to make them more useful, but it's still a fair warning)
everytime i kill a Husk i scream: The Wayans Bros. was a good show, and they didn't even get a final episode!

Also, it's amazing that you can use singleplayer CAMPAIGN with Player mods!!

the ragdolls will make you giggle like a schoolgirl while alone at night with a heart of ice, And Hollywood films can't even match the jump-scares, but also the look on my face when i finish these Midnight Mining tasks.

Performance Fix by Evil Factory tends to solve the FPS issues the game has, and i think recently updates in April 2024 really helped, as low Frames Per Second was the biggest issue in the game.

sometimes your mods will break though, load order is key so that takes some testing...if that annoys you then you won't like the game at times, but if you can ignore it (or fix it) then you will LOVE IT

So like i said, the modders have outdone themselves, as well as the developers are tweaking things constantly, we just need a few minor fixes so i can continue the downward spiral into the Abyss, You can install almost any kind of mod and it keeps going BTW, like the Duracell bunny. it's not high graphics and it won't make you pasta, but for the price & all it's little workings 9.3 on the enjoyment scale. (make sure you tip the modders [that i like], they really put in work, lol)

Edit: there are many things that could be added to the game...however to speed it up & make it more fun, like a way to edit your character's features (tough, professional, crazy) after the first load-in to the game, (send them to the re-education camp!) and a way to put ammo in a magazine, so you dont have to carry around loose bullets. 

Max stack for ammo should definitely be 60+ for loose bullets (but there is a mod for this...it doesnt always work though), you dont buy a gunshop ammo pack and only get 8 loose rounds in your pocket.... so i prefer the SMG magazines, but those should stack to 4 or 6 and im seeing it as 2x Mags (i get tons of free magazines when i attack a station but 2 on each inventory slot is a bother)... Duffel Bag MODS are a blessing, because you can put all your ammo in your waistbelt or duffel. 

2nd Edit: i need to add there are too many gun mods, too many diving suit mods & now too many gene mods too (probably), but it's not a big hassle besides needing to sort or avoid buying things and just sell all the guns you find, lol. also, ONCE AGAIN... mods can break because there are so many mods... watch out for that & becareful with what you install, like some mods can be unsafe. i took the risk of using mods from people who have (VAC) bans (cheaters) but i dont recommend other people do this. [so be careful with how many mods you install]

[h1] 𝙸𝙸. Details [/h1]

It's an exceptional game, especially when played with friends*. The narrative is not explicitly presented but rather unfolds through the environment and interactions. The gameplay might initially appear straightforward and unengaging, but it quickly escalates into an intense and thrilling experience. Barotrauma comes equipped with a built-in submarine editor and supports workshop mods, allowing for subtle adjustments or a radical transformation into an ultra-realistic diving simulator. Overall, Barotrauma is an immensely enjoyable game that can be played casually for a few laughs or seriously, delving into the lore and sparking heated debates among teammates regarding their preferred faction loyalties.

*Friends aren't required, but it's much more fun to play it with friends.

Really well done survival Co-Op experience that even works well in single-player with bots. The developers behind Barotrauma started out making a spiritual successor to "Space Station 13." They ended up with much more. They leaned into oceanic horror elements... in space... in the oceans below the ice crust of Jupiter's moon of Europa. The developers have also mentioned that Frictional Games' "Soma" was a big source of inspiration for Barotrauma. The result is quite an experience.

The game is light on story elements, but what there is for story unveils itself pretty naturally as you progress and dive deeper. The random mission (or quest) structure generally involves transporting people/cargo, mining, retrieving objects (Ye Olde Fetch Quests), hunting the wildlife, or hunting outlaws. On the surface this looks pretty limited. But beware... it's not quite so simple, as once you drop into the procedurally generated world, anything can happen. You could get a "blue milk run" that has little to no action and is just easy money. Then... you could stumble into terrifying situations that you and your crew barely survive. Playing with bots on even normal difficulty presents a challenge at times, not because the AI is bad, but because there are things lurking in the deep that will challenge even seasoned crews.

Speaking of crews, each member of the sub is important, and will help in vital roles. The sub itself is both the object that keeps you alive, and tries to kill you... that's where the crew's roles come in to play. Whether that be Security, Engineer/Electricians, Mechanics, Doctors, and of course the leader being the Captain. Engineers keep the nuclear reactor purring and maintain electrical equipment. Mechanics maintain equipment, Doc maintains the crew's health and can perform CPR to potentially revive crew that have gone into cardiac arrest. The Captain makes sure everything is coordinated and running smoothly, as well as filling in gaps in coverage when necessary. There is also the role of "Assistant" which is basically a "red-shirt" from the original Star Trek. If specialist crew are killed, it will typically have a negative effect. Not so with assistants, though there are certainly other good reasons for hiring them as they can provide... some unique... services.

It's a very unique, fun (and at times terrifying) experience, and I hope that people won't be turned off strictly by its classic side-scrolling nature.


TLDR: Fun with friends, side-scrolling adventure and submarine management, thalassophobia exposure therapy game.

BAROTRAUMA

A great singleplayer and multiplayer co-op game that dives into the world of "2D horror, strategy, survival shooters" where you are part of a submarine crew journeying deeper into the crushing depths of Europa's oceans. Playing in singleplayer is challenging at first but once you get the hang of efficiently assigning and prioritizing tasks for the crew, the AI does those without you having to manually control the specific crew members. 

Multiplayer is where this game shines through as it is absolutely a different experience filled with nerve-wracking pressure and also perhaps some crew shenanigans along the way. Expect the unexpected especially when you go deeper into other biomes as there are routes where you may encounter Abyss creatures. 

So make sure to stock up on guns, ammo, medicine, and materials because it's going to be one hell of a journey towards whatever lurks at the deepest part of Europa's oceans...
Dont forget to like and subscribe "DIGGA DIGGA DIGGA" - jack black

funny submarine game

This is a game that checks many  boxes.

First, its a great coop that requires cooperation but its prone to chaos. Would you keep your cool or will everything catch on fire while you sink and are boarded by creatures from the depths? Will everyone be covering their post or will you have a straggler that accidentally opens a hatch and condemns the whole crew to its doom?

Also has a traitor mode that can be hilarious.

The game can be very technical. I've spent almost as much time designing subs with complicated wiring and component systems as I have spent playing. You don't have to go into such depths to enjoy the game, but it opens a huge doo for experimentation and chaos.

The campaign has a nice flow and diplomacy layer that you need to manage as well as  resources and economy that reacts to your actions in the map.

Its ok as solo but its not very good because the bots are very limited and it can be overwhelming to have to deal with many of the missions, but bots will perform fixes and other tasks inside the sub with enough skill to be able to not think about them. But you really want to play with you friends.

Now that the game is complete, I can let you guys know my honest opinion on this game. This is a very challenging game, in fact, if you're not up for a learning experience, trying to comprehend how to play the roles on the sub, I would think it's not a game for you (at least playing the game on multiplayer).
Has an interesting story, almost everything has an explanation on the game (yes, even the clowns) not without leaving some mysteries for players to wonder. The price is ok for the content you're having, also the devs said that they will make some changes in the future to make the game modes more interesting.

For short, the game is amazing, interesting enemies, amazing systems, challenging, and you should buy it, worth every cent spent and amazing to play roleplaying with friends, I LOVE THIS GAME!

Honestly can't explain it, nor convince even closest acquaintances to play due to the graphics,ragdolling and visual 'appeal'  ...but god is the game satisfying to play.

Even in SP story mod (with/without modding) they've made massive strides and making a complete experience and the setting and atmosphere is done quite well.

MP, is pure chaos, as intended, but there are the odd server(more than you'd think) with decent players, with JUST enough room for some shenanagins, while not just being a constant troll fest [and addition of random traitor presence into Story MP games is a ton of fun and really puts a crew on edge, even with randoms.

Screenshots, videos, footage will not convince you, but if you survival, exploration, horror, co-op/crew management...electrical engineering (if that's your thing?) ...and a dash of clowning (literally,and a totally valid character build), definitely do yourself a favour give it a try --...and do the tutorials so you aren't completely lost at the start, does take a bit to figure out wtf to do at the start I recall, but once you've played around solo for a little bit, you'll get itand the fun will begin!

Just doing this for the Steam Awards badge, but honestly, this game is great especially with friends.

Edit 26.11.2020: Editing this review for the Steam Awards badge yet again! My opinion on the game hasn't changed. If you got some friends to play it with, you're bound to have a lot of fun and even if you don't have friends to play with, you can find some from public servers! :D

Edit 25.11.2021: Here we are again. This game is something that I just never really get bored of long term. Sure I take breaks from it, but I always end up coming back to it! There's also a lot of mods available for the game, if you ever get bored of vanilla. Anyway, until next year!

Edit 23.11.2022: Hi, I'm back! This is the 4th time I'm adding to this review now. The game's still as great as it was before and it keeps getting better as the devs are still actively updating the game. If you were thinking of getting this game, I'd say now's a good time as the game's 75% off and for that cheap price you're going to get possibly hundreds of hours of fun. Well I can't think of anything else to say, I hope you're having a good day whoever might be reading this! See you in 2023! :P

Edit 22.11.2023: Hello again! It's the 5th time that I'm updating this review! I'm still playing Barotrauma, though admittedly not as much as last year.  The game is still a lot of fun though, and they've finally added a proper ending to the campaign (which I still actually haven't got to, but I've heard it's good). Anyway, how's your year been? Good, I hope? To me, 2023 was one of the best years in my life so far, despite some low points. Well, I'll see you next year! Have an amazing day! :)

Barotrauma is a game best played with the kind of friends you can trust to not devolve into team killing in magicka.

It's at its best when everything is going down the drain and the environment is nothing but chaos but your team is staying organized and clearly communicating.

It's a game of feast and famine, of hurry up and wait. Some tips for getting more enjoyment out of it: use only the in game voice chat/text  (trust me it ties in to a few things), don't do all your organizing when you're docked (it's good to have stuff to do during lulls), and don't look up anything on the wiki (its much more fun to not know what lurks in the deep)

One of the first things that struck me about Barotrauma was the level of detailed suffering put into the game mechanics. As a new player, I found myself constantly learning new things about the submarine systems its management, as well as the vast array of missions and encounters throughout Europa. This vast array of systems and mechanics allows for an incredible level of pain and suffering, allowing players to really make their time with the abyssal horrors their own.

The gameplay itself is intense, with high stakes and a constant sense of danger. As we descended into the depths, I found myself constantly checking the status of the submarine and crew. Mainly cause we were constantly taking on water, I ain't the best captain. But at least I'm learning and enjoying myself, unlike the rest of the crew.

In addition to the main gameplay loop, you don't need to progress forward as you can always turn back and just have fun while not stressing about progressing. These missions offer a great way to freak out and also provide new challenges to tackle. But yea the game can seem highly repetitive at times. 

Overall, I highly recommend Barotrauma to anyone looking for a unique and immersive drowning simulator. The game's challenging and extremely unpredictable gameplay make for an incredible experience that will keep you coming back for more. Oh and don't forget, weld the assistant in the ballast tanks without a headset, you'll thank me later.

Amazing game with constant update, you can just throw tons of hrs only in the editor to make your best submarine, or try playing the hardest mission with your friends/crew,  is also good for roleplay giving the player lots of things to use.
The atmosphere is amazing with low flickering lights, energy that comes and goes off from the reactor, monsters outside the sub, crawling and trying to break through the hull and a strange space environment around you open to exploration.
 
[h1]Pro: [/h1]

-Atmosphere
-Coop
-Exploration
-Crafting
-Subs/Monsters/Characters Editor
-Workshop

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- Not easy to understand on the first impact
 there is a tutorial but some things like eletrical components are not clearly explained, you need to use them multiple times and experiment before understading how it works (that can be also considered a PRO)

- AI
The AI is not the smartes if you play solo, but not completely bad. you can order them to do a lot of things.. anyway dont expect help if you are drowning outside the sub. They keep costantly saying a lot of bullshit, campaign-talking 0 interaction with the AI crew (actually anyway is decent AI, hope for improvments).

- Mission in the campaign
Some times the missions you can get form the outposts can be repetitive, they are adding more and different type of missions, the biome the strcuture of the map and the situations change how the mission should be accomplished but some times.. just dont feel enough to breake the game routine

Overall awersome game if you love submarine/space atmosphere and coop palying, is a must play.

Barotrauma has been in development for a really long time and it has finally released its full glorious potential. I reviewed Barotrauma in 2019 when it was still in Early Access as 'f*cking awesome already'. 

Everything that I then wished would be improved, has improved. 

Yet, one of the risks of purchasing this game has stayed the same: the fun is essentially dependent on the people you are playing with - and its popularity has brought another issue with: most servers require you to install a lot of mods.
