[b] small TRYPOPHOBIA warning for ballast flora  [/b]

this is a complex game which is a spiritual successor to space station 13... you can imagine the chaos this means.

[b] gameplay[/b]
You and your (bot or real) friends are in charge of navigating and keeping a submarine working, while exploring an extremely hostile unending deep ocean that is darker and scarier than the path from your bedroom to the kitchen/bathroom at 3 am

[b]the good[/b]
you will never run out of things to do. specially if you play as engineer/electrician because EVERYTHING WILL BE CONSTANTLY BREAKING WITHOUT GIVING YOU ENOUGH TIME TO BREATHE
and that's when you playing it right, mind you. when you play it wrong you will instantly die.
playing it right means agony stress and slow death :D

you can have your own pet alien, one is named peanut and another is named orange boi. imagine how cute they sound

you can become the alien, or if you are a doctor you can make everyone else the aliens. both in a lethal and non lethal but very mutant way. via genetic engineering and forcefeeding your crewmates.

you can steal stuff which is far cheaper than crafting it yourself :D

[b]the bad[/b]
-peaceful underwater silence... and then explosions that are louder than the jumpscares in FNAF4 out of fucking nowhere, and likely inside your pocket or the area you are standing in. this kept me off of playing it for a while because I almost had a heart attack.

-the bots AI is abysmally STUPID. to the point you can't quite enjoy playing it singleplayer because they will just fuck up too much, lose all your diving suits in the middle of your sub sinking to the bottom while aliens breach and chomp your head off but you cant do anything because the bot lost the last diving suit and chose to close you in the medbay that is now serving as a full ballast because the aliens wanted to enter that way. and yo can't exit because the bot thinks they are helping by constantly closing the door so the alien doesn't get inside, while you, as the captain are drowning trying to escape trough that same door while getting your legs eaten away by a freaking underwater dinosaur.

- the possibility of getting stuck with an incredibly annoying 'DO WHAT I SAY BECAUSE I SAY SO' kinda crewmate, which will not let you do anything other than what they want. yeah I get that you are the medic of the sub, but I know that I should be fixing shit instead of commanding the helm because I'm an engineer and not the freaking captain. (a captain that is very alive and already driving the sub btw)

[b] my experience [/b]

ignoring the first hours of gameplay i had with a shitty crew and the small 'loud enough to make you deaf' jumpscare that almost killed me and put me off of playing it for years..

i am honestly very hooked to this game now, after some rounds with a small 3 person crew which are all very cool with each other, and avoiding explosive cargo, and nannying the reactor to make sure it will not explode... i am having the time of my life pretty much

i love how you can be peacefully navigating the void for a while.. and suddenly you get swarmed by aliens that breach your ship and get inside so you can beat them to death, then get alien aids and since you are both the engineer and the medic of the crew you need to eat a bunch of antiparasite medicine while pumping your crewmates full of opium and giving your sub cop a crapload of steroids so he can go punch the aliens better. 

and then you regain control of your ship, get back on your feet, navigate peacefully for a little while UNTIL SOME MASSIVE MARINE MONSTROSITY DEVOURS YOUR WHOLE SUB AND YOU ALL DIE, and out of nowhere you hear clown noises...

i freaking love this game. space station 13 was made out of CHAOS and even if this one does not reach to even a quarter of the chaos of SS13 you still have your good deal of chaos , and is the chaos and the roleplay capabilities of your crewmates that can make the end of the sub, a glorious time to remember.

9/10

get this if you want to have a taste of chaos and possibly roleplay, oh and also if you like gardening and pet keeping.

I'm Not a fan of 2D games because that's all i had to play back in the day, But this game removes the restrictions presented by 2D games in a unique way. Even though you are still restricted to moving in 4 directions, this game is amazing with its open world feel to it, its a crazy experience when something bursts through the hull of your submarine turning your routine of fixing equipment into an all out panic to find either a dive suit or a room that isn't flooded or inhabited by a hostile monster. You will feel like you're accomplishing so much by repairing an entirely destroyed submarine, fixing breaches, repairing pumps and restoring the power from the nuclear generator, junction box by junction box.

You wont know how awesome this game is until you have parked your submarine for an external voyage. leaving the relative safety of your submarine full of oxygen will change the game for you,. With not knowing if there is a monster diving at you from above or below, or not knowing what caused the wreckage you're about to explore. 
I enjoy scavenging for everything i can from a wreckage or from the cave walls/floor to sell, use, or craft with.
Beware the alien structures, if you don't pay attention to the route you take, you could find yourself getting turned around and lost with limited oxygen. The artifact you drag out of these places can be a game changer for the rest of the mission or an explosively failed mission if you don't know what you're bringing on to the submarine...

This game is one of the best multiplayer games I've played... about 2 years ago. The unique mechanics and deep sea horror atmosphere of the game plus its difficulty made playing with my group a blast, but as this game was updated its flaws would grow to its breaking point. I think two updates in particular mark the largest drops in quality for the game, the latcher update and the talent update. The latcher update was perhaps the single most mind boggling updates I have ever seen for a game. Abyss creatures are by their design and nature meant to be scary, insurmountable barriers and a deterrent to navigating the abyss. I remember the first time I entered the abyss and encountering an endworm in the first zone of the game while trying to reach a mission objective and being terrified by the line that moved on sonar. We tried to do that mission several more times after that to no avail and eventually gave up on that mission. The latcher is, by design, an easy abyss creature, it is the only abyss creature that spawns in the earliest areas, it has the lowest hp pool of any abyss creature, Its AI will start retreating at a handful of gunshots sent in its direction, its latching attack can send you UPWARDS (and off of hydrothermal vents in many cases) which is more beneficial then it is a detriment. This is contradictory to what made abyss creatures scary, interesting, and more importantly fun. The pandemonium that would break out on my ship when a few orange shockwaves showed up on sonar was fun and constitute my favorite memories of playing this game. During the campaign where I beat the game I was [i] RELIEVED [/i] when plummeting to the abyss in the [b] Hydrothermal [/b] Vents (last area in the game) and seeing that the abyss creature that spawned was a latcher, any and all tension that we might all die was lost and that is [b ]NOT [/b] what an abyss creature should be doing. 

    I don't even know where to even begin with the talent update. I feel really bad for my friend who played assistant because they got [b] DESTROYED [/b] by that update, although as a captain main we didn't get off easy (although captains have always had a bad talent tree, made worse with the medals being nerfed). Engineer is still far too powerful and can do the roles of mechanic and security with their talents. Security and Doctor were good changes, but doctors are still a largely useless class outside neurotrauma playthroughs. Many of the fun things about the talent trees (assistants getting being able to reach 200 in every skill, 3 medals at the end of a mission if played well, Hand Cannon not being trash) were removed and made the anticipation of progressing to get new levels much weaker and is one of the reasons why my group of friends never finished our 1.0 playthrough of the game.

    The last thing I want to briefly touch on is how this game has one of the most out-of-touch communities I've ever seen for a game in terms of what makes this game fun. There was an outrage a while ago in the Barotrauma community over the removal of "storage containers" which at first me and my friends though meant the removal of the boxes that items came in when you purchased something but was actually about the removal of a suitcase-like item that functioned as an additional 4 inventory spaces. Me and my friends never realized that so many people were actually playing the game with their hotbar filled to the brim with these items (which sounds like management hell to me) and were so mad at this that they threw such a tantrum that the devs backpedaled. Not the talent changes or the awful latcher update, they were angry about an item that made inventory management [i] worse [/i] somehow. I think that its telling that only 3.5% of players have  gotten the achievement for beating the campaign, compared to 2.1% when I first beat the game prior to 1.0. 

If you want to play this I suggest taking a time machine to late 2021 or early 2022, rising tide was probably the peak of this game.

The traitor update made the game 3x better.
Now you can't stack oxygen tanks which is cool considering the fact that before the update every person had more than 3 oxygen tanks in a single slot in his inventory.
Now when you crash from the server and join back your character won't be dead and you can control him again which is very cool.
And now traitors are much more fun to play with. You don't get the same traitor tasks over and over again anymore and now the tasks are much more interesting. And also allowing you to set at what chance a traitor might be on your sub is very cool. The update overall is perfect. I hope they add more monsters, structures and missions for the campaign. The game is very good every update makes the game better and better overtime and i think its pretty much worth the money considering the amount of content the game has.

The amount of detail and depth in this game, no pun intended... is phenomenal. Yes, you can fight enemy submarines in PvE combat as well as giant monsters or little monsters. You can accidentally shoot your friends, or flood your submarine. The difficulty levels and sliders are all very adjustable so you can tailor the game type to your own fit. 

The customization and immense amount of weapons and armor as well as other random items are all very appealing and it takes serious work and dedication to get some of them, sometimes days of playing the game. It is better with multiple people but playing alone is also incredibly well polished, it enables a unique AI dialouge similar to Fallout 2 or Tactics and makes your NPCs feel more alive. Yes, you can also mix NPCs and players together. Yes, you can have little 4 man submarines all the way to 20 man submarines. The game is very fun.

There's just something about being in a metal box surrounded by ever-growing horrors as you go deeper. Gameplay can be janky, but feels intentional to make keeping the sub intact a struggle. Traitors in this game feel unique as their limited objectives can quickly spur out of control. This game has the same vibe as Space Station 13, but in a much more concise package. Careful what you find in the deep seas of Europa, you might have been better off docked at the station where it's safe.

I have just completed the game after beating the final boss. And it was wonderful as I dumped vast amounts of nuclear shells into it. The battle to get to it was hours of fun, enjoyable conflict of managing AI (which were a little silly sometimes) where I fought against so many horrors that made me genuinely spooked (at least for the first time fighting them). There's nothing more terrifying about seeing a sonar signature that [i]you don't what it is and it is coming very very quickly[/i]. It is a fear that made me (and possibly you if you play) irrational as maybe instead of trying to enter an alien ruin, you try to level it to dust by wasting ammo instead of being brave in facing the alien guardians inside. [b]Barotrauma is a game where you don't have as much control as you think you do.[/b]

There are some qualms I have about it such as sometimes dumb AI and a lot of management in singleplayer. I also dislike the fact its so hard to get lore when I deeply deeply want to drown myself (haha) in this world. I want to know the biology of how these monsters work and the ecosystems as well. However, as far as I know, the monsters are just enemies rather than apart of an ecosystem. Lore exists and I know it is deep however it is hard to find with it being thrown in through text or rare characters (which I think is fine, I just want more).

Of course, friends will make this game 10x as funny and enjoyable with the intense moments caused by being attacked by a moloch from the top and a thresher horde from the bottom (you'll learn these terms quick) let the game have any atmosphere you want in a snap. Of course, it is mostly just terror. There are so many positive things about this game that I can't just explain, it has to been seen or experienced. Get the game and play with a friend or several if you can, I don't think you'll regret it.

I was caught off-guard by how incredibly deep and challenging this game is. It was _rough_ at first, but now I live only for my next dive into the depths of Europa. This game really reminds me of Freelancer (2003) and how much I miss that open world multiplayer experience.

This game is so cool. It takes all the cool things from SS13 and makes them into a much more palatable, fun, cooperative romp with missions and purpose. The campaign mode is excellent and the division of labor between teammates is divine. When playing alone, the bots are pretty good too! They've been slowly improving all the annoying things and frequently add more and more content and make the bots smarter and smarter. Great game.

I love when I am going well on along just transporting cult members, the usual Tuesday. But what isn't the usual Tuesday is when a giant behemoth of the deep sends the loudest noise know to Europa into my submarine and the cult member explodes and starts attacking me.

Going for a short, easy mission in a relatively weak sub with some friends. Accidentally damage the ballasts severely while screwing around on our way to port after the mission, and plunge to extreme depths while trying to repair. We hit the bottom hard, and almost die from the impact. Fortunately, we patch ourselves back up and start the long, 1600 meter ascent to get to port. And then a late game monster hears our sonar.

We are then hunted in the deep ocean by a beast about the size of the ship that really likes sticking its tentacles to the sub and dragging us hundreds of meters down. Not only does it drag us down, but its spine attacks cut clean through the ship and flood every compartment, causing the ship to plummet even further. To top it off, we hooked our brand-new depth-charge system up incorrectly and it didn't work, so we only had our weak cannons to fight it. But after hours of fighting, flooding, sinking, repairing, and the most intense respawn sub journey I've ever seen wherein we ran out of power and had to swim the last 100 meters through the abyssal-monster-infested ocean, we finally got into a rhythm and decided this bastard was our white-whale, and we weren't going home without it being dead. It took everything we had, and by the end we had almost no ammunition, welding fuel, or addictive medication remaining, but she was finally dead, and we limped home.

And then we remembered that it wasn't part of a quest, so no loot.

Tl;dr: Barotrauma is to SS13 what Rimworld is to Dwarf Fortress - accessible, and with a completely different theme, but a LOT of inspiration and similarities.


Gameplay: Barotrauma is a 2D sidescroller. The game was intended to be played mainly in multiplayer, but enough work was put into the bots to make it... playable in single-player. In the game, each person controls a certain human character (in singleplayer, you can switch between the crewmembers), who then, according to his role as well as the needs of the mission, is responsible for doing various tasks among the team's submarine. There are 6 classes in total:

- Captain: Pilots the sub. Usually, in multiplayer games, acts as the "game master", giving orders to other crewmembers. He's the most crucial of the bunch, since bad piloting can strand the sub in an unrecoverable position (such as sinking into the Abyss to be mauled by a gargantuan Abyss monster). The sub mostly navigates using active sonar, which also attracts monsters, so around some (like the blind Moloch) you can simply sneak past. On top of that, piloting too aggressively can fry the electrical systems, so there's a bunch to juggle, and it can get quite intense at times.
- Mechanic: Repairs mechanical devices and crafts mechanical items. the game also has a very robust inventory management system, with roughly about one or two hundred different items, each with various functions, and which can be stored within toolbelts, storage containers, or sub furniture lockers. This includes various tools, drugs, weapons, ammo, clothes, etc. On top of that, most items that can be carried can be crafted using a fabricator, while any raw ores mined from inside caves can be deconstructed for raw materials for the fabricator. Usually, the mechanic is responsible for quite a bit of that.
- Electrician: Repairs electrical devices, but can also help out the ship by tinkering with the wiring. The game has a significantly complex electrical wiring system, with a bunch of logic components to allow rudimentary programming of certain functions of the ship. Stuff like automatic nuclear reactor controllers, automatic door controls, remote-controlled guns, extra ballast toggles, silent running modes, and whatever the players can think of. Neat.
- Security Officer: Responsible for the guns. Both manning the large cannons attached to the ship, but also wielding shotguns and SMGs for excursions outside of the ship. A bunch of missions involve exploring Europan caves and alien ruins, which is where the Security Officer shines.
- Medic: Responsible for healing crewmembers, as well as crafting various medicinal drugs, and tinkering with more esoteric stuff, such as researching alien genetic material for genetic boosts. A more niche role in the vanilla game, it's still very helpful to have at least one in a crew.
- Assistant: A role for newbies. Focused mostly on fast skill gain, and becoming a jack of all trades by the end. A bunch of crew talents lose bonuses upon crewmember death - but none of those count on assistant deaths. So, it's essentially the Star Trek redshirt class.

Each class also has a talent tree, which unlocks special abilities for each class. They can range from minor to almost game-breaking. They can give status effects, or they can unlock new fabricator item recipes, allowing for the crafting of new tools and weapons.
There are also a bunch of mods that can overhaul some essential systems of the game. For example, "Neurotrauma" is a mod that completely reworks the medical system from the ground up, making it much more complex and engaging. Haven't really played it myself, though.
The game is very in-depth. Expect to spend a day or two just browsing the wiki, like you would to prepare for playing Space Station 13.


Level Design: Sailing the ship from one end of the map to the other takes 10-20 minutes, but if the crew take some 3 missions that require excursions outside the sub, that can quickly balloon to about 2-3 hours. On top of that, due to all the crafting and inventory management, I would also sometimes spend up to 2 hours in each station in-between each mission just organizing and upgrading my sub's inventory. The game has a "director" AI that spawns hostile fauna at different points in the mission - it's just a bit repetitive, and you can almost expect and brace yourself for an incoming attack.
The Campaign has some 30 missions if you go straight forward through the world map, so expect to spend quite a bit of time before reaching the ending.


Story: Barely exists. Most of it is tone and set dressing, Essentially, the game takes place in a future on Europa, one of Jupiter's moons. Humans have started colonizing the planet, but then lost contact with Earth. Also, Europa is full of alien ruins and hostile fauna. And the game takes place in an anomalous crater, from what I understood. That's... essentially it.
There are some random events that can be triggered in stations, but they give little extra world-building. There's a group of ending missions, which take place in a unique environment, but that's essentially where the story actually begins - right near the very end of the game.


Graphics: The sprite work is great. The ships feel slightly rusted and worn down, yet still functional. Rugged, yet still high-tech. There's a lot of visual clarity - each piece of furniture, appliance and most items can be easily identified and picked out from background decorations. A lot of aesthetic weight is being carried by moody lights, lamps and other light sources illuminating (parts of) the ship. 
The monsters are straight-up Lovecraftian - the crawlers, for example, give me Innsmouth Deep Ones vibes. The Abyss monsters are majestic in their size and sheer presence. The background has parallax layers of rock floating. Wrecked ships are all completely rusted, like in Iron Lung, or some of the interior pictures of the carrier Admiral Kuznetsov. Europa truly feels like a tight, hostile place.


Music & Sounds: Great. The main theme is strong, full of creaking metal sounds. Intensity layer music almost acts as scare chords. Outpost music is usually a bunch of sci-fi bangers, with samples of buzzing machinery or electronics incorporated into the tracks. I have some of the tracks in my personal playlist that I listen to while working.
The sound effects are quite functional. They're not overwhelming, but draw your attention, and give a lot of info as well. Monsters growl, hurt humans grunt, damaged alien machinery loudly beep, the nuclear reactor buzzes, engines whir, weapons go *bang-bang* while sub cannons lobbing shells go *thwump*.  When an emergency alarm is blaring through your ship, you'll hear it loud and clear.


Summary: When I first read the story idea on /v/ for the game "Pressure", I wasn't too hooked by it - it didn't sound so fun. However, Barotrauma proved me wrong - it's a phenomenal game, and, dare I say, almost one of its kind. If you have a stomach for complexity and item management, definitely give it a shot.

Rating: 5/5

Single player is playable but multiplayer is where this game shines.

Do the tutorials, get a microphone, and play with some folks in the multiplayer campaign. With a good captain and folks taking the game at least a little seriously, this one is a blast. Most other games eat your time, but aren't really exciting. This game has you cooperating to operate a complex vessel and overcome extremely dangerous horrors. 

I've seen subs 100% full of water, floundering on the bottom of the Europan ocean, with all their systems ruined come back from the brink because of dedicated crews. Games like Barotrauma can't really be compared to games that don't offer this style of play. Its extremely awesome and satisfying to face major set backs, but pull through.

If you have a mic and people to play with this game is 100% worth the full price. 

Did I mention there's robust mod support? Yeah this game rocks.

I'm not fond of other submarine games, as i find them both difficult and boring at the same time. Barotrauma on the other hand is complex enough to not be called a children game, but also simple and entertaining to have me (as simple player) engeaged throughout the whole thing. Being a sub captain in real life would be kind of boring, but here you have all of the mechanics at your fingertips. And if the chaos that your campaign will inevitably evolve into isn't your style, you can just delve into the submarine editor and make the sub of your dreams or the most OP one, who cares. EDIT: I now recommend this game. Finally item prices were adjusted, and ammo and other items can be crafted from multiple materials. While the rest of the community complains about the storage changes, they actually make it much more manageable to play solo. Empty crates are still a nightmare, so is crafting while controlling a single character, and bots still suck but they can be worked around, so it can be done, especially with mods. Not all issues were addressed though, original review below.


This game is not ready for a 1.0 release.

Bots still get stuck. Ordering a bot to clean up will result in them standing around when they're done and not doing the next order in their list. If you were wondering why a turret was not firing and your sub is flooded, then this is likely it. Bots tend to be bad in general, especially during emergencies. They'll struggle to repair flooding breaches up a ladder. They will run around enemies for some reason while I'm trying to get a shot in. Speaking of which...

[strike]A revolver round costs half as much as a railgun shell. As in, [b]one[/b] revolver round, yeah. For the basic revolver, which needs about 5 shots to kill the most basic critter in the game. I can either buy two of these, or buy ammunition that will annihilate them several times over in one hit. Anyway, the consequence is if you get boarded, even if you manage not to lose anyone, you get severely punished in terms of resources, and if you're in the early game you probably won't survive another hull breach. Also, merchants have very little stock of everything, including railgun shells which you need copious amounts of in the late game. The economy needs to be reworked across the board.

Talents tend to be bad,[/strike] mostly the early ones. Some talents only give crafting recipes for very basic things that later become obsolete. Similarly, a lot of talents revolve around gaining bonus XP or leveling skills faster, which necessarily means they'll eventually become pointless.

The game features single player campaign but is absolutely not designed for it. Since traders have very limited stock, crafting is mandatory and incredibly tedious solo, as you have limited inventory slots and you have to haul everything around yourself, while controlling crewmates with different crafting skills who keep wandering off. Being able to order bots to craft things on their own would be much better and would have saved literally a third of my playtime.

Also, for some reason, buying things at a trader spawns a crate in an arbitrary room in your sub with the purchased items inside. Each purchase at a trader (there are usually 3-4 different ones at each station) creates a new crate, which you can get rid of by picking them up one by one and dropping them in the deconstructor in a different room. Empty ammo bins also have to be deconstructed/refilled one by one. All of this easily took another 20% of my playtime. It's completely ridiculous, and yes, you can now guess how much percentage of my playtime was dedicated to actual gameplay instead of chores.

There are probably a few more points I have forgotten about since it's a complex game, anyway I doubt there is time to properly fix everything. Developers have announced the game will be out of early access soon, but this really isn't the time for a full release, it sorely needs quality of life and a lot of adjustments and fixes. I've mostly enjoyed the game by keeping its EA status in mind the whole time, so I can't really recommend this game if it gets out of early access in this state.

[strike]EDIT : 1.0 patch notes don't mention any of these issues, and it seems there are new ones as well. I bought items twice from a merchant which spawned two crates, one of which didn't have the items I bought in it. Previously only one crate spawned per trader, not one per transaction, which I suppose causes the bug.[/strike]

I am a very big fan of cooperative games. Whether it's Far Cry 5, Carrier Command 2, Diner Bros, Door Kickers, Emergency 20, It Takes Two, Lovers in a Dangerous Space Time, Overcooked 2, Portal 2, Trine or Satisfactory. I know many and love them. But Barotrauma is by far the best cooperative game I've ever played! The possibilities are endless! The fun is enormous, the replay value unrivaled so far. 

Sure, it's still an early access version and the AI could use some upgrades, but the game is already a legend.

I would still highly recommend to use some mods (https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3027569027) and also, if you have that time, to build your own submarine in the editor. That makes the game even more enjoyable!

If you want to have a look at my submarine just search for "TA-24" in the workshop. 

Have fun!

This game exemplifies how you don't need jump scares or demons to be truly scary or creepy. The limited visual range and the sound effect add to the already dark and creep atmosphere the game poignantly creates within the first 10 minutes of game-play. I would fully recommend this game to anyone looking for a good quest driven horror game.

you're locked into a tiny submarine with your best friends for several hours
the cramped space gets to everyone as the horrors of the outside lurk and drag across your submarine

Eventually your friend goes mad, puts a clown mask on and straps C4 to the hull of the ship and blows a hole into your vessel while you're crafting something, blissfully unaware that the entire crew has perished.

Would play again, will continue to play.

Devs neglect every gamemode except campaign. Most notable examples were: addition of talents (unobtainable outside of campaign, but many things were nerfed for every mode because of their existence), and the amount of starting gear being devastated in the name of campaign balance.

Very little actual content. Most levels are the same barebones wastelands with little to do besides loot the same 3-4 pre-made wrecks, spend AGES navigating alien ruins for abysmally small amounts of loot, mine randomly generated caves that have bugged layouts concerningly often or mostly very samey copy and pasted missions that are "kill monster but bigger", "mine x rock" or the occasional "cargo mission" in which you get free money on basis of cargo missions being almost impossible to fail and having no risk associated with them.

Did I mention the changes to campaign balance? The campaign balance that doesn't exist. Extraordinarily easy to stack armour or buffs to instantly kill enemies, become impossible to damage, and maintain this state for almost completely free.

Also it costs way too much. This is in no way a £30 game. £20 at best, and that's being generous.

TL;DR: balance fucked, no content, most gamemodes ruined by updates,

TLDR: This is one of the best co-op experiences you can have with your friends with a plethora of features and details that a lot of devs simply lack, please support this product.

Barotrauma is such a unique experience as a game, so much thought was put into this and with every update it only expands upon itself in so many ways and evolves itself to fit any medium in its own way (which at least to me says something to the quality). Putting these words into perspective is a bit difficult, so I wont. However! I can telly you dear reader that there are few games that will make you absolutely HATE your friends/crew mates in a very unique way, I stg this is a competence test, you will go through the equivalent anger of watching someone sledgehammer your pet in front of you, then IMMEDIATELY after they resurrected it said "JK bro just a prank here's 1 billion dollars". All you are left with is discombobulated emotions and like a higher quality screwdriver for repairs, maybe even a real neat gun. With that intense hatred comes an extraordinarily strong sense of duty and respect for your crew mates, having a full crew in a dire situation doing everything they can to keep a ship running gives an incredibly strong feeling of community, after all its only a few inches between you and oblivion...or another horror of the depths.

I wont go into too much about the actual content of the game, I genuinely think going into this with a group and discovering for yourself what it has to offer is the best possible experience, that being said I wont leave you with nothing, so I'll give general information. Faction status matters a lot in game progression, its not hard to manage just don't go on random killing sprees in stations...Unless it benefits you, you can play this game any way you like and it will generally be viable. Any sub can be customized to its fullest potential, I mean everything, from its shape to the way the wires run and function in the ship, its not even a necessary feature you can just do it to reach any potential you want. The game is linked with steam workshop (always a bonus) I would recommend modding, normally I wouldn't I personally enjoy games as a company presents it but the community of this game is insanely good at making everything feel like an authentic addition (within reason). when on stations random faction missions appear out of nowhere giving you random advantage. Level design and monster design are inspired, some missions feel like you're experiencing one of the Alien movies....just not any post Aliens, maybe Prometheus but only the goods parts. A lot of this game really feels like you are the survivors of multiple horror movie scenarios and the more you learn the more you just become the monsters you fight so hard to quell in your pursuit of glory and riches..... Perhaps some clown related activities.

To close off this rant; this game really is something special to me and I think there should be more like it, I hope this will inspire anyone to give it a go, I promise its worth it.

(Note: I was fucking hammered when I typed this magnum opus. I will not do any revisions. Play this game it deserves as much recognition as it can possibly get.)

Changes to the pressurization system makes this game effectively unplayable. A breach in the hull of the ship is near instant death regardless of the depth of the submarine. You are required to wear the full scuba suit at all times now because there is simply no time to repair the hull before you are squished like a grape. This wouldn't be terrible in theory if it didn't make you slow as a snail and consume oxygen bottles the entire time. The suit and helmet should really be two different items. I remember when this game was about reacting to the chaos of a sinking submarine, but now the margin of error is so low that is simply not fun or recommendable for new players or veterans because a hull breach will now kill an entire crew in under six seconds.

This game is amazing, had it for 2 years and hardly played it until recently. One of those games like rimworld that make me care for my crew and feel the losses as if my own brother had died.

Often times I will complete objectives slowly, exploring the map, killing off the entities attacking my sub and tediously collecting resources from each one. 

Delving into every cave to collect materials, scrapping abandoned and destroyed subs for loot while trying to figure out what went down. Dragging bodies back to my sub to be returned to their families. 

This takes hours sometimes per delve, so it gets exciting when things go wrong, the stakes get higher. Perhaps the moloch you were contracted to kill rams your ship into the ground, maybe you let your guard down and suddenly a bone thresher and his posse of tigers decide to get under your sub and tear it apart, sending you crashing into the rocks below. 

Thank god I have my crew to depend on, like brothers. Each one of them ready to man the guns, ready to repair the hull, ready to repair the electrical boxes and restore the nuclear reactor. They can all do this in under a minute and if anything gets inside we kill them without prejudice. It’s thrilling when things that had gone wrong end up going right, the cultists even managed to survive in stowage. Nice.

This all works out about 50% of the time, sometimes things get out of hand and loses are inevitable. That’s part of the game. 

But when after all that trial and tribulation, half your crew refuses to equip diving gear before repairing sub and they explode due to low pressure, it makes me want to commit self harm. 

I should not have to use up an order to at all times have my crew ready for expedition so they do not  willingly kill themselves. Please for the love of god give the ai some self preservation. If the hull is compromised and their little bodies are bout to bust why are they repairing before equipping the suits that are in the next room? Sometimes they outright refuse to wear them or take them off only to die moments later. 

Epic game but if I have to retry for a 4th time in a row because my crew hates living imma buss.

Edit: New review. With the comeuppance of the latest update; It truly feels like treachery. Radiated_leader had already stated most of what I wanted to say in their review "  I like the game, I find it pretty fun, both with and without mods. Pretty good servers still remain. I overall really liked it and it was definitely worth the price I paid for it.

HOWEVER

It is a dying game, the devs have made quite a few changes that were opposed by the players, and, like many other games, it is greatly overpriced now.
If you buy this game off-sale, you are paying $35/€35/£30 for a game that has about 5-8 non-campaign servers at a time, and something like 10 campaign servers.
While I can't speak for the campaign servers, since I don't tend to play on them since I consider it a commitment, I can speak on the non-campaign ones. About half of the non-campaign servers suffer from shitty hosts and admins that abuse their powers at the expense of the players.
For the ones that don't suffer from admin abuse, it's about a 50/50 whether your experience is ruined by reactor griefers, shitsec, or medics that just poison/OD everyone. That leaves about 1-2 non-campaign servers at any given time that will actually be fun for a decent person to play.
But of course, you can just play on your own. Except due to limitations of the bots (I think the devs have tried their best to make them better, but they still struggle alot) singleplayer campaign can be a living hell.
If you want to play with friends, that's another $35/€35/£30 for each of them.

Overall, as much as I love this game and would love to see more people join, I can't honestly recommend people to buy it."
After the community had publicly stated that they would not want the removal of storage containers from the usage inside other storage systems, such as cabinets, it had practically nullified their entire purpose. I am not biased with or against any side of the argument in terms of relations, but instead of the idea of ideal gameplay. The undertow development team has truly made a blunder by the rework of this system, and effectively made grinding in their game FOCUSED on grinding in order to finish a campaign practically physically fucking painful. It has also made SEVERAL, and I mean SEVERAL creators have to redo FLEETS of workshop items to the point some have them may have even given up entirely on the game. So we may lose a strong modding force due to this complete assfuckery. Several times over the community has stated NOT to make this change and yet they stepped over them like bugs -- hence, they no longer care for what the community has but instead completely ignored them. Matter of fact, I myself am starting a new boycotting group against Undertow due to the fact they've overstepped. Yes it IS their game, however to make a change that would irrevocably anger hundreds if not thousands of players due to the MASSIVE scale it has, completely breaking saves and workshop items that FOCUSED on this feature being changed. There was talk on how it was "difficult for new players" to find resources -- and that is COMPLETELY bullshit. Now, it will be even HARDER for large scale campaign players to organize their resources and stuff everything into one location, meaning overstock will occur and thus some items will be lost. And then backpacks -- the idea was practically used because of the popularity of a mod. and thus, Undertow practically just yoinked that for themselves which sounds pretty familiar (Ahem. Development teams have taken entire ideas from modding teams quite often recently.)

Even after the community basically begged and cried out for this change not to happen, the devs stepped all over creators who had large-scale ships and stations posted on the workshop, some who may have left due to this change. and then, not to mention the complete RUIN it sets onto previously functioning campaigns which will now have items and storage containers all over the floor. 
The older players pleaded for a while when this was announced, all the more to sell out to newer players who were just a little whiny that they couldn't find some extra items. But since this is a change MANY players don't exactly like, I suppose like all true crews. 
I'm proposing a mutiny. And we're gonna aim for scuttling if the terrible changes are not removed, and fixed.

Now, for those who wish to read my original review:


  


I've played this game since it was a wee legacy on gamejolt and I have to say that watching this game grow is like being the godfather of a child -- You know it's not yours, but you cherish it just the same.

and here's my experience at 700 hours on this version:

When you join a lobby with a long campaign, be sure to check if there's a discord! There's lots of friends to be made, especially when you join the Almighty Meat's servers! 

Clowns are actually a good thing in my opinion (I am a clown and doctor main.) So when you see someone going assistant and in a clown suit, be sure to help them get clown gear! But NEVER provide them explosives! I can tell you right now that in legacy, clowns were the icons of demonic influence! So it's best to help them grow from the negative roots, and nurture the slapstick comedy factors.

Be sure to pick Engineer or mechanic if you don't feel like you could handle too much expectations like a medic or guard, and especially a captain. They're important and also can provide extremely helpful gear in the endgames of campaign runs.

whenever you go out for a dive, grab a couple of extra oxy tanks and place them into a toolbag or clothing piece you have if you have "pockets"

Never mix up oxygen and welding fuel tanks.

Buy it for you AND all your friends. Its not for the faint of heart but incredibly rewarding. I actually feel like a crew with the people i play with. It's not a normal game. Not like the competitive aggro stuff you usually see released. First game I ever bought on steam.

This is, without question, my favorite co-op multiplayer game on steam. With a crew of good friends by your side, the horrors of Europa's icy waters are incredibly fun to overcome. This game makes you feel like a genuine sub crew. You'll feel the paranoia of a parasite outbreak on the sub, the rage as you attempt a mutiny on the captain for docking your pay, or the fear of losing radio contact with your crew in an underwater cave. Like any submarine, the game is a bit rough around the edges (poor single player support, wonky physics, connection issues, occasional frame rate dips), but will serve you well if you stick with it. Plus, if one sub doesn't work out, you can always make your own or download one from the workshop! To this day, the question "We diving tonight?" is always met with a resounding "yes" in my discord. I definitely recommend.

This game is amazing. There's no other way I can describe it. Buy it with your friends.

The premise of the game is simple, get from A to B in a submarine while completing missions and getting paid. But every level is different, and can be a good challenge. The game itself isn't hard, and you will need to learn what you're doing, but the tutorials do a great job explaining. Past that, there is a large degree of freedom afforded to the players. You can create your own electrical logic gates to do just about anything if you know your way around computer logic(not that hard, trust me).

The games replayability is immense, but it truly shines with at least a small crew of friends (2-3 friends can work very well, 4+ can be amazing). Past that the modding/steam workshop scene for this game is one of the best I've seen, and so many of them introduce fun aspects. Your friend is too loud? Cool. Remove his lungs like the surgeon your parents wanted you to be. Wanna get fried alive by sonar? There's a mod for that. Giant mech suits? There's a mod for that. Wanna secretly drug your friends ad make them go insane? That's already a thing but mods take it to a whole new level.

Overview
Barotrauma is a survival horror game developed by the Finnish studio Undertow Games and published by Daedalic Entertainment. Following an early access beta phase that started in 2019, the game was later released in March 2023. I enjoy this game and it's one of my favorite games.


Basic Knowledge And Lore
Barotrauma is set in a fictional world where humans have landed on one of Jupiter's moons “Europa”. Due to the icy surface of the moon, people have moved under the ice into a vast and deep ocean. Civilization lived as one until they stopped receiving signals from Earth. Due to the sudden break civilization broke apart and formed into many separate factions. In the campaign, you play as an adventurer whose goal is to maintain his submarine and venture into the depths of Europa.


Location And Setting
Barotrauma does a great job of giving you a sense of location and freedom. Even though most of the game is spent inside of your small cramped submarine, the game nails the caves and feeling of a vast and open ocean. The different biomes give you a sense of progression while reminding you of the dangers that lay ahead. The game keeps you from feeling bored on long journeys with its huge element of surprise. For example, ice spires appear in vast spaces and you need to make a choice. You decide whether you shoot them, causing noise, or you outmaneuver which takes more effort and be silent. This is just one example of the many cool dangers these oceans present.


Creatures
Probably my favorite thing about Barotrauma is the number of scary creatures that roam the ocean. These creatures range from deceased humans that roam the halls of flooded submarines due to a parasitic virus called “Husk”. Fun fact: the husk virus attaches to its victim's bones so you can capture it using calcium extract. The game also features eldritch horrors beyond your imagination such as the Charybdis, a huge sea monster that is incredibly efficient at tearing apart the hull of your sub. It has relatively bad eyesight but it makes up for it with its hearing. If you have your radar ping on and it hears you… it's pretty much game over. The game has tons of terrifying enemies that can also BOARD your sub. Meaning they can claw their way into your submarine and rip you apart. I have separated the scariest 3 into what I like to call “the big three”. One of the big three is the Charybdis who I talked about earlier. The second one is called “the Latcher” It has 30 eyes and lurks in deep dark crushing depths. It attacks by biting your hull and sticking its tongue into your sub, proceeding to drag your sub down into crushing depths. Hence the name “Latcher”. The last one is “The End Worm”. This thing is the most aggressive creature in the game. It makes its presence known even from afar with its loud roars and shrieks. It is the largest creature in the game. When it attacks your hull it will beeline toward your sub hitting it with a devastating blow violently sending your sub flying toward rocky cliffs. This thing attacks all creatures showing no mercy. 

 Overall
Barotrauma is a very scary yet interesting game and if you enjoy a good scare I definitely recommend this game. For this game's price tag of 35 USD, I would definitely buy it without waiting for a sale. I also wanted to mention that I had a lot more to say but I wanted to keep it spoiler-free hehe. Thanks for reading and I hope you have a good day.

This may be one of the most unique, and fantastic games I have played in the last 5 years. I believe it deserves all the recognition it has. In essence, its a game about crisis management, recovery, and team coordination, playing solo your best bet is to grab a good small sub you can manage largely alone, in a group, is where the game truly shines. 

I will not bore you with the dramatics, but my experiences have included. 

Being trapped at the bottom of the abyss by a colossal leviathan, we where unable to destroy with what we had, we instead disabled every part of our sub that was making noise, sealed all the holes, and floated slowly out once it couldn't detect us anymore. 

Watching my captain succumb to a rabid infection that turned him into a monster, having locked himself in the brig to prevent it from spreading. 

Spent hours with a friend of mine who enjoys organisation, meticulously managing our supplies and equipment aboard the submarine. 

Falling into the abyss aboard a re-spawn shuttle, and abandoning it, having to swim up in pitch darkness, while the main submarine barely was close enough for us to pick eachother up on radio. The most despair and fear I have felt in a game, quickly became the biggest joy I have felt in a long time, when we saw the searchlights of our rig. "I SEE LIGHT! I SEE THE SUN!!!" 

This game is a challenge, a trial at times, but if you are with the right group, or are personally dedicated enough, you will prevail. 

You must be patient, you must be willing to lose everything if you fail, you must accept the cruelty of the world. This is the philosophy to enjoying Barotrauma.

Title: Barotrauma: Dive Deep, Face Terrors, and Unleash Creativity Under Pressure

Introduction:
Ahoy, brave submariners! If you've ever had a hankering for undersea adventure, alien encounters, and the relentless pressure of survival, Barotrauma is the game that plunges you into the murky depths while keeping you on the edge of your captain's chair. In this review, we're going to take a creative deep dive into the world of Barotrauma.

Graphics: 4/5 - "The Abyss Beckons, in Pixel Art Glory"
Barotrauma embraces the pixel art style with a twisted grin, making the depths of Europa (one of Jupiter's moons) feel both familiar and alien. The submarine interiors are claustrophobic, and the underwater landscapes are hauntingly beautiful. It's like watching a classic sci-fi film on an old CRT TV, and it fits the game's atmosphere perfectly.

Gameplay: 5/5 - "Waterlogged Chaos Wrapped in Strategy"
Barotrauma is like a chaotic symphony of survival and strategy. You're part of a crew aboard a submarine, tasked with completing missions while battling the elements, terrifying sea creatures, and your own sanity. The gameplay is as unpredictable as the depths you explore, making each mission an adrenaline-pumping thrill ride.

Exploration: 4/5 - "Europa's Dark Secrets Await"
Exploring Europa's ocean feels like venturing into the unknown. You'll uncover bizarre creatures, mysterious anomalies, and eerie underwater caverns. And remember, every dive could be your last. The thrill of discovering what lurks beneath keeps you coming back for more.

Multiplayer: 5/5 - "Crewmates or Chaos-Mates?"
Barotrauma truly shines when played with friends. Whether you're coordinating repairs, battling monsters, or plotting mutinies, the chaos of multiplayer is where the game's heart lies. Your friendships will be tested, and the hilarious mishaps will be endless. Just pray your engineer doesn't flood the ship again.

Creativity: 5/5 - "Submarine Building, Meet Madness"
The real magic of Barotrauma is in its ship-building system. You can create your own custom submarines, complete with reactors, weapons, and the all-important coffee maker. It's like a mad scientist's playground, and the results can be both awe-inspiring and utterly disastrous. Just remember, a bad design can lead to a watery grave.

Terror: 4/5 - "Fear Has Many Faces (and Tentacles)"
Barotrauma's alien sea creatures are genuinely terrifying. From grotesque humanoid monstrosities to tentacled horrors, you'll encounter nightmares from the deep. The tension as you battle these monstrosities is palpable, and the jump scares are both panic-inducing and hilarious.

Conclusion:
Barotrauma isn't just a game; it's an underwater carnival of chaos, creativity, and camaraderie. Dive into Europa's abyss, face your fears, and forge unforgettable memories with your friends. Just be prepared to shout "All hands on deck!" as you navigate the unpredictable waters of this deep-sea adventure. Barotrauma is a unique experience that'll leave you gasping for air and craving more aquatic madness. So, captain, are you ready to dive in?

The stories my crew and I take away from every session is always worth the experience, and I'll tell you one know.

• A simple mission to investigate beacons and mine some ore
• The beacons turn out to be zombies (AKA husks), which start ripping into the hull of the submarine.
• One gets jelly'd by one of the crew shooting a railgun into it. The rest are killed by smaller arms.
• We are done with missions, so we are heading to the next station to turn them in.
• We are attacked by a giant Mollusk, which proceeds to ram our ship.
• I am HURLED at mach-5 into the roof and halfway across the sub, suffering a broken neck in the process.
• I rush back to the controls and try to finish the battle, the medic examining me.
• The paralysis from the broken neck kicks in and I die of a severed spine.

Barotrauma is all about making good of a bad situation. One of the best "crew" type games and the modding community is very active.

1. Unparalleled Cooperative Gameplay: Barotrauma excels in cooperative multiplayer, allowing players to work together in a submarine crew to navigate treacherous underwater environments. The need for coordination and communication among crew members creates a strong sense of camaraderie and teamwork.

2. Immersive Underwater World: The game's dark and foreboding underwater world is richly detailed and atmospheric. It immerses players in a deep-sea setting filled with alien creatures, eerie ruins, and unpredictable environmental hazards.

3. Dynamic Emergent Gameplay: Barotrauma is designed to produce emergent gameplay experiences. The unpredictable nature of the ocean and the various challenges that arise during each mission ensure that no two playthroughs are the same. This keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting.

4. Diverse Roles and Responsibilities: Players can take on different roles within the submarine crew, including captain, engineer, medic, and more. Each role carries its own responsibilities, adding depth and complexity to the gameplay. Cooperation and coordination are essential to the crew's survival.

5. Realistic Simulation: The game features a detailed and realistic physics simulation, which means that every action has consequences. The submarine's systems can fail, breaches can occur, and fires can break out, leading to intense moments of crisis management.

6. Deep Customization: Barotrauma offers deep customization options for both characters and submarines. Players can personalize their avatars, craft their own submarines, and tailor their equipment and supplies to suit their preferred playstyle.

7. Complex Crafting System: The crafting system in Barotrauma is intricate and rewarding. Gathering resources and crafting items is an integral part of the survival experience, adding depth to the gameplay and a sense of accomplishment as you build and repair.

8. High-Stakes Survival: The game's harsh and unforgiving environment keeps the stakes high. Constantly monitoring oxygen levels, maintaining the integrity of the submarine, and fending off hostile creatures are just some of the challenges that make survival a thrilling and rewarding endeavor.

9. Active Developer Support: The developers of Barotrauma have shown a strong commitment to their player community, regularly releasing updates, addressing issues, and adding new content to keep the game evolving.

In conclusion, Barotrauma is a hidden gem in the realm of cooperative multiplayer gaming. Its immersive underwater world, complex gameplay mechanics, and focus on teamwork make it an exceptional experience for players looking for a unique and challenging adventure. Whether you're exploring the depths with friends or joining a crew of strangers, Barotrauma offers a deep and thrilling dive into the world of underwater survival. It's a must-play for those seeking an unforgettable cooperative gaming experience that tests both your wits and your nerves in the unforgiving abyss.

It's not just a submarine simulator, it's way more:

and calling it only a "submarine game" doesn't do it justice:

In the ingame world of Barotrauma, instead of human life, society & social unrest being on the surface, and you being isolated from it, in an ocean uninhabited by humans:

Barotrauma takes place on a moon of Jupiter where humans built underwater cities and outposts traveled between by submarine

It's a choose your own adventure game, in cities & outposts, as well as between them:

there's the Europa Coalition, undemocratic authorities ruling with an iron first,

Jovian Separatists, rebels that conduct guerrilla warfare against the oppressive Coalition authorities trying to crush them,

cultists that worship a horror-parasite,

clown

in a future where a large portion of humanity has migrated to underwater cities & outposts in the ocean on the moon of Jupiter Europa,

You control human characters that can rig explosives & use handheld guns for human player-on-human NPC ambushes, as well as warfare, inside underwater cities & outposts,

which are also part of a free-lance submarine crew,

there's authorities, rebels that wage guerrilla warfare, cultists that worship a horror-parasite, and a clown order,

and instead of being barred from joining any factions, or forced into one you don't like:

you get to choose who to side with, as you start as a freelance submarine crew

There is a story to enjoy as you do little missions across the planet. Although it seems pretty repetitive you can get caught off guard at any moment during your travels.
This game is WONDERFUL! You can control the submarine using a wireless gamepad and inject drugs into your partners!
Joined a server, got attacked and cuffed for no reason, then kicked. 10/10

Things I like:-
Multiplayer is very fun as it can lead to some great moments in the game.
Although not much lore, the lore the game DOES have is interesting
The game has a good challenge but isn't hard enough to no longer be fun.
The community is nice and understanding, they gave me 10 bucks just so my account can no longer be limited so that I could post steam workshop items related to this game.
The feeling of accomplishment you get when you reach the end of the level after almost dying feels really nice.
The game can very suddenly shift the tone from mundane to goofy, to horrifying to dreadful, and back to mundane all in the blink of an eye.
This game is extremely fun when you go into it blind and aren't aware of what kind of obstacles you'd face, although, I recommend you do at least learn somewhat about the controls and mechanics before you play.

Things I dislike:-
Not many weapon options, and the few weapons that the game DOES have can not be bought early in the game, making it harder to survive intruders.
A steep learning curve for those that know absolutely nothing bout the game
Griefers 
Stupid NPC Crewmates, being limited to assign a maximum of 3 tasks to them, and no quality of life commands such as "Don't be in this room" or "Don't shoot ice spires"
Although most of the talents are great, some feel very mundane.
Although all of the classes are great, I feel like Assistants and Captains are slightly left out, Assistants have a lot of talents related to their own death which can feel unnecessary at times, and although the captain has a lot of powerful buffs for the crew, he lacks a powerful craftable item for himself to make himself feel like a god, the handcannon he can make feels underwhelming, whereas other classes get stuff such as mechs, drones, giant raptor pets, drugs, etc.
The stations although interesting at first, get mundane rather fast, they don't FEEL like an actual place where you'd expect someone to live their entire life, it would be cool to have other things to do at a station besides just buying stuff and getting a quest.
No "Press R to reload" and other convenient things most games have.

Overall, I love a lot of things about this game, but also hate a lot too. I very much enjoy playing this game but get frustrated about the minor things I wished this game could change. This game still has some ways to go before I can think of it as a fully finished game.

I highly recommend you try it out (Oh, and here's a tip, if you can't afford the game, just go and download a VPN and pretend to be in a 3rd world country, you'd be able to get the game for a cheaper price, I live in Pakistan and got the game for like 7 bucks at 50% off. If you aren't sure whether or not this game is for you, do what I did, pirate the game, try it out, and then buy it if you come to enjoy it.)

titan submersible
The Titan Sub POV

To be frank, did the developers ever stop and think how the game mechanics could actually be fun?

- A submarine is a giant collection of Tamagotchis that constantly need feeding (= repairs). Running through the sub, applying your wrench here, turning the screwdriver there, replacing yet another fuel rod in the matter of minutes, putting out random fires, while nothing of significance happens is fun how exactly? As a workaround you can let a bot do these tasks - which is just an elaborate way to turn them off.
- Hulls are apparently made from cardboard that break when a goldfish licks the paint. So you run to the nearest breach to weld it shut. Which you don't finish, because pretty much everything is almost insta-kill, be it water pressure, alien creatures, etc.
- "Respawning" doesn't place you back in the submarine, but in a shuttle that first needs to find the sub, then dock. Guys, seriously, dying is frustrating enough. Why are you making it so hard to get back into action (the fun part)? But that's not even the worst thing, which is...
- Default respawn time of five minutes, really? "Pointless waiting - the game". Not fun.
- All this happened on the easiest difficulty, which should be a walk in the park and motivate me to try the harder settings, but really didn't.

All in all, this was a rather infuriating experience and I applied for a refund.

As a barotrauma veteran, I absolutely recommend this.
YOU will know what joy is after repairing a submarine from a complete asshole, and then you will know what anger is when it immediately sinks again.
YOU will hate the captain when he, for fun, sits behind the turret and shoots at Moloch childrens.
YOU will scream in pain when you take everything you need to the ruins, and then inside the ruins you understand what you forgot the oxygen tanks.
YOU will fucking hate mud raptors because they specifically gnaw on hatches and doors.
YOU will hate husks in the beginning, and after 50 hours of play you will intentionally become infected with them.
YOU will curse tiger sharks for eating your submarine in a couple of seconds, and your crew in less than a second.
YOU will pray to God that you will never encounter worm in your life.
YOU will understand what it means to "be fucked by the thalamus." Literally.
YOU will curse that dev who invented giant spineling.

And you will love all of this in your memory, that adventures, that emotions, crew members... it's worth it.

I'd highly recommend the tutorial just to get the basic idea of what's going on with all the roles, but a LOT of stuff is going to be learned as you play. You can swap between crew members, but each profession has associated skills that make it preferable to have someone specific to the role instead of an all-rounder (though they're still very nice to have). If a crew member dies, they're gone for good, though, and some enemies are very unforgiving (looking at you Latcher), so be VERY thoughtful on your choices; with enough coordination and pre-planning you can get through even the worst of it with few to no casualties. Also, there's NO SHAME in running from things, some things are better left alone, and it's DEFINITELY better to live to fight another day. All said, I'd highly recommend the game, I'm addicted!

Honestly, I was enjoying the game, I think it could be very good. But the devs seem dead set on changing things in worse directions rather than fixing bugs (like my achievements not getting proc'd) and adding new content, they want to artificially inflate the difficulty by retroactively adding false difficulty. Have you earned a lot of supplies? Decrease storage. Benefiting from a perk they deem too strong? Removed, no attempt to balance.

The game itself is janky and pretty boring for 70% of gameplay, the community has some good folks but plenty of people play the game just unwire your sub and leave. The game's gameplay is mainly a number check: Do you have the resources to survive an attack? Or the resources to defeat a monster? If yes, you win. If no, run or die. It's not particularly exciting after you've done it 100 times, after you've seen all the content the game offers, and the devs don't add new content. 1.0 was the biggest release ever, and yet the somehow didn't manage to add a single new monster that wasn't tied to endgame.

This game isn't worth $35, go play space station 13, it's free and somehow LESS janky and has a great community.

I am a huge fan of this game. I've played since real early access with a lot of my friends and the devs have continued to deliver functional and fun content. I'll compile some opinions below. 

TL;DR: Very active modding community. Every class and play-style has something to offer. Kind devs that are willing to take feedback from players. Great environment and sound design. 

Pros

-Dark and aesthetic environment. Games like Barotrauma really need an immersive environment to pull in players. And Barotrauma executes it very very well. The depths of Europa feel like a bleak abyss. The sound design is very powerful, the creaking of the ship and screeches of the local wildlife feel very real.

-Engaging gameplay that keeps you on your toes. Every role has something to offer in Barotrauma, as captain you have to manage driving the ship and keeping your crew in order, Security officer works of firing guns and keeping the "wildlife" outside. Barotrauma is a rare game that can keep you entertained no matter what class you pick. No one class feels less important than the next.

-The modding support. This is a HUGE plus. Barotrauma has a very friendly, and very active modding community. This game is made for modding. And the community does so. Which helps the game feel fresh every playthrough. Main mods I would recommend are: Neurotrauma, Hazardous Reactors, and Dynamic Europa. 

-Active online community. If you don't enjoy playing solo there is a very active community of Captains willing you let you join their play through. The discord has plenty of kind individuals waiting for others to join. 

Cons

-Barotrauma made some questionable decisions on the physics of your character, with them kind of wriggling and flying around due to your legs hardly feeling attached to your body. This is funny to begin with, but can quickly become a nuisance. It's not that big of a deal, but can be frustrating when you're getting stuck in door ways after being killed by an abyssal creature and getting sent back to the station. 

-Linear progression. This isn't necessarily a con as some games can benefit from linear progression due to the fact that it gives you a clear goal. But Barotrauma does have a pretty linear progression without you really knowing what your end goal is. The map is pretty straight forward and you don't really know where you're going. 

In conclusion: Barotrauma is one of my favorite games. It feels fresh with modding support and is constantly being updated by devs that listen to the community. It can be hard to enjoy the game solo and it definitely has it's flaws. But is a gem amongst some pretty bad games that have been realsed within the last few years.

It is a dying game, the devs have made quite a few changes that were opposed by the players, and, like many other games, it is greatly overpriced now. 
If you buy this game off-sale, you are paying $35/€35/£30 for a game that has about 5-8 non-campaign servers at a time, and something like 10 campaign servers. 
While I can't speak for the campaign servers, since I don't tend to play on them since I consider it a commitment, I can speak on the non-campaign ones. About half of the non-campaign servers suffer from shitty hosts and admins that abuse their powers at the expense of the players.
For the ones that don't suffer from admin abuse, it's about a 50/50 whether your experience is ruined by reactor griefers, shitsec, or medics that just poison/OD everyone. That leaves about 1-2 non-campaign servers at any given time that will actually be fun for a decent person to play.
But of course, you can just play on your own. Except due to limitations of the bots (I think the devs have tried their best to make them better, but they still struggle alot) singleplayer campaign can be a living hell. 
If you want to play with friends, that's another $35/€35/£30 for each of them.

Overall, as much as I love this game and would love to see more people join, I can't honestly recommend people to buy it.

This game needs more automation options for your crew, like crafting, item dumping or decomposing, etc. But it is still a great (although a bit painful) single-player game experience as is. If you have friends, I heard playing it co-op is even better.

Personally, I quite like this game. I like what it offers, the features it has, the adventures you can have. The different kinds of missions, certain quest lines, enemies, locations, submarines, submarine editor - what this game offers is really fun. Not to even mention the mods people come up with.

However that there are some things that are just [b] really [/b] annoying, especially when you play by yourself or with not very cooperative players.

1. If you don't have a deconstructor and fabrication bench on your ship, and have them right where the shop crates spawn, it's extremely annoying and just time-wasting to either get rid of empty shop crates that spawned with each purchase you make or refill/deconstruct empty ammo boxes.
If you have 3-4 human players and they are willing to help you, it's less of a problem, since one crate per player, carrying it to the deconstructor or fabricator to destroy or refill it. But it's still a chore that you all have to do, forcing you to not "play the game", but carry stuff around after each and every quest, all the way troughout the entire game. Is there really no better way to code it? Not to mention, what if they are not willing to help, or you play by yourself? You have to take each and every crate all by yourself, [b] one crate at a time [/b], pick one crate, go out to either toss it into the ocean or climb all the way up to the outpost deconstructor to get rid of it, and repeat it for every single crate, every single purchase you ever make, and every single ammo box that gets emptied. It's not only time wasting, it's a freaking psychological torture.


2. There are serious performance issues. My current PC should definitely be more than enough to handle this game with no problems, and yet I'm having serious FPS drops, stutters, even freezes. Even with settings set low.


3. Bots are so freaking annoying on multiple levels.

-One, they are talking just so much about nothing important, and there's no option in the menu to change the frequency of their babbling, to decrease it or turn it off entirely. You want them to only alert you about an enemy, leak somewhere, or broken device? No, you can't, enjoy the messages popping up on top of messages, repeating themselves how X doesn't like crawlers, Y is afraid of husks, or Z thinks one kilo of steel is heavier than one kilo of feathers. So annoying!

-Not to mention that every time there's a leak, they put on the diving suit on... and whenever "it's no longer needed", they don't put it back, no, they toss it onto the floor, right where they were. At least there is an option to tell one of the bots to do "maintenence - clean up", but 1. when you don't know about it, have yet to discover it, it can be really rage-enducing and 2. When you have a pet and toss food onto the ground for it, even if it starts eating, the crewmate will take it out of it's mouth and put it into the locker - make it starve! So you either have to A) juggle the tasks every time you want to feed the pet(and they sometimes still do 'cleaning task' anyways, even when not asked to do so, taking things into lockers that you want to be on the ground!) B) Forbid a certain door from being opened, trying to prevent bots from entering a room trough it, so you put pets in there and throw food onto the ground there. But 1. they will still try to access the room if the door is ever opened, so you have to hurry every time you want to put food down, open and close the door with haste. 2. If there is a leak in that room in particular, you again have to juggle commands, either go there yourself to fix the leak or unforbid the door, and as soon as you open(or unforbid) the door the flowing water will push the pets out, requiring you to "put them back" there every single time there's a leak.

-Did I mentioned that every time you 1. Load the game 2. enter the outpost 3. leave the outpost. The locations of pets change? So every time either of those events happen, you have to manually pick a pet, carry it, and put there into that pet/feeding room, lock there, and hope there won't be leaks/breaches there...

Also, I tried to forbid certain item, but even if I do, bots pick it up and put into lockers anyways. Epic.

So much playing around with commands just to prevent bots from being an absolute nuisance instead of help!


4. If there is more than one cabinet linked to a fabricator/deconstructor, the positions of the inventories are all over the place. Even if you reposition the inventory windows to where you want them and then click the option to "lock" them there, it still changes!


5. Want to have a fruit garden in one of the rooms? Make some extra money on the side, or perhaps make food for your pets instead of needing to buy it one fruit at a time? You can, with planting pots, but then what happens? Regular blazing inferno appears! Because for some reason developers thought it would be fun feature to code in that randomly some of the fruits dropping are freaking molotov cocktails. Epic. 
Maybe it's up to a dispute, but to me, it's not a fun challenge, but a total nuisance that just discourages you from using that feature. If it wasn't enough that you need to water each plant, and if the water meter goes down to 0 the plant imminently dies, and it takes forever to uproot and replant it.

Seriously I like the game, the adventure it offers, but some things are just a freaking torture.

It's the perfect game for you and your pals to team up and have a blast together.

Picture this: you and your crew can take on different roles like a badass Medical Doctor, a hardcore Security Officer, or even the almighty Captain. Each role brings its own unique flavor to the gameplay, and trust me, playing the doctor is epic! You'll be the hero, saving your buddies from the jaws of death when they mess up. Talk about a life-or-death adrenaline rush!

But that's not all. Barotrauma hooks you with its variety of missions. You'll be exploring creepy underwater caves, going on intense research expeditions, and even engaging in epic battles. The missions keep coming, and you'll never run out of challenges to conquer. It's the kind of game that sucks you in and refuses to let go.

Now, if you think the vanilla version of the game gets a bit dull after a while, fear not! Barotrauma is a goldmine for mods. You want more missions? Done. Fancy some wicked weapons or mind-boggling sea creatures? You got it! Mods take the game to a whole new level, keeping things fresh and exciting.

Oh, and here's the cherry on top: you can build your own freakin' submarine! How cool is that? Barotrauma lets you unleash your creativity and design a sub that suits your style. From the structure to the interior layout, it's all up to you. It's like playing with Legos!

So, gather your squad, gear up, and get ready for the adventure of a lifetime in the treacherous depths of Barotrauma. With its awesome multiplayer dynamics, thrilling missions, modding madness, and the chance to create your own sub. Get ready to laugh, scream, and cheer as you and your friends conquer the underwater world together. Let the madness begin!
great game
good

Ever since I got my hands on this game in 2021, it's been an absolute blast. The replayability factor is through the roof, thanks to a wide array of mods that cater to different playstyles. Whether you're into visual enhancements or gameplay tweaks, there's something for everyone.

The developers deserve a special mention for their commitment to the community. Regular free content updates keep the game evolving, ensuring that it never grows stale. It's a refreshing approach that sets this game apart from others in the market.

But be warned, this game is not for the faint of heart. The challenge is real, and it demands strategic thinking and adaptability. Each level presents unique obstacles, making every victory feel earned and satisfying.

I must confess that I haven't explored the multiplayer aspect, but the single-player campaign alone has been a rewarding investment. Intricately designed levels, compelling storytelling, and immersive gameplay fully justify the money spent.

Whether you're a seasoned gamer looking for your next challenge or someone seeking an engaging story, this game has something to offer. Trust me, give it a try, and you'll understand why it's become a favorite of mine.
