This is one of the most unique games ive played in a long time. It's a perfect mixture of role playing, adventure, survival, horror, simulation, management, and action. So far i have only played single-player but its been an awesome experience. While your AI crewmates arent the brightest crayons in the box, they are more than adequate for doing what you need them to do once you learn how to command them properly. 

The atmosphere of this game is claustrophobic, terrifying, and at times comically absurd (in a good way). It really makes you feel like you are the captain of a submarine on a strange and dangerous alien world. I cant think of another game like it. The gameplay videoss on youtube dont really do the game justice. If your on the fence about buying this game (i had it on my wish list for over a year) just buy it, i promise you wont regret it.

Class-Based submarine crisis management.
This game has managed to scratch my itches for a high-intensity team-oriented game that's not a total balance nightmare, a randomly generated map to keep me slightly more on my toes, rpg-like skill trees, and a slight bit of difficulty to keep me interested and satisfied.

Every class can technically do everything, and the only REQUIRED class is the captain; every other class beyond excels at their main stat in the early-mid game, but the skill tree system gives a class unique buffs and crafting recipes that tend to come in handy later down the road. 

-Captain: Efficient Driving, submarine and crew-wide bonuses, and crisis management buffs.
-Security: Submarine gun buffs, Personal Weapon buffs, and Combat toughness. Hoorah.
-Medic: Chemical crafting and (I swear to god I have 2 full syringes of cyanide loaded in this gun) application, Saving lives, and genetically modifying your crew.
-Engineer: Electrical repair, submarine fuel/power management, and... nuclear... applications.
-Mechanic: Mechanical and hull repair, Mass production, mining, and effective breaching capabilities.
-Assistant: The deaths of assistants do not count. Honk Honk.
Having played We Need to Go Deeper, This War of Mine, and Plasma Burst 2(flash), this game is like my favorite elements of all those games combined.

Barotrauma - a game with two extremes
Disclaimer this is a personal view from my time playing the game.

Barotrauma from an idea standpoint should be a game which makes being on a sub on alien world with a number of people (Or bots) one of the most unique experiences in gaming. From having different classes which decides what roles on a sub each person is good at, to building your own sub and a campaign which allows u to play it your own way.

Sadly Barotrauma is never that game for too long. So lets get on with the main parts:

The bugs:
This is one of the biggest problems this game suffers, its so bad that it took me a whole year of getting fed up of the bugs to come back to finish the campaign. Now some bugs aren't so bad like the random disconnects which happens without any reason behind them, to the AI of both monsters and bots just breaking at times. I had one time a monster fully just standstill and do nothing on the sub but as soon as we move the sub it started to move again. Another time is a crew bot deciding randomly to not shoot the ship guns but shoot it's gun at me out of the blue. Note i was just walking into the room when that happen and this was single player.
But the bugs get worse like not letting u dock randomly which requires u to restart the whole round which can be up to a hour of game play wasted to random parts of the subs just stop working again without reasons as i have even check the subs in editor to find nothing wrong with them and at times they just start working again.

The mods:
I normally have a view which is if a mod is need to make a game playable.... something is wrong with your game. Now thankfully Barotrauma doesn't have that problem but has another... the lack of content mainly online. See while the game does give you roles/classes well there really isn't much reason to stick to what jobs those roles are meant to do. Even the items you get in-game are kind of basic which honest isn't a bad thing but with how long this game been out and developed feels its lacks stuff. So the answer is mods which honest Barotrauma has a good number of mods which really make the game play better. However when you start using more than one mod that's when you really playing a dice game with wondering if the game isn't going to crash or break a save or even a sub. Why bring this up well notice i say more than one mod, well even if say u use 2 mods with don't even mess with the same stuff, sometimes they end up breaking each other sometimes out of the blue and then work fine later on. Tho i do recommend to use mods if you do feel the game is lacking stuff as even with those faults the do make a difference.

The Subs and the Editor:
You know when i think of an in game editor, i normally think they would make it so anyone could pick it up and make a sub.
What you find instead is an complex editor which fails to teach you how to use it and what each thing does, has settings on items which feels like you have to write your own code just to add a simple id to a card. And the wiring... oh my the wiring... while as an idea is sounds interesting. In game how ever it becomes this nightmare as one missing wire can at times break a whole sub. Honest the editor should not be this complex and made simpler for newer players to learn instead of having to look up a number of guides written by other players, not the devs to even understand the basics.

The Performance
Now i not going to say i have a high end PC but if i can a number of games at high graphics and frame rate at times then i should be able to play this game easy. Sadly Barotrauma suffers from unable to access more than 2 cores at any one time which really hurts it to how un-optimize the game is. Want to play with a number of people well hope u don't have more than 5k items or the sub just lags and yes its easy after a few hours to get to 5k items as every bullet, mat, wire, even doors are class as items and u need a size able sub for more than 6 players. Even monsters on the higher difficulties spawn at high rate which lags the game. Even worse i don't think no matter what sub i been on i never had a lag free mission with another sub i need to kill for a mission.

The Online:
The online is a mix bag, on one hand it is the best way to play the game, on the other hand is also the worse. Let me explain, you could be in a lobby with a good crew who all having fun and progressing the game. All that can change as soon as someone joins and just trolls which it turns causes others to leave. The next problem comes to finding a committed crew to play with as its a hit or miss. i been lucky that i find a crew when i beat the game finally last month but that took near a month before hand to even find those people down to time zones and how busy people are. Even then some trolls was able to slip into our private game under the idea they wasn't which shows its hard to trust people playing the game.
The last problem with the online is how bad the server log is. Back to the wires, if someone disconnects a wire on the sub in game, then the log only tells u a wire has been disconnected. Doesn't tell you where and which wire was disconnect. This makes running a public server a pain as u spend mins at a time trying to find which wire was disconnected.

Art/sound:
This is one part i feel Barotrauma does well, the way the sounds u hear on the sub as you walk around or even when the sub moving makes you feel like you only have a wall of metal to protect you from the horrors in the water. The way the monsters all look makes it easy for you to tell what they are and even the sounds they make are different from each other which is a nice touch. Character design is nice and doesn't feel out of place, personally i do use an anime mod for human characters but that's a personal taste, even then tho i do feel the base game's designs aren't bad.

Conclusion:
Barotrauma is a game which has been worked on for many years, by a team of devs which have done their best to bring this game to life with all the ideas i stated at the start of this review. Sadly over time i feel somewhere went wrong and the game just fails to live up to those ideas. The performance problems is the big killer as depending on your PC your mileage may vary but for a experience to have with a number of people all on a sub, not many games can do that.

With that i don't recommend the game if you expecting to play this game with randoms and by yourself at this time, but if you have or find a number of people to play it with then i would recommend it even with all its problems and to pick it up on a sale as right now i don't feel its worth the £30 asking price at this time.

This game.
When you play it, you might think that the waiting time for setting up the actual playtime is a flaw.
Even if it is, the game weaponizes it. It makes you want to play.

You start the game. You load into a lobby. You wait for everyone to get done at station one.
And the amount of time between events, whether that be mission objectives, or fights, or whatever else, is PERFECT. It's not too long to make the game boring, but it's JUST long enough that you start getting settled in to your task. The moment you forget about being vigilant, THAT is when the eldritch horror starts attacking. That moment, when everyone is minding their business, and the captain has forgotten to check sonar, and the entire sub SHAKES. And everyone goes unconscious for a moment. That moment is the most masterfully created moment of this game. Because right after that, when everyone wakes up and hears the water pouring in, EVERYONE gets to work. With multiplayer games like this, you sometimes run into troubles with a team that doesn't want to work. But because of the perfect waiting period, everyone wants to do something, and it feels exhilarating watching everyone get to the task to repairing the ship. Watching and helping the gunners fend off the monsters. Rescuing a diver who got paralyzed by the thalamus. Even being dead, the scene of whatever crew left trying desperately to repair the sub and fend off the invaders, in red, dim lighting after the reactor shuts down, is impeccable.
And then the mods.
Hazardous reactors, for if you want the engineer to never leave the reactor room lest the entire sub get covered in radiation (they really need to design better reactors for these things), Neurotrauma, where the medic singlehandedly heals the entire team that are all dying from fractured bones and internal bleeding and asphyxiation and so much more, and Barotraumatic, for when base game isn't hard enough and you want MORE MONSTERS. This game. This game is a masterpiece.
Whenever it's on sale, get you and at least like four other friends to grab it and play together. You'll have a hell of a time.
Good for playing with friends. High potentional and already playable.

The appeal for this game for me is that you never know when shit is going to hit the fan. One mission it's all peaceful with only a few enemies to deal with and in another something goes wrong and everyone is running around like chickens with their heads cut off screaming over comms and that uncertainty of what's going to happen in the next mission is what drives the game. I've had missions that I thought would be hard but we got through it unscathed and missions we thought would be chill and we ended up not accounting for something and now half the crew is husk infected with muraptors and crawlers running around the submarine. 

Truly this is the best morphine injection simulator you can get on steam.

The game is a janky mess of movement, but imo that only adds to the charm.
I don't like the solo play, but this is an absolutely AMAZING game to play with friends. Better than Deeprock Galactic, better than literally any sims or city builder, it's just an absolute GEM for team play.

That's the good, and truth be told, it's EXCEPTIONALLY good.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Now for the bad.
It's not many issues right now (just some inventory management easily fixed with mods), and...well one is critical.
They're one currently-an-unstable-build (that's not far from becoming the latest update) away from making the game entirely unplayable.

LONG read below, TLDR on it: Carrying enough oxygen to even play (in a game about constantly sailing around and leaving your sub in a dive suit) is about to become so impractical that the game's effectively going to be unplayable.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Long story long:

I'm particularly not fond of quite a few ""balance"" choices the devs make.
This isn't supposed to be dark souls, and I damned well do NOT want to spend 1.25hrs moving railgun ammo 1 bullet at a time into the ship from a enemy ships (seriously, that's not a hypothetical, we literally spent over an hour and 15 minutes doing that shit!) because the ammo is fairly expensive and hard to come by so you have to stock up.

Not having these things stack in containers or some form of transport is downright criminal.
Oh, and now they want to make the game unplayable!
The game's main grind involves about 30-45min in an average run submerged at several thousand feet under the water in a suit. So right now as of typing this, oxygen tanks stack up to 8.
...
Now. They. Want. To. Remove. Stacking!

At 5min 33s in each tank, with one stack of 8 plus the tank in your suit, you can currently spend 49m57s under water before needing to be back in breathable atmosphere or find somewhere to fill your tanks.

But your inventory space is EXTREMELY limited.
9 hotbar slots (at LEAST half of which will be taken up with required tools, weapons, ammo, and meds) along with an 8 slot toolbelt (for air tanks and a few spare spots to put the precious loot you just grinded half an hour to HOURS to get).
And carrying all that is a requirement, unless you want to die and lose +12hrs of gameplay worth of skills (-30% to all your skill levels is an insane penalty when it takes about an hour to grind 10 skill levels, in a game where you can hit a cap of 100 per skill and there's 5 skills).
Not to mention potentially losing nigh-irreplaceable equipment that can only be found via extreme 1% RNG chance after fighting your way through a wrecked sub you found on the ocean floor near crush depth, which is crawling with infected bodies and various creatures.

So carrying at LEAST 4 tanks per stack is an ABSOLUTE must for the game to be remotely playable or enjoyable.
What LSD-laced GMO peyote-on-steroids stuff they're smoking for this to seem remotely intelligent, I do not know.
I want the number to their dealer, because whatever he's selling these devs is apparently coming from some higher dimension or astral plane!

And ironically, being higher than is physically possible in our limited 3 Dimensional space is what's apparently required to actually enjoy the game with the ""balance"" changes they're making.

An incredible game to play with friends. You play as a bunch of fools trying to make a living in the colonized depths of a lovely moon, Europa. You traverse its waters with a submarine which consists of many individual parts with their own functionality. There is a good variety of submarines in the game, and you can even make your own from scratch, or download one from the workshop. Depending on your familiarity with the game, your sub can feel like a coffin or a haven. There are riches to be found, pirates to be killed, and missions to be completed. Oh, and look out for the... inhabitants of the moon. they are usually not friendly, and they appear to like how you taste quite a lot.

This Submarine simulator has given me 21.7 hours of memories. These are some of the most fun, painful, heart wrenching and down right autistic memories I have...

My group consists of 4 members with the occasional 5th (very rare) we assume the exact same roles every game. 

-One heroic and bold captain (he doesn't reward us help us or do anything around the ship other than bark orders)
-One brain dead security officer (He often gets drunk then calls everyone racial slurs, hand cuffs himself and doesn't do anything but sit by the guns AFK)
-One Toxic Engineer (When you are not paying attention he will stab you with morphine and give you an opiate addiction, he will also feed you husk eggs when you are not paying attention which turns our dear security guard into a zombie. He will also hatch a giant alien egg aboard the ship attacking the entire crew, he will also chase and threaten you with a bomb)
-One junkie Mechanic (Is almost always addicted to opiates, gets electrocuted very often and never crafts anything which is his job)

This crew consists of some of the finest Autism god has graced this earth with... now while you may be thinking this crew sounds like a shit show, you are absolutely right... but occasionally the story changes.. Our captain picks up a wrench and gets to work... Our security officer braves the darkest depths of the ocean floor... Our engineer puts out a fire he started... Our mechanic pulls his head out of his ass and starts crafting... 

With our Brave captain keeping us focused on the mission at hand...with our Security officer fending off the dangers of the oceans depths... and with our mechanic and engineer keeping us afloat... we get the job done... one mission at a time.

Very based game. Has combat system, exploration system, medicine system, chemistry system (4x cyanide>bobbit worm), and nuclear weapons. Has an electrical engineering/wiring system that can be compared to minecraft in that it is far more applicable than redstone in game, but unlike its counterpart is not strictly necessary to play; it only improves quality of life (sans some positioning wizardry - automated cannons), although it improves it in a more impactful way than redstone, so I would definitely take some time learning about wiring components. NPC system is also really good, NPCs are good at what they do. I heard there used to be bugs for this but I don't really see any, besides NPCs being unwilling to turn off the reactor themselves. Overall, this is a very good game, and well worth the price. I heard it often compared to ss13, and although I have never played the game myself, I have seen some video and while the games are similar, I think Barotrauma expands on ss13 and makes it its own, better than I think the original did.

My previous review of this game was really short and just basic, so im going to change it.

Right off the bat this is the best nieche game i've played, the game knows what it is and doesn't have mechanics that don't fit.

The presentation is beautiful, this the best looking 2d game i've seen, it has a style that looks amazing.

The mechanics and CO-OP features are really well made, YOU HAVE TO cooperate to survive and you can't be a one man army, truth be told the guns and melee weapons are your last resort options, they aren't good, but that fits.

The atmosphere is just perfect, the story is simple on paper but the deeper you go the crazier it gets, and in a good way, the game makes you feel like a nobody, like you can die like everyone else, you're not the center of the universe.

The music is simple, but executed to perfection.

In-game lore is interesting, and the random encounters/quests were really good

Sound design is great in some places, while in others it's passable at worst.

Overall a 10/10, best experienced with friends

Really Really fun game

Two things may be a little off-putting at first: it's a side scroller, and it's got more than one good learning curve.
Once you accept those as integral parts of the game, you'll find that Barotrauma is insanely good.

It runs well. the only issue ive had is some slight desync in multiplayer, but that isn't common enough to be an issue.

One of my favorite parts of Barotrauma is the mechanical depth. Each of the six jobs on the sub can be learned to proficiency reasonably easily. OR you can take the time to master the job and do crazy stuff. For example, Engineering isn't that hard to learn: Run the reactor, make sure the electrical systems run well, craft your materials to save money, etc. OR you can rewire the entire sub, push the reactor beyond what it should be able to do while managing the risks, build cool gadgets and traps, and learn to do a bunch of crazy stuff in the submarine editor (i saw a vid of a guy today creating his own guided nuclear torpedo). Another example is the medic. You could learn to heal, manage medicine, and become your crew's savior, OR you could craft poisons against human or animal enemies and turn your crew into coked up super-heros (even if you make them part-alien and addicted to meth lol). All of the jobs have depth like this, even the assistant (You should definitely become a clown sometime. when done well, it's a blast). This game has phenomenal depth of features.

The game's got weird lore, a wicked cool submarine editor to make subs to use anywhere in the game, and integrated mod support! The mods are wonderful too!

Also, you maybe wouldn't expect a side-scroller to be horror, but Barotrauma delivers. You gotta experience that lol. great solo or coop, but especially coop with some chill people.

This is a great game that captures most aspects possible for a video game. Want an adventure with a large map to explore, that is here, want combat, that is here, want aliens, that is here, want electrical engeneering aspects, that too you can find here.

A lot of my qualms about this game (particularly its difficulty with modding) have been since ironed out by the devs and modmakers as far as I can determine, so I can safely go back to recommending it once more.  I play Barotraumatic Explorer with all creature packs included in particular, so the "what the hell is that?" factor is heightened with no centralized wiki-page to know quite what we're dealing with apart from experience teaching us, combined with the increased potential human mortality of Neurotrauma.

Barotrauma is a great game and there's nothing else quite like it out there.  Perhaps the few other submarine-centric games would count, such as perhaps U-BOAT, but actual submarine simulators don't catch the abyssal terror of not knowing what's clawing into your hull from the outside.  Maybe Iron Lung comes to mind, but even then, there's a distinct degree of helplessness present with that title.

Instead, Barotrauma is about a dysfunctional crew of submariners dealing with the day-to-day hostility of the fictional environmental hazards of Jupiter's moon, Europa; whether it just be the local wildlife of varying degrees of abyssal horrors and eldritch monstrosities, a dangerous parasite that nurtures itself within one's own skeletal system, ancient ruins from an alien civilization long gone, yet another parasite that has somehow managed to cross the barrier from organics to inorganic matter by commandeering wrecked submarines, the threat that other humans pose whether it be the political climate or various cults or just plain old piracy, or even just the planet itself via the intense depth pressure of the waters surrounding you or your submarine's hull.  Barotrauma wants to kill you at any opportune moment, and it's amazing how quickly the tone changes from you goofing around with your shipmates to everything going utterly and horrifically wrong.



It's a great game, would let the captain drive into an old forgotten naval mine again, rupturing the hull and snapping my neck against the wall flying away from the blast, thus rendering the only medical doctor aboard the submarine a vegetable whilst the rest of the crew screams in a frenzied panic.

Absolutely give the modding community a try as well.  Between the EK collection, Barodrama, Enhanced Armaments, Real Sonar, the myriad of custom subs, and other assorted goodies, they pump out a lot of great stuff.

Barotrauma has captivated me in a way that few other games have. I'm awarding it a perfect score, 10/10, as it ranks among my all-time favourites.

One of the brilliant aspects of this game is the subtlety of its story. It's not glaringly obvious, or in-your-face like some other games, but more of a nuanced, lurking presence. It's not intrusive, so players who prefer straightforward gameplay can do just that. However, if you crave a narrative, it's there, quietly waiting for you to piece it together. This delicate balance is so rewarding, as the game caters to various playing styles.

The crafting system in Barotrauma is both extensive and rewarding. It gives you a sense of being a real mechanic aboard a submarine, learning what each item is made of and what needs to be broken down. This attention to detail and the immersive mechanics heightens the overall gameplay experience.

Now, onto my favourite part - the role system. It has to be one of the most refined and immersive systems I have ever encountered. I've come to realise that letting the game assign me a role has been the best way to play. After trying out every role, I can now switch between different roles with ease, leading to a more comprehensive gameplay experience. This flexibility ensures that the game never feels limited; it keeps expanding in possibilities the more you play.

To sum up, Barotrauma is a dynamic, immersive and intricately detailed game that challenges and rewards in equal measure. It doesn't just allow you to play a role; it lets you live it. A definite must-play for any fan of submarine survival and role-playing games.

Oh Barotrauma... I've played around 60+ hours of this game and I still get surprised of what is possible here in the depths of Europa.

You can hire your own crew, control them as you want, play them if you want. The game is challenging and requires a dedicated mind to play through the hardest and most difficult situations where you are sinking to the bottom, being eaten alive, being shot at, suffocating, burning alive, being crushed by the immense pressures and survive...

There is so much to discover in this games, cults, revolutions, pirates, amazing biomes, caves, new outposts and new crew. You can go ahead and start killing guards at a facility, poison or infect your own crew and others. 

There's a lot more that I don't yet know about so the good thing is to play more, enjoy the relaxing moments until BOOM! Your submarine is hit, you are thrown to the ground and nearly knocked out, your sub's hull is damaged and water is pouring in fast, your crew is quick to react but what will you do to survive?

All and all this game is absolutely worth the full price, a refreshing new gaming experience even for seasoned gamers. So much to do, so much to explore... 10/10

Barotrauma, oh boy, where do I start? This game is an absolute masterpiece that has left me addicted and on the edge of my seat! Dive into the eerie depths of an alien ocean aboard a submarine and prepare for an adventure like no other!

The attention to detail in Barotrauma is astounding. The submarine mechanics are so realistic that you'll feel like a seasoned captain navigating through treacherous waters. The constant danger posed by hostile creatures and environmental hazards adds a rush of adrenaline to every moment. The sense of teamwork required in multiplayer is unparalleled. Get your friends together, and you'll be shouting orders and scrambling to survive in no time.

The game's difficulty is challenging, but that only makes every victory and narrow escape all the more satisfying. The sheer unpredictability of what you'll encounter keeps you coming back for more, and the modding support means there's no shortage of new content to explore.

In short, Barotrauma is a must-play for anyone seeking a gripping and immersive gaming experience. It's a game that will keep you hooked for hours on end, and you'll find yourself completely immersed in its captivating world. Grab your diving suit, assemble your crew, and dive into the adventure of a lifetime!

Played this with the same crew since long before the game was on Steam, since the very early builds when it was still called Subsurface. Each update we came back and watched the game develop into something more complete. With the full release of the game we started a campaign in earnest. It was tough to schedule time to play between all of us, but bit by bit we continued.

4 months later we finally completed the campaign to complete our nearly decade-long journey on Barotrauma. There is jank but some of it you learn to deal with and the rest is part of the fun. For a sandbox game, Barotrauma regularly creates the most interesting moments you can have in a videogame. You live with your mistakes. Five of your crewmembers died on a mission and you're the last survivor and you manage a long struggle to pull through. The game is filled with these sorts of moments. Truly a game to remember.
Super fun and radical :)

Overall an extremely fun game to play with friends. Highly recommend picking this up if you have at least one friend commit to play through the campaign with you.

The game does an amazing job immersing you in a dark, alien ocean atmosphere with a gritty, steampunk/futurepunk theme. There are a multitude of mostly well balanced gameplay mechanics that add a surprising amount of depth. Focusing on survival and strategy is rewarded, if not required. Every decision feels important. Comebacks are very satisfying - and crises will get your heart racing.

Nothing beats the chaos experience of your friends all yelling over the radio with water pouring into your Barsuk, sinking into the abyss and being boarded by a half dozen tiger threshers. And that's really a fairly "normal" crisis.

I do wish the price was a bit lower - the $35 tag after full release makes it challenging to convince those who are on the fence about purchasing it. Hopefully there will be sales in the future. As great as the game is, the campaign does still feel incomplete, the AI needs significant improvement, and there's a surprisingly lacking amount of creature diversity (mods solve this).

Recommendations:
- IMO, playing with Jovian radiation is truly the best way to get the true game experience. When first learning the game, turning it off will make things easier. Once you get comfortable, start a new campaign and turn it on. Without the radiation, you will take more missions, make more money, and quickly become overpowered - taking any challenge out of the game. Having radiation on and a 1-2 mission count will make every mission, every salvage, and every mineral all that more important.
- Download mods. The developers are incredibly supportive of the mod community, and the quality and quantity of the mods reflects this. The mods alone at least double the overall game experience, and make the game worth the full $35 price tag. I recommend looking at Barotraumatic or any of the "extended" series, just as a start. I would avoid mods that add OP mechanics or make the game easier, but that's just me.
- Treat the campaign like it's a storyteller, and try not to restart the mission every time something doesn't go your way. Losing an AI crewmate because they decided to open the airlock without a suit at 5k meters adds to the chaotic and unpredictable story line - you ARE thousands of meters down in a foreign, alien inhabited ocean after all...

This is a game about trying to survive on a submarine on an alien moon, repelling threats like a giant eyeball, mudraptors or the ships medic. 
There is also a resource management aspect to it, but fortunately its not very complicated and usually boils down to figuring out which engineer will attempt to start an arms factory and shooting your captain if they come near the medical supplies.

You can build your own submarine, which is where most of my playtime and my sanity has gone. 

The sub editor is very versatile, allowing you to do pretty much anything as long as you have the nessesary know how. 
This leads to it being pretty complicated, but the basics are still pretty easy to learn and you can usually work yourself up from there. 

I can make a submarine that can help you create a Statement of operating costs based on german real estate laws* and thats not even the tip of the iceberg. 

*(provided you feed it the right information ofc) 
(I am not responsible for any legal documents creating using my submarines.)



TL;DR: if you like boats, suffering, coordinating with your friends, getting munched on by edritch horrors (and your security officer), extremely overcomplicated solutions to simple problems with a slight seasoning of grimdark, you should definitely give this game a try.

"This might be the first time a game made me actually FEEL seasick..."

I kept an eye on Barotrauma for a couple reasons. For one it was a Finnish game, which earns bonus points from me, but it was also a game about submarines, underwater perils and management of a ship, all of which sound GREAT to me!

But, as you might have noticed, the review I'm giving out with less than an hour spent playing the game is a negative one, and there are a few good reasons for that.

First and foremost: this is not really a game suited for single player. It is designed around the learning and mastery of complex systems and communicating with your crewmates on how to manage all of that together. Since one of the key systems to master is the physics-based movement of your character, efficient movement and communication feel key to success. However, the AI crewmates are immensely efficient and quick to act, making the players actions and input feel almost pointless, at least early on. 

That movement, along with the camera motion accompanying it, is why I gave up rather quickly. Movement and animation are based on physics, which is a neat idea and might allow for complex, unexpected interactions. All it did for me was send my character bumping into doors, ragdolling inside hatches I accidentally closed on myself and just generally acting sluggish and unresponsive. Add to this the fact that the camera lurches around quickly to track mouse movements and I found the game gave me a headache after just 15 minutes of play, unless I sat still and stared at the captain's screen, which wasn't much fun alone.

I feel Barotrauma borrows a lot of its ideas from Space Station 13, a complex game of varying roles for players to learn and adopt. But unlike SS13, Barotrauma cannot hide its complexities behind simplified visuals and instead tries to show and simulate a bit too much, easily overwhelming new players. It's quite telling that one of the first things the game offers you is a link to a wiki. A sign that the game simply lacks the tools with which to teach you all the mechanics you'll need to understand to play.

It's also a sign for me to move on.

I'd love to see more of the world on offer, to experience more adventures, but as a solo player there really isn't much here. With a group of friends and a lot of time, you might find this game worth your time, though.

Barotrauma is absolutely a game that you can play.

Is it a game you *want* to play, though? Well, I would imagine it would appeal to the sort of person who played Subnautica and thought, "no, this is too easy to control and to see what's going on, I want to be trapped inside of a bathtub, at the mercy of the whims of AI crewmen, while my head is stuffed inside a sack so I can't see anything and with the developer of QWOP in charge of the UI design"

And it's one of those games I feel a bit bad about giving a negative review because I can absolutely see what they were going for: Cold, darkness, claustrophobia, monsters and the potential to play it in co-op to survive, relying on the whims of NarutoXSephiroth666 rather than a janky AI crewman.

But it just sinks itself by having one of the clumsiest UI's I've ever dealt with, with a ton of information obscured from you, generally only seeing an ill-detailed sonar screen rather than, well, any of the actual darkness and spookiness around you. I think that 90% of my issues with the game could be cured if they just tossed out the sonar conceit, so I could see what was going on rather than having to guess, and made the interiors slightly more spacious. I know its supposed to be a submarine, but if you want those sorts of cramped environs, you also need the tightest controls known to man, which this game does not have.

Even just walking around a station or your own submarine feels like controlling a string puppet on the moon.

(Clicking on one singular pixel while being chased to open a door, stealing trash items initiates deadly force responses, you will be teleported outside of your submarine; many times, you will struggle with quests on a multiplayer server/friend group since the game cant handle multiple people talking to anyone, Quests bug out and you will have to retry certain objectives, you have to wipe a character and their perks if you want to no longer be locked in a class, you will lose dozens of objects in your inventory if you die outside of your sub, your body is almost always either eaten or smeared into paint making retrieval of items impossible)

Does everything worse and is so filled with little nit picky annoying things that the only people who will enjoy this at the end of its inevitable lifespan will be big foreheaded white men with thinning comb overs. The game feels like it's designed for 4+ people to play. Bots can handle simple tasks but can't be told to keep the sub organized. Unless you enjoy spending most of the time doing menial work, this is not the game for you. 

You'll find yourself running around different stations just to talk to the right NPCs for missions, supplies, and sub upgrades. Man has made it to Europa but didn't invent telecommunications. It would have been much simpler to have NPCs on a menu screen instead of having to jog everywhere just to tell them to ship X items to your sub. It felt like the game did everything to waste time; NPCs located as far from each other as possible, hatches connecting interior compartments don't open automatically, bought items do not get stocked automatically (or by bots) to the appropriate compartment, and the list goes on. I want to feel like I'm the captain of a space-age submarine, not the cabin boy of an 18th century sailing vessel.

The bots' AI is terrible and can't allow them to prioritize tasks. You're bleeding out defending the sub from intruders? Too bad, your bot medic is trying to fix leaks WHILE the monsters are still roaming the sub.

At the end of 4 sessions playing with my friend, we just couldn't find the moment when the game got fun.

On my first time entering a server one of my friends, knowing i had never played, injected all the opium on board into my head and 3 bottles of sulfuric acid into my blood.

I asked the medic to heal me but he said my injuries were to minor to waste any time on. I fell unconscious and was left for dead on the bottom of the ballast tank, i would have died if it wasn't for my friend who came and did CPR to revive me.

I came back thanking him even though he had basically killed me in the first place, but my thanks were short lived for he then inserted 90 units of alcohol into me and i went around vomiting all over the other crew.

My nausea left but i still was taking insane amounts of damage from my destroyed organs. I grabbed my shank and went off the find my friend. While he was in the cargo hold i stabbed him in the back twice before the captain came down into the hold to see whats going on. He saw me stabbing my friend so he pulled out his revolver and shot me in the head. I fell onto the ground and was paralyzed while my friend pulled out an SMG and mauled me with it.

I re-spawned in a shuttle and i set course back to the ship. Even though my little shuttle was faster than the main sub, we seemed to be getting further and further away from them. I then noticed three small green dots right next to the submarine following me on the sonar. Knowing that these dots were probably monsters i tried to find a gun on the shuttle but i sadly failed at this task when the shuttle smashed into a cliff. 

i turned to run to the navigation system but before i reached the ladder the wall in front of me burst open and water ripped into the room. I was on the verge of suffocation when i was able to grab a diving suit. i swam through the rooms and corridors of the shuttle trying to find a welding tool to fix the hole. I went through all the compartments in the shuttle but found that it had not been correctly supplied. 

I then sat at the bottom of the shuttle accepting my fate. The sound was just silent for a moment as i looked back of my fond memories of my short life. But this did not last for long as a thresher rammed through the neighboring wall of the sub and i was mauled to death while attempting to kill it with a screw driver. I died.

All in all the best experience i have enjoyed that much in a long time. I got to have a more glorified version of a story that five billionaires had, and i didn't even need to pay $250,000 for it! 11/10

Cons:
---The UI is really annoying. There is no keyboard key that opens doors, so you have to click on each door to open it. Same for ladders, which are everywhere.  Also there is no key to jump, the spacebar just makes you ragdoll in ridiculous fashion. You have to close all menus with right click.
---About 80% of this game is completely passive. You steer your sub waiting to get to your destination. If you are security, you sit at the guns waiting for an enemy to come. If you are medical, you wait until someone gets hurt and heal them. If you are engineer or mechanic, you wait until something breaks and fix it. From what I have played so far, the vast majority of the game is simply waiting for something else to happen. It puts me to sleep.
---This game does a terrible job of explaining itself. There is a tutorial for each of the roles & the basics, but it never explains other important concepts like fixing a beacon, navigating an outpost, or progressing in a campaign. Combined with an annoying UI it is a recipe for frustration.

Pros:
---The atmosphere is really cool, and it does a good job of feeling like an alien ocean full of danger
---Very good mod support
---Online multiplayer

Och, laddie, ye've brought up Barotrauma, a game that'll test yer very soul and leave ye feelin' as battered and broken as a shipwrecked sailor on the shores of despair. Prepare yerself for a tale of treacherous depths and heart-wrenchin' hardships that'll make ye question yer very existence.

Barotrauma is a survival game set in the icy depths of Europa, one o' Jupiter's moons. Ye and yer crewmates find yerselves aboard a submarine, embarkin' on a harrowin' journey through treacherous waters infested with all manner o' horrors. Ye'll face the relentless pressures of the ocean depths, the icy chill of the waters, and the constant threat of death lurkin' at every turn.

The first thing ye'll notice about Barotrauma is the sense of dread that hangs in the air like a thick fog. Ye'll be plunged into a world where darkness reigns supreme, and the only light ye'll see is the eerie glow of bioluminescent creatures, a constant reminder of the danger that surrounds ye. Every creak, every groan of the submarine will send shivers down yer spine, for ye know that disaster could strike at any moment.

Ye and yer crewmates will face a barrage of challenges that'll push ye to the very limits of yer endurance. Ye'll be fixin' leaks, managin' oxygen levels, and navigatin' the labyrinthine depths while facin' creatures that would make a kraken think twice. The pressure is on, laddie, and the consequences of failure are as unforgivin' as a Highland storm.

But what truly sets Barotrauma apart is its multiplayer aspect. Ye can gather a crew of brave souls and face the horrors of the deep together. But beware, for cooperation is key, and trustin' yer crewmates can be as tricky as navigatin' a treacherous reef. Betrayal and chaos can lurk just beneath the surface, threatenin' to tear ye apart like a shipwreck in a maelstrom.

Now, laddie, I must warn ye that Barotrauma is not for the faint o' heart. It's a game that revels in yer suffering, a masochistic voyage into the depths of hardcore survival. Ye'll face permadeath, catastrophic failures, and the unrelentin' forces of nature. But if ye have the fortitude and the will to endure, ye might find yerself emergin' from the abyss with a sense of accomplishment like no other.

So, if ye're ready to face yer fears and dive headfirst into the cold, unforgivin' embrace of Barotrauma, then prepare yerself, laddie. Brace yer heart for the pain, yer mind for the challenges, and yer spirit for the ultimate test of survival.

Now, I'll be off, seekin' me own thrills in the virtual realms. May yer submarine sail true, may yer crew be steadfast, and may yer resolve be as unyieldin' as a Scottish Highlander. Slàinte mhath!

I absolutely love this game. They've definitely improved the AI over the years, and as a solo player, I can definitely approve of it being solo-able, however there are still plenty questionable moments for the AI, that makes me question their underlying logic and code.

Note, however, that this is not exactly a complaint, but merely me wanting to point out some frustrations and funny moments.

Security Officer AI's appear to prioritize the most powerful ammo types over others. No matter where I hid the nuclear shell on my submarine, he'd always make it his damn mission to load and fire it first, after a reload, quickly turning my submarine into a notmarine.

Despite having my Security Officers set to prioritize hostiles on-board over manning the turrets, only one of them actually decided to do something against the two mudraptors having a party in the airlock, by which he promptly stared at them while the engineer was beating their [strike]meat[/strike] heads in and getting clawed to death.

While the engineer was literally lying on the floor bleeding to death, the medical AI decided it would be a better priority to administer minor medical treatments to my gunner across the other side of the submarine, running past the dying engineer at least twice.

Once the medical AI finally did decide to resurrect the engineer, he promptly ran away trying to fix mechanical devices before even being partially healed, to the point where he nearly bleed out and died again.

The AI also seems to enjoy hanging around Volatile Fulgurium Fuel rods, promptly getting themselves killed or causing my medical staff to waste my entire supply of antirad, unless they're part of a mission, in which case the medical AI will ignore them and let them die of Radiation Sickness.

Overall though, I do truly love this game from a solo perspective, and the few rounds I've had with friends has also been incredibly fun. Especially the horror part, which is coming from someone that nearly passes out playing other horror games.

Our captain guides us to the opening of a vast cave system in deep water and our crew starts to make preparations to exit the sub and explore inwards to find diamonds to mine. Me, being a foolish new recruit, leaves the safety of my team and within two minutes I am mauled to death by threshers. None of them know where I am, all they know is that I am dead and my corpse is missing. Three of the crew, failing to find my body, decide to go searching in the mine anyway where they happen across the diamonds. One has forgotten to take extra oxygen, so returns to the sub to resupply.

As soon as he returns to the sub it is attacked by a swarm of crawlers and a crawler mother and failing to counter-attack quickly, they puncture the hull and send the sub falling from the crevice it was tucked into at the entrance of the cave, separating the two members of the crew busy at work with their plasma cutters retrieving the diamonds from a rapidly descending sub quickly falling into panic. Managing to dispatch the crawlers, their sub gets stuck between two large rocks, preventing it from descending even more dangerously low. As soon as they manage to catch their breath, hammerheads attack- and at the same time, the two miners above discover the sub is gone. Out of batteries and dangerously low on oxygen, they begin their descent to make it back to the sub.

On the sub, the member of the crew who abandoned the mining crew for oxygen is killed by the hammerheads. By some miracle the two on the sub live, and return to patching it up. Above, one of the miners is running out of oxygen. In a moment of pure heart, the weaker of the two gives up the last of his remaining oxygen in the hopes at least one of them makes it back. Minutes go by. The sub is almost ready to move. 

The miner who gave up his oxygen dies with a quarter of the way left to go. The other grabs his corpse and continues to swim. The sub has been fixed, powers up, and prepares to make an ascent. The final miner makes it to the sub, and swims underneath to reach the airlock. Before he can close the airlock behind him, the sub immediately launches upwards, and the last living miner is thrown out of the airlock. He runs out of oxygen and perishes.

One of the major issues with the game is that it has a nasty habit of trivializing itself. Early game you face certain challenges that make the game interesting, but as you and your friends advance your skills, find new weapons, and upgrade the submarine, the monsters quickly become less of a threat until they are just a mild inconvenience. And god help you if you play as medic, electrician, or mechanic. You will fall victim to the same repetitive game play loop especially after all the upgrades. Despite the wide variety of medical items and advanced healing system in game, you will only use the same 3. The pool is wide, but very shallow. 

This game left me wanting more. What is here is awesome but so limited.

A somewhat steep learning curve for new players but once you figure out the basics, this game is a lot of fun.

- manage a crew of specialists who each have their own roles and skills (captain, engineer, doctor etc)
- ensure your submarine stays fuelled, repaired and use it to explore the ocean and complete missions for different factions on Europa
- fight hostile wildlife, including some creepy/ scary boss fights with huge creatures in the deep sea

Gameplay-wise, it feels like a much more fleshed out FTL, it's 2D and consists of traversing through dangerous environments between different set points on the map, going between colonies and stations to get missions, upgrade your sub and recruit new crew members.

I have only scratched the surface of the game, but so far I'm having a lot of fun with it, definitely recommend. You can play it single player with bots but it's a lot more fun with a few friends.

Edit 1: *Sigh* It's been a bit since my original review now, so I will give an update to it as promised. Unfortunately, the answer is nuanced, and the nuance won't come across well. Regardless, I will try to convey my opinion well

To start, it has become painfully apparent that the developers are being actively hostile to the community, as their response to bad optimization and poor inventory management is to remove inventory management. Which is unfortunate, but fine and almost expected. However, this leads me to my first crucial point of the review: If you want a vanilla experience, don't buy the game. Vanilla will waste your time and hurt your feelings because if you don't play *exactly* how the developers want you to, including not playing one of the game modes, then you will not have fun....however, there is hope.

This leads me to the second part, which is: Modding. If you treat the game like one developed by Bethesda, which is to say, the game itself is fine. Not good, but not terrible: "It just works." ...however, the game itself is a platform for mods. Then Baro becomes an enjoyable experience. I don't think I am overstating it when I say that mods are the reason the game is still alive today. If you don't mind the hour or two setup of mods, and dealing with the headache of fixing them every so often as the developers making modding their game worse, then you will probably enjoy it.

In summary, if you're looking for a "vanilla" experience from Barotrauma, don't buy it. If you want to mod the game to hell and back, then buy it on sale because my god 34 dollars is an insane price.

Original: This review is hard to write. I've played and loved this game for a long time now. I've made countless subs (Some on the workshop, some for private use) and was forced to remake them as well, which I'll get into later. I've laughed with friends while being a literal clown, and in the next moment been trying my hardest to save the sub from something out of a Lovecraftian horror. Through all of that, I believed the developers had the best intentions for this game. That is, until recently.
The past few updates, as a seasoned player, have been worrying. In the past, they have broken the sub editor and/or the subs made with it, forcing many (Including me) to remake the sub from scratch. This, while annoying, always seemed to be for the better, albeit not without growing pains of something new. However, the more recent updates seem to break a lot of the core functionality or changing it in a way so unrecognisable that it is hard to even begin to understand. To be clear, the sub editor was never intuitive to begin with but these changes made it much worse.
However, I understand making a sub from scratch isn't for everyone and some people just want to play the game. Well. Recent updates on the campaign side of things just made that much much harder for you. Barotrauma was never an easy game. Nor were any of its mechanics easily understood (Especially Medical as a lot of the in-game tips were wrong). It was hard, and hard to get into. Recently, they made it so selling items salvaged off of less fortunate submarines than yours, or even items you made/mined yourself significantly less valuable meaning it takes significantly longer to get *required* upgrades to your sub to progress. In simple terms, it makes the game significantly grind-ier. This is before I mention that those same items no longer give you as many materials when deconstructed, making repurporsing them effectively impossible (As the cost is now too great). All of this is without mentioning how punishing the game is for being under prepared, which was a good attribute until making it improbable that *anyone* would be prepared. One smaller thing to note as well is that recently there was a colony update which, did sound awesome on paper, however in practice didn't change much aside from making you walk significantly longer distances to buy what you wanted, or in many cases, needed.
To sum up my thoughts, the game was really good and had the potential to be amazing, however recent updates make me question if the developers have good intentions for their player base or if something more sinister is around the corner. The game, in its current state, shouldn't be picked up by any newer player, and veterans like myself might have to seriously consider retirement (I personally have chosen that route for the time being). Maybe I'll be pleasantly surprised by a positive change, but until then do not buy this game.
I hope I will be able to change this review. But until then, TL;DR-Game was good, had potential then developers squandered opportunities and made it a grind.

Squad is a game being created and developed by Offworld Industries. It was approved on Steam Greenlight, Kickstarter-funded and is currently has left Steam Early Access for full release.

Squad is an online, team-based, military themed first-person-shooter where high levels of teamwork and communication are crucial to success.

Built from the ground up in the Unreal Engine 4, Squad pits teams of up to 100 players against each other in white knuckle modern day combined-arms combat scenarios, with both conventional and unconventional forces.

It makes sense why this game has been in development since 2015. The amount of content alone is baffling. If you're reading reviews to see if the game is worth it. Let me save you some time, It definitely is. If you like this kind of content, this is the best example of it that I have ever seen. Not to mention that on top of some of the most interesting and oddly terrifying gameplay (Witch in my opinion is worth 35$ on its own) It has a captivating and interesting story that ends in an extremely satisfying conclusion that is left up to Interpretation, and solves everything that it needs to from a thematic standpoint, And It doesn't waste any time doing it. This is one of my favorite games of all time, and from somebody who writes Scripts and enjoys learning about what makes them great, this is one of the greatest stories that I have seen in the video game medium. This Game is Extraordinary, Its worth your money, and its worth your time.

Barotrauma is a good game. It's fun with friends and is playable solo with bot crew. Vanilla experience stays varying stage to stage. Understanding the downsides of your vessel is important so that you don't sink.

Modded experience can by very bumpy. Using the same modset, players on similar power machines can get different experiences. There might be a bug that just kicks you to lobby and doesn't let you back until the crew in-game finishes the level or restarts the server. Or the point where everything is seemingly alright, but few of the players are having much lower frames than usual. Having a few overhaul mods can be alright. But enable too much and the experience will not be as good as you would expect.

I am a mechanic, my job is to fix the submarine's systems. I am a vital aspect in surviving in the submarine. One day, at the post, I find myself a pipe, and a box of tobacco seeds. Of course, who wouldn't plant seeds? Its human nature! As I grew the seeds in the reactor, my senses got to me, and I got one of the seeds, turned it into a smoke-able substance, and smoked that bitch clean. This wasn't an addiction, i'm only 70% addicted according to the medic, so there's no need to fix anything when you can grow tobacco. As the days went on, my crew was wondering; "why is he not fixing anything?" The answer is that I had 2 supply boxes full of tobacco, and got the captain high on it. The Roots spread across half the ship before my crew eventually beat my ass because I wasn't fixing shit. Was it worth it? No, it really wasn't. I think it was too good of a price, maybe a bit more expensive would make it worth it, and a fair trade, because this was too good.

A hidden gem with a slow dev cycle. This game could be so much more.

I think Barotrauma is a fun game, but I think the development focus sometimes feels mismanaged, and the pricepoint is *way* too high for what the base-game offers. With the modding workshop you can get hundreds of hours of entertainment, but 35$ (26$ on sale usually) is an outrageous pitch to friends for a game you need WELL over two hours to get into.

The premise is pretty straightforward, play submarines on an alien planet. 

The problem is that sometimes the game itself is maybe too straight-forward. Without expansions to the gameplay offered by player mods, many of the jobs are too simple and/or unexciting, and the gameplay doesn't vastly change or improve over time. May of the developer decisions are bit a questionable, hard to understand.

I like the game, I really do, but the developers are clearly not interested in making it more engaging and interesting for players in a timely fashion now that the framework for the base game was finished with having left early access. The price point is too high for a niche game, that offers no major end-game content without the workshop.

----Quick rundown on why jobs stay boring----
Captain: Your goal of piloting the ship means you stand around, looking at a sonar map for hundreds of hours.

Mechanic: Many of your trees are mediocre and don't give you much to do. Your main job (repairs) becomes less necessary as other crewmates level up their skills, and you feel useless besides some overpowered talents from your skill tree.

Electric Engineer ("Nukies"): Your primary job is very intense, and very important, but perhaps also a but dull. Your potential for getting into mayhem is significantly high with your talents, especially since you can get a remote control for the reactor. But your base kit is boring and can often be managed automatically, that you just sit around playing with logic gates and circuits fruitlessly trying to do "cool" things to automate the sub.

Security: Maybe the only fun job, as you get to shoot at things and become harder to kill, but conversely you don't have any extremely interesting talents to begin with. 

Medic: Bandage. Morphine spam. Bio glue if they're really torn up. Your talents are neat but you probably won't use most of them that much.

It is weird to describe why exactly this game is enjoyable to me. Normally I could distill it down to things like a specific mechanic being satisfying to use or the story being immersive and--while these things are true for this game as well--are not why I would recommend this game.

This game is one huge "you had to be there" moment. It is a "0-100" simulator. It is a game that will test how well you can command, be commanded, improvise, and strategize and, in between all of that, are long conversations with your buddies that will somehow develop into what each of you thinks the meaning of life is.

It is for those reasons that I would recommend this game.

I can review this game to anyone thinking about purchasing this game. 

This game is an acquired taste. To put that in perspective. 
The map is laid out like FTL with a board with destinations connected with strings where there are between 12-15 destinations along the road. 

According to the steam achievements list, 36% of players have not gone farther than 10km which is not even one single move from the tutorial area to their first of many destinations.

This game has the potential to be the most scary, nail-biting experience as you watch your crew mates die in increasingly horrible ways before your submarine is lost to the black void of the ocean...
Or it can be the most zany, nonsensical sequence of events that leaves you confused and laughing so hard you can't see the literal clown approaching you with a gun.
Bring some friends and scream.

Barotrauma is a fun game. It has evolved into a pretty solid playing experience with version 1.0.
I love the detailed environments. The submarine systems, crafting, rewiring, combat mechanics. All work together to create a very complex and spooky experience. Exploring sunken wrecks, abandoned beacon stations and alien ruins, all the while clearing all sorts of enemies. Also juggling constantly between states of calm and chaos. Balancing the needs of the ship and the needs of the crew. This is the kind of game which is a blast with friends. EDIT: I've since got hooked on the Sub Editor. Making a powerful variant of the Humpback, and a Tier III sub and shuttle almost 99% done. Sub editor is even more addictive than the main game :)

Dive into an Unforgiving Abyss

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Barotrauma is an intense and immersive survival game that plunges players into the depths of a treacherous alien ocean. Developed by Undertow Games and FakeFish, this cooperative multiplayer experience offers a unique blend of horror, strategy, and exploration that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

Set in the distant future, Barotrauma presents a dystopian world where humanity has colonized the moons of Jupiter. The game revolves around the struggle to survive and maintain a submarine as players venture deeper into the abyssal depths. The oppressive atmosphere, coupled with the constant threat of hostile creatures and malfunctioning systems, creates an intense and nerve-wracking experience.

One of the standout features of Barotrauma is its intricate gameplay mechanics. Each player assumes a specific role on the submarine, such as captain, engineer, mechanic, or medic. Cooperation and communication are paramount as you work together to navigate through dangerous waters, repair critical systems, and fend off aggressive underwater creatures. The depth of the gameplay and the need for coordination make for engaging and dynamic multiplayer sessions.

The game's graphics, while not groundbreaking, effectively portray the hauntingly beautiful and eerie underwater environments. The attention to detail in the creature designs and the unsettling ambiance contribute to the overall sense of immersion and tension. The sound design, with its creaking metal, echoing sonar pings, and ominous background music, further enhances the atmospheric experience.

Barotrauma's steep learning curve may deter some players initially. Mastering the controls and understanding the complex systems of the submarine can be overwhelming, especially for newcomers. However, once you overcome this initial hurdle and grasp the mechanics, the game rewards you with a deep and satisfying gameplay loop.

The game's replayability is a double-edged sword. On one hand, the randomly generated levels and emergent gameplay make each playthrough feel fresh and unpredictable. However, the lack of a strong narrative or progression system may leave some players searching for a deeper sense of purpose. While the multiplayer experience shines brightest, the game also offers a single-player mode with AI-controlled crew members, though it does not capture the same level of excitement and camaraderie as playing with friends.

Despite a few minor shortcomings, Barotrauma offers a compelling and nerve-wracking underwater survival experience. Its immersive gameplay, intricate mechanics, and cooperative multiplayer dynamics provide hours of thrilling gameplay. Whether you enjoy intense teamwork, atmospheric exploration, or facing the unknown dangers of the deep, Barotrauma is a game that truly submerges you in its harrowing and unforgiving world.

The following is an accurate representation of my first time experience:

-Spawn in the respawn shuttle as an Engineer
-Wait for transport to our sub
-Land on top of the sub while it's on the verge of collapse
-Put on a disposable diving suit and exit from the hatch
-The sub starts moving up once we exit and we almost get crushed by it against a ceiling
-The sub then starts to rapidly sink leaving us desperately swimming after the sub
-After what feels like hours of swimming we finally reach the sub at 14% oxygen left in our tanks
-Upon entry we take off our suits and immediately get to work
-Everything proceeds as normal for a while
-I do a little trolling and remove a button from a ballast room with an automatically closing door
-Our chief engineer gets stuck in the ballast room and loses consciousness from drowning
-Our captain and I drag him out of the room and give him CPR, good as new
-As we go back to look at the room, our chief engineer wants to show me something
-He takes me to the sub's shuttle bay, telling me if shit hits the fan we're gonna get in the shuttle and go away
-As we go in the shuttle, our head of security undocks the shuttle
-The sub's only engineers are now off the ship
-I scream at our head of security accusing him of being a traitor and proceed to stab him with the knife I stole from one of his duffel bags
-He turns away from piloting the shuttle (which he did not know how to do) to shoot me
-The bullets hit the control panel causing the shuttle to be stuck at full acceleration
-The shuttle collides with a rock at extremely high speeds, causing immediate depressurization and killing all of us on impact
-The shuttle continues to speed off after impact with our captain chasing after the shuttle unaware that we have all died
-Our bodies explode shortly after

The Ulysses incident is still under investigation. As of this review, the three crew members and the shuttle involved are still MIA.

[olist]
[*]I spawn into my first sub as a medic, greeted by the captain who was dressed as a clown and playing a harmonica in my face (Immediately, what the fuck?).

[*]I went into the medical bay where there was already 2 dead people and another unconscious.

[*]At the same time, I could hear screaming of an engineer and a couple security guys saying "THEY GOT IN, THEY GOT IN!"

[*]I grabbed medical supplies and tried my best to resuscitate the unconscious guy in the medbay using what I learned in the tutorial which absolutely did not prepare me for the chaos and bullshit that was going on.

[*]The guy dies, I had literally no idea what I was doing.

[*]I grab his crowbar and sprint into the captains quarters where my superior officer, the clown, was using a shotty to hold off an unbelievable number of monsters. I help him by Morgan Freemaning the shit out of their skulls.

[*]We're both dying, the clown goes unconscious, I manage to save myself from the same fate. I perform CPR on the clown and bring him back to life.

[*]We both limp below deck where only the engineer is left, he somehow killed them all and was repairing the breaches.

[*]The clown gets on the hull guns, his happy facepaint hiding his terrified tears.

[*]I help the engineer repair the ship. Whilst we are repairing the electrics, he is shocked and goes into cardiac arrest. I perform CPR and somehow bring him back from joining the rest of the crew in the forever sleep.

[*]We get the ship powered again, I take over the guns from the clown, he climbs the ladder back up to his alien-corpse-ridden quarters and directs us towards the closest docking station.

[*]With me shooting down the horde, the engineering performing repairs (still screaming btw), and the clown steering us home, we somehow manage to achieve our goal.
[/olist]

Have you ever wanted to gun down eldritch abominations and explore the unfathomable horrors of Europa, all while maintaining your submarine and your sanity? If your answer is no, I don't want to be friends with you.

To sum this game up, you and your buddies (or bots) have to pilot a submarine through the depths of the previously-mentioned moon of Jupiter, gaining cash money and upgrading to go deeper and deeper until deep doesn't have a meaning anymore. Sounds fun, right? That's because I didn't say anything about what monsters lurk in the deep dark sea-- there's a lot of them, and they only get scarier and tougher to take down as you progress.

The game doesn't have too much of a direct narrative, but there are story-like quests and a very vast world to explore. You'll be meeting interesting groups such as; the big-bad government, small and disorganized rebel forces, a cult that wants to turn everyone into parasite zombies, and a group I can really only describe as "the entire circus." 

I love this game, and you probably will too if any part of what I just said sounded fun to you.

An awesome 2D Submarine simulator that makes you feel near constant dread because hazards are everywhere and facing anything outside the ship is risky and dangerous. It makes you feel small and insignificant almost in a Lovecraftian way (which is very valid).
It's mostly a co-op game (wouldn't recommend going solo) about keeping the submarine going, completing missions and staying alive in and increasingly hostile environment.

I'd give the game an awesome 9/10. I find it really fun - especially with friends - but definitely not a game for everyone. If you don't mind 2D games and aren't easily deterred by complicated and hard things - you may be pretty interested in this game. And here are my thoughts:

There's a pretty good, complete main campaign that doesn't really have "missions" within itself as you go, only a final destination and some hurdles on the way. There's PvP, traitor mode (which isn't fleshed out too well at the time of writing), chaos mode and pretty much whatever you can think of and make on your server.
There are multiple mission types that you can complete in between outposts, maps are generated based on current biomes (with their looks and quirks), if you're looking for something to do in between mission areas you can usually find something to explore or get resources from.
At the start you pick one of the classes which have different starting stats, equipment and - most importantly; in campagin only AFAIK - different perks which can make not only classes but characters specialise in distinct areas.
The main focus of the game is mechanics - it's pretty advanced in that area: different types of damage and wounds (and medical system to match) on separate limbs that influence how well you can use them, repairing things requires tools designated to repair them, repairing things that are currently powered may prove shockingly hard for the unexperienced, other creatures - while being very different - still follow the same rules as your character does, mining and gathering underwater plants, crafting system for a ton of things, modifying the ship with basic logic gates (useful making automatic or just better systems for your ship) and more.
There are submarine, outpost and creature creators. Though creating a non-small submarine or an outpost takes dedication and a lot of time. Also there's a vibrant modding community - a lot of ships, some items and a few deeper mods.

When you start you will likely feel absolutely outmatched, underequipped and unexperienced (though it's not that bad anymore at the very start of the campaign) and you'll probably be right, but don't let it discourage you. It takes time, practice and failing a bunch to start getting good at the game and figuring out what works, what doesn't. But you will get good, less panicky and more confident.

Space is dark and frightening but the void is mostly empty. However the deep tells a different story, However the deep tells a different story.
With no way home and a surface bombarded with radiation we have no choice then to venture deeper. It is cold, it is dark, it bears many similarities to space. But down here it is also wet, the pressure is maddening and the darkness, is not empty.
With no way to see then short spotlights you must rely on sonars, but every pulse tells the void where you are.
The deep may be horrifying,  but the terror of humanity is as well. As the safety of outposts shelter us from the void, it does not from ourselves.
Form a crew to trust through dark and deep, yet be wary of each member. Upgrade your submarine to protect and guide you, be know you are never safe. Build your relations with a faction, but remember all allies brings enemies. Dive towards the center to uncover the mysteries and riches at its core, as wells as its nightmares and ends.
Care for your marine, care for your crew. Beware the creatures, beware the unknown. Endure the pressure, endure the cold. Strengthen your body, fortify your mind. Rise as a living legend, or sink as a corpse.

The game is a great and somewhat innovative game. However, there are 2 issues that remain.

1. You have to be a person of a very specific type (clever enough to understand and be proficient with all the stuff game has to offer, and one-minded enough that you don't notice dozens of things that you can exploit or "rig" in this game) to enjoy the game unconditionally. Otherwise, you have to either bring up your patience game (former) or bring up your self restraint (latter) game to enjoy this.

2. 1.0 is, unfortunately, very rushed. Game is yet to be properly operational for a release game instead of EA. I'm fairly certain this is Daedalic's doing, and devs are doing their best to build a lot from a shaky ground, but a rushed release is a rushed release.

With these 2 reasons, I cannot in good conscience say this game is currently a recommend, despite how many hours I have poured into it.

Buy the game. Decide to join as a spectator to watch your friends and learn how a sub is run. Get drafted by the game and be thrown into an ongoing round in a tiny, claustrophobic shuttle. Hear things scratching at the walls as you scream in voice trying to figure out what's going on.
Get rescued by your friends as they change course to pick you up before the crawlers get inside. Become the all-round shipmonkey with wrench, screwdriver and welding tool who doesn't have any mechanical skills but a shitty weld is still better than an unsanctioned window to the abyss.
Operate the gunnery stations. Pepper crawlers with coilguns. Fend off raptors with machine guns. Find out what "danger close" means when you notice too late that the first round in the railgun rack is the special Honkenheimer™ brand nuclear shell spiced up with an extra bike horn in its payload slot. Flash-boil yourself, half the submersible and an entire crawler swarm including their mother.
Decide to do a little funny. Sneak around a Separatist station. Steal every oxygen tank you find, including the ones in the emergency diving suits. Use a plasma cutter to flood the crew quarters and watch as the traitors rush to get to the diving suits before the reality of several hundred thousand liters of water rushing in can assert itself upon them. Smile, knowing you have already repo'd all the canned breathing fumes for your own hoard like a particularly vile undersea magpie.
Realize you have killed likely a significant part of the human population on Europa. Realize you have become a monster worse than what you have encountered up to this point.

Welcome to goddamn Barotrauma. You don't have to be insane to play this game, and it really doesn't help, but you'll get there anyway.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.
