This game is really really good. I don't really know how they made this a near perfect co-op, players vs. environment game. It's honestly pretty easy to hop into; the first time I played I just jumped into a co-op game of like 10 friends and still contributed. There's just something really fun about the whole crew working together trying to deal with a Latcher dragging your ship into the abyss. There's enough little things that need fixed or tended to all the time that you never get bored. 

The jobs are segmented enough where you can focus on one specialty and completely ignore medicine and crafting, for example, so you never get overwhelmed. I've had at least half a dozen friends do the same and they really enjoy the game. Yet there's a pretty tall learning curve if you want to dig deep about say wiring or crafting. 

The marketing for this game is trying to make it sort of a horror game, but the art style and controls really make this not scary at all. It's far more spooky, which is just kind of the games mood. 

Anyways, I've literally only played campaign on easy mode, and there's like 4 or 5 other game modes that I haven't even looked at yet, and I'm already trying to get all my friends to play this game.

If you're here because of Titan and wondering if the game is good outside of just a timely meme, yes.. yes it is. The game can be as high pressure as the surrounding water when certain happenings begin to happen around your vessel. Task delegation seems to be important with clearly defined roles and appropriate workloads for each friend-turned-crewmate to ensure utmost efficiency and accuracy. 

Here is a description of our last 30 minute or so play-though leaving the starting station. As captain of our sizeable crew of 3 individuals it was also my duty to be a repairman, "trained" medical professional, and de-facto head of security all at the same time. Other crewmates had similar workload sizes with extra hands being needed for various important tasks such as repeated electrocution and morphine overdose. We begin our journey by simply undocking and turning on our active sonar to explore the surrounding waters. Unfortunately, this decision drew in a few of the local sea natives who began chewing at our seran-wrap layered hull finding an easy way in to our vessel. Of course, to deal with this situation we sent our strongest man who was currently busy with nothing important (reactor upkeep) to deal with these intruders. The fight was eventually ended with a few welding tools and a couple well places shots by yours truly the captain, with his trusty revolver. Unfortunately, during this endeavor the reactor was left in a manual operation mode and had completely expended its resident 2 fuel rods with 1 micron of uranium in them. This led to a small blackout aboard our vessel causing a catastrophic sinkage to occur. Fast forward about 20 seconds we impact the bottom completely removing the metal foil protecting our bottom half allowing a vast amount of water to enter the living compartments. Our reactor man eventually succumbed to multiple bite wounds , lacerations, and internal bleeding in the following scuffle with the natives that came with the liquid. Captain and extra man attempted to repair the hull breaches only to find no metal foil left on the holes to weld. Captain and extra man decide it best to swim back to the station with extra man not grabbing sufficient oxygen and eventually suffocating in the black nothingness on the way back to home. Captain overwhelmed with grief over the untimely demise of his crew decided the only recourse was removing the diving suit in the middle of the abyss. Captain removes his diving suit and is surprised by nothing happening in the seconds after, shouting with glee to his fallen comrades spirits watching over him. In the following second the emotional roller coaster comes to it's downhill portion when the surrounding water realizes it has been deceived and captain is actually not in fact wearing his protective sweater. Surrounding water implodes captain crushing not just his body, but his dreams entirely. 

If you made it through my 2:00AM literary abilities congratulations. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has some friends to play with, the more the better, and if no friends and you're driven enough you can play with bots which join your crew for money at stations or with other online randoms via the server browser. I would expect a slightly-below average crew cohesion though if you choose to play with randoms (sabotage may be a common occurrence) maybe thats fun though.

The game is more for multiplayer, local bots on your submarine are pretty bad. First I tried tutorial, but had to abandon it after I could not get further with oxygen and suite, it was making some noise and artifacts on screen that made me feel nauseous.

In first mission I used autopilot, and when I was close to next base, my submarine lost all power and caught on fire. Bots informed that there is fire and did nothing to save sub, I found fire extinguisher and tried to remove fire but died. Now I would need to replay whole mission and probably catch random fire and die again. Meh, better back to other games with reasonable interface where game is better balanced.

Also periscope interface was awful.

Personally, this game wasn't really something I enjoyed. 
But now I realize with the sub creator and roleplay capabilities I can have the $250,000 experience for a minut fraction of the cost!
